headline: Berry Crisp Cake Recipe
description: This cake is rich and tangy with mascarpone cheese, spiked with sweet white wine. Once baked, the berries sink into the cake and burst, becoming a built-in layer of fresh jam, while the crumble melts and crisps into a cookie-like crust that provides wonderful textural contrast. Serve it warm with a scoop of vanilla ice cream or at room temperature with a cup of steaming coffee in the morning.
name: Berry Crisp Cake Recipe
keywords: blackberries, cake, crumbles, Let them eat cake
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup (about 3 1/2 ounces) packed light brown sugar
6 tablespoons unsalted butter, chilled and cut into small pieces
3/4 cup sweet white wine, such as riesling or moscato
2 sticks (8 ounces) unsalted butter, at room temperature
20 ounces fresh mixed berries, such as blackberries and raspberries

recipeInstructions.text: For the Crisp Topping: In medium bowl, combine brown sugar and flour. Add butter, and with fingertips, rub together and toss until mixture resembles coarse meal. Stir in oats, almonds, and salt. Refrigerate until needed.
For the Cake: Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 350°F. Coat 13- by 9-inch baking pan with baking spray.
In medium bowl, whisk together flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt. In small bowl, whisk together wine, mascarpone, and vanilla until blended.

Beat sugar, butter, and lemon zest on medium speed until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Add eggs, one at a time, beating well after each addition. Reduce speed to low and add flour mixture in 3 additions, alternating with wine mixture, scraping down sides and bottom of bowl with rubber spatula as needed. Scrape batter into prepared pan.

For the Fruit Layer and Assembly: In large bowl, toss together berries, sugar, lemon juice and salt. Distribute berry mixture in even layer on top of cake batter. Sprinkle berries with reserved crisp topping.
Bake until cake tester inserted in center of cake comes out clean, about 45 minutes. Transfer cake to cooling rack and cool to room temperature, about 1 hour.

review.reviewBody: Half of the crisp topping was swallowed up by the cake during baking. Does anyone know why this might have happened?

headline: Chocolate Biscoff Truffles Recipe
description: Another fun way to use Biscoff spread, these truffles are a melt-in-your-mouth combination of dark chocolate and warming spices.
name: Chocolate Biscoff Truffles Recipe
keywords: Biscoff, chocolate, truffles

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium, heavy-bottomed sauce pan, heat heavy cream over medium low heat until warm. Add chocolate and cook, stirring frequently, until melted. Stir in vanilla, take off heat, and immediately stir in Biscoff spread until mixture is smooth.

Pour mixture into a bowl and freeze until firm but pliant, about 1 1/2 hours. Pour cinnamon into a shallow bowl. Scoop one tablespoon of mixture and roll between palms of your hand until round. Roll truffle in cinnamon to coat and place on a plate. Continue with remaining mixture. Place truffles back in freezer for 10 minutes to stiffen. Serve. This Recipe Appears In 
 Sweet Hacks: Chocolate Biscoff Truffles

review.reviewBody: I made these today. They turned out to be perect little truffles. They were very easy to prepare. The Biscoff flavor isn't really that pronounced, but this recipe has inspired me to make all sorts of truffles using all sorts of chocolate(basically a common bar is what the recipe calls for), Biscoff, vanilla, and whipping cream. The possibilities are endless.
This sounds amazing. Can't wait to try it out!

headline: Vegan Peanut, Sweet Potato, and Kale Soup With Coconut Recipe
description: The version of West African groundnut soup I ate in my youth was a thick, peanut-packed broth made with chicken, spices, and tomatoes, but recipes for maafe (as it's called in Mali) vary hugely.
name: Vegan Peanut, Sweet Potato, and Kale Soup With Coconut Recipe
keywords: comfort, kale, low carb, soup, sweet potato
recipeIngredient: 1 1/2-inch knob of ginger, peeled and roughly chopped
1 small bunch cilantro (about 1 1/2 ounces; 45g), thick stems reserved separately from leaves and tender small stems
1 Serrano or jalapeño chili, stemmed and halved, divided
6 scallions, whites and pale green parts only, thinly sliced, divided
1 quart water or homemade vegetable stock (see note)
8 ounces sweet potatoes, peeled and cut into 1/2-inch dice (about 2 small sweet potatoes; 225g)
1 (5-ounce; 140g) bunch lacinato kale, thick stems discarded, leaves very roughly chopped
1 tablespoon (15ml) fresh juice from 1 to 2 limes
Hot sauce, such as Frank's Red Hot, to taste
Rice, for serving (I like using red or black rice)

recipeInstructions.text: Combine garlic, ginger, thick cilantro stems, and half of the chile in the bowl of a mortar and pestle (see notes). Sprinkle with about 1 teaspoon of salt. Pound into a rough paste and set aside. Thinly slice remaining half chile and set aside for garnish.

Open 1 can of coconut milk and carefully spoon off about 3 tablespoons of the solid fat from the surface and place it in a large Dutch oven. Add 1 tablespoon of vegetable oil. Heat over medium-high heat, stirring frequently, until coconut fat separates and solids start to sizzle, about 4 minutes. Continue cooking, stirring constantly, until solids turn pale golden brown, about 1 minute longer. Add the pounded garlic/ginger mixture and cook, stirring, until aromatic, about 30 seconds. Add half of sliced scallions and turmeric and cook, stirring, until lightly softened, about 1 minute.

Add remaining contents of both cans of coconut milk along with 1 quart of water or stock. Add sweet potatoes. Bring to a boil, and reduce to a bare simmer. Cook until sweet potatoes are totally softened, about 15 minutes.

Meanwhile, combine peanuts and remaining tablespoon of oil in a medium skillet set over medium heat. Cook, tossing and stirring frequently, until peanuts are a deep golden brown, about 8 minutes. Immediately transfer to a bowl to prevent scorching.

Transfer 1/2 cup of peanuts to a cutting board and roughly chop. Reserve for garnish. Transfer half of the remaining peanuts to the now-empty mortar and pestle. Sprinkle with 1 teaspoon sugar and a pinch of salt. Pound to form a rough paste, then transfer to pot of soup. Repeat with the other half of the remaining peanuts.

When potatoes are fully softened, blend soup until mostly smooth but a little texture remains using a hand blender directly in the pot or by transferring to a countertop blender in batches. Bring to a simmer, stir in kale, and cook until kale is completely wilted and tender, about 5 minutes. Stir in lime juice. Season soup to taste with salt, pepper, and hot sauce. Stir in cilantro, reserving some for garnish. Serve soup with rice, sprinkled with cilantro, chopped peanuts, scallions, and sliced chiles.

review.reviewBody: This recipe is delicious. But.... it is not a 45 minute recipe. More like an hour and a half. There are many ways to speed this up and still have it come out just as tasty. Crushing up chopped peppers in a mortal and pestle is very time consuming. Next time I'll use a food processor. The texture won't be exactly the same, but they end up all getting pureed in the soup anyway. I made the peanut butter from scratch, as suggested, but to shorten the time, just use about 1/2 cup of peanut butter. I doubled the sweet potatoes and it needed it. Two small sweet potatoes for 2 cans of coconut milk and vegetable broth is not enough texture or flavor. Lastly, large chopped kale, added at the end, to an already pureed soup, was just not palatable (and I love kale). I ended up pureeing the kale into the soup. It left little green specks, which were lovely, and I wasn't getting soggy chucks of mushy kale stuck in my teeth. Top the soup with chopped peanuts, some hot sauce and chopped cilantro. It's a beautiful and tasty soup that I'll make again, with the shortcuts.

Super delicious. Definitely takes way longer than described (as all online recipes, esp. Serious Eats ones). 
Whatever you do, don't skip the Frank's Red Hot. It really takes this dish from a B+ to a solid A. Want to take it to A+? Do yourself a favor and along with the red/black rice and raw garnishes, throw in some mandolined (or shredded with a knife, but mandolin cut is *chef's kiss*) red cabbage. The crunch and visual appeal it adds are the only things this recipe needs.

I give this recipe only 3 stars as the prep time took way too long and the recipe said ‘45 minutes start to finish’. And while I know that the ‘recipe authors’ timing never really quite matches that of the ‘home chef’, really it just took way too long (I will blame my vodka cranberry tomorrow!) Harumph! 
The flavor on the other hand was quite delicious! My teenager, ‘the one who does not like sweet potatos’ loved the soup … ‘did I say sweet potato, or carrot soup (she loves carrots) hehe ;),;).
Changes:
-Instead of using coconut milk, I used coconut cream. It was a minor oversight at the grocery store today, but thought the mistake worked out quite well. 
-I doubled the amount of ginger (We love ginger)
-And, while I started out using my mortar and pestal to grind the green onion, ginger, Serrano peppers, and garlic I ended up tossing them into 
the food processor as my hands were exhausted. 
- As for the peanuts … I just used a dough roller to chop for the garnish and food processor to make the peanut paste.

Excellent recipe. I used no-sugar added peanut butter, added some fish sauce and a bit of coriander and it was a hit. I don't understand the comments describing this dish as bland. I think the issue may be that a key step, simmering the blended soup until thickened properly, isn't explicit in the recipe. Highly recommended.

I used a garlic press to crush the garlic, and I used a cup of high-quality peanut butter in lieu of crushed peanuts. Did not have a mortar and pestle, so just threw the minced garlic, grated ginger, and half the chopped scallions and japlapeno into the hot oil for 30-60 seconds, then dumped in the two cans of coconut milk, chicken stock, and sweet potatoes, bringing it to a boil.

Once the sweet potatoes were tender, I mixed in the cup of peanut butter, then used an immersion blender to thicken. Then, I threw in a huge handful of frozen, pre-chopped kale and while it simmered, cut the lime into wedges - I used the juice from the whole lime. The acidity added nice balance to the flavor. Salt to taste.

I also added Sriracha. Sambal Oelek would be nice too instead of regular hot sauce. I garnished with the remaining scallions and jalapeno, and I didn't even bother with the rice.

It didn't look as pretty as the one in the picture, but it tasted great and was a lot less labor intensive!

headline: Shortbread Sandwiches Recipe
description: The beauty of these cookies is their versatility. Play around: you can fill them with jam, Nutella, peanut butter, or chocolate ganache.
name: Shortbread Sandwiches Recipe
keywords: cookie, cookie monster, Jam, nutella
recipeIngredient: 2 sticks (8 ounces) unsalted butter, at room temperature
1/4 cup jam, Nutella, peanut butter, or chocolate ganache

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven rack to upper middle position and preheat oven to 350°F (175°C). Butter an 8-inch springform pan. In a small bowl, whisk together flour and salt; set aside. In the bowl of a food processor, process butter until light and fluffy, about 3 minutes. Add sugar and pulse for 1 minute. Add flour mixture and pulse just until dough comes together.

Divide dough into two equal portions. Press one half of dough into bottom of prepared pan until even. Spread with filling of choice, leaving 1/3-inch border at edge of pan. On a lightly floured surface, roll second half of dough out into 8-inch circle. Transfer to pan and place on top of filling. Gently press down on edge of dough to seal. Bake until golden, about 45 minutes.
Let cookies rest in pan for 15 minutes, then transfer to a cooling rack. When cool, cut into wedges or squares.

headline: Quick Gluten-Free Chocolate Cake Recipe
description: This cake is best served right from the pan. If you'd prefer to remove it from the pan for serving, place a "foil sling" in the pan before baking. To do this, place one piece of foil in the pan,...
name: Quick Gluten-Free Chocolate Cake Recipe

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Spray an 8-inch square baking pan with non-stick cooking spray.

In small bowl, whisk together cocoa powder and boiling water until smooth. Allow to cool. In large bowl, whisk together granulated sugar, white rice flour, sweet rice flour, potato starch, baking powder, baking soda, and salt.

Combine canola oil, egg, and cooled cocoa mixture. Whisk until smooth. Pour over dry ingredients. Whisk until a thick batter forms, taking care to get to the bottom of the bowl to ensure all ingredients are thoroughly combined. Spread batter evenly into prepared pan.

Bake until cake tester inserted into the middle of the cake comes out with a few moist crumbs attached, about 30 minutes. Allow cake to cool in the pan. Ice as desired. Store cake, covered, on the counter for up to three days.

review.reviewBody:
@grumblekitty--Great suggestion. Are you looking for a vanilla or chocolate cake? 

@BostonKate--I hope you enjoy this cake! It has a dense crumb. So I think it would be great with peanut butter icing! Let me know how it goes!

I have high hopes for this recipe, so far most of my chocolate cup/cakes have been flops. Not "don't serve to company" flops, like take a few bites and toss in the garbage flops. I have been desperate to find a gluten free way to do black bottom cupcakes and chocolate sheet cake with peanut butter icing. Here's to eternal choco-optimisim.

It would be awesome if you could invent an egg-free, gluten-free cake that would rise. I do great with cupcakes, but I can't get a real cake to be any better than a hockey puck. My son wanted a pirate ship for his birthday a couple of years ago, and I did it, but boy was it dense. =)

headline: Improved Mendota Recipe
description: Think of this beer cocktail as a variation on the mimosa, but full of fresh and tangy flavor from grapefruit juice and hoppy IPA.
name: Improved Mendota Recipe
keywords: beer, brunch, cocktail, drink
recipeIngredient: 12 ounces chilled IPA or Double IPA (such as Ninkasi Tricerahops)
3 ounces (6 tablespoons) freshly squeezed juice from 1 to 2 grapefruits

recipeInstructions.text: Pour IPA into serving glass. Add grapefruit juice and stir very gently. Serve immediately, garnished with a grapefruit twist.

headline: Curry Paste with Peruvian Flair: Red Curry and Pink Peppercorn Meat Sauce Recipe
description: Learn more about pink peppercorns here » During the summer my thoughts turn to spicy fare. It makes you sweat, in a good way, and if you can't beat the heat, you may as well fight it on its own...
name: Curry Paste with Peruvian Flair: Red Curry and Pink Peppercorn Meat Sauce Recipe
keywords: curry, noodles, pink peppercorns, rice, sauces, Spice Hunting, spices
recipeIngredient: 1 pound ground beef, pork, or bison, lean but not devoid of fat
1 tablespoon of coriander, toasted and ground
1 tablespoon of pink peppercorns, toasted and ground
Up to 1 tablespoon of sugar, to taste
1 1/2 teaspoons of cornstarch dissolved in two teaspoons of water

recipeInstructions.text: Heat a large skillet on high heat for several minutes until water sizzles off instantly. Add your meat of choice and brown it well, salting aggressively. When the meat is browned and a little crispy, remove it with a slotted spoon to a plate lined with paper towels.

Drain off all but a thin film of the fat and add the curry paste. Stir it constantly until it has slightly darkened in color and is intensely aromatic. Add the ground coriander and pink peppercorns and stir to incorporate for about 15 seconds.

Add the coconut milk, soy sauce, and rice wine, scraping the bottom of the skillet to remove any browned bits. Stir to combine and let it all come to a boil, then reduce it to a simmer for about half an hour, or until the sauce has thickened, the flavors have melded, and the meat is tender.
Raise the heat to high and pour in the cornstarch mixture to let the sauce thicken, stirring, for about a minute. Taste for salt and sugar, then add the lime juice off the heat.

Add a good-sized ladle of sauce to a bowl of noodles, rice, or rice cakes, and garnish with some cilantro. This Recipe Appears In 
 Spice Hunting: Pink Peppercorns

headline: Reveillon Cocktail Recipe
description: During the holidays even the most reluctant cooks take their shot in the kitchen. It's much the same with drinks. Those who would ordinarily get no more creative than opening a beer find themselves caught with the idea of mixing a fancy seasonal drink.
name: Reveillon Cocktail Recipe
keywords: allspice dram, brandy, cocktails, holiday cocktails, holiday recipes, Serious Cocktails, vermouth, winter drinks
recipeIngredient: 1/2 ounce pear brandy (the clear, unsweetened eau de vie - Clear Creek has a good one)
1/4 ounce good-quality sweet vermouth (Carpano Antica or Punt e Mes, or use Dubonnet)

recipeInstructions.text:
Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and fill with ice. Stir well for 30 seconds and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Garnish with a cinnamon stick or a piece of star anise. This Recipe Appears In 
 10 New Year's Eve Cocktails

review.reviewBody:
It's a favorite here as well. I use Mr. Taggart's Pimento Dram recipe which also makes a great gift in itself as my family has come to call it "Christmas in a Glass".

Merry Chirstmas Paul!

Rich

@plazmorb Yes indeed. It is summer here and I have just pureed some apricots and plums. In the warm weather cocktails are too much so sparkling wine is the drink of choice. A cube of apricot puree in the bottom of the glass is way too awesome to pass up. I stewed the apricots with amaretto and vanilla. So excited!
It sounds like it would be good, but I would have to spend over a $100 to have a cocktail :)

headline: Toronto Cocktail
description: The Toronto Cocktail pairs the Italian bitter with the crispness of rye whiskey and a little sugar.
name: Toronto Cocktail
keywords: amaro, cocktails, drinks, fernet, fernet branca, rye, Toronto Cocktail, whiskey

recipeInstructions.text: Combine rye, Fernet, simple syrup, and bitters in a mixing glass and fill with cracked ice. Stir for 20 seconds and strain into chilled cocktail glass. Squeeze a piece of orange peel over the drink and use as garnish.

review.reviewBody:
The guys at Golden Monkey here in Melbourne made one of these for me, just so I could try something different than my usual Old Fashioned.

What a winner! You can't drink many of them, but done well it's an exceptional drink.

One note, the guys at GM substitute maple syrup for sugar syrup. :-)

It's odd to see this described as being akin to an Americano when it's basically an Old Fashioned with a splash of Fernet. I'm drinking one right now and I can safely say, it tastes like an Old Fashioned with the slightest hint of Fernet on the finish, most noticeably via the ashy bitterness and menthol notes so familiar to those of us who have learned to like Fernet Branca. That said, it's basically an Old Fashioned.

I've been mixing equal parts fernet, rye, 1/2 part Cointreau, rocks, at home for some time. Didn't realize I was kind of making a Toronto. More fernet as opposed to Ango bitters, with Cointreau bringing the orangey/ sweet note. Interested to try this recipe.
Oh my goodness! We just made this and LOVE it! Thanks! It's in our recipe box now!
This is goodness. Are either of you involved with Oddfellows, on 10th? They have the Toronto on their cocktail menu. Tasty...

headline: Tonkatsu Sauce (Japanese-Style Barbecue Sauce)
description: This tonkatsu sauce is easy to throw together and perfect for serving with golden, crispy panko-crusted cutlets.
name: Tonkatsu Sauce (Japanese-Style Barbecue Sauce)
keywords: tonkatsu sauce, tonkatsu sauce recipe, sauce tonkatsu recipe

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, stir together ketchup, Worcestershire, soy sauce, mirin, sugar, mustard, and garlic powder. Use immediately or store in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to a month.

review.reviewBody:
This recipe was updated in June of 2023 and it now has a mismatched ratio... double the worcestershire sauce, triple the soy sauce and double the mustard... The old recipe was correct and this new one is definitely wrong and taste is poor

The old recipe listed here:
1/3 cup ketchup
2 Tbsp Worcestershire sauce
1 Tbsp soy sauce
1 Tbsp mirin
1 Tbsp sugar
1 tsp Dijon mustard
1/4 tsp garlic powder

Again I am not sure why the recipe was updated but it is now incorrect.
I'd never had authentic Tonkatsu before, so nothing to compare this with, but we thought it was very tasty on some panko fried chicken cutlets. Would like to try it on shrimp or fish as well.
Adding a dash of rice vinegar helps a lot
Too ketchupy
Tried it with no sugar and with a tablespoon of sugar, I liked it more without. Would reccomend tasting and adding sugar to taste! Otherwise quite tasty!

headline: Tonkatsu (Japanese Breaded Pork Cutlets)
description: Crispy, golden-brown, and juicy breaded and fried pork cutlets, Japanese-style.
name: Tonkatsu (Japanese Breaded Pork Cutlets)
keywords: cutlet, easy, katsu, pork, quick
recipeIngredient: 2 boneless, skinless chicken breast halves, about 8 ounces (225g) each; or 4 boneless, skinless chicken thighs, 4 to 5 ounces (110 to 140g) each; or 4 boneless pork sirloin cutlets, 4 to 5 ounces (110 to 140g) each
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 1/2 cups Japanese-style panko bread crumbs (about 5 ounces; 140g)
Vegetable, canola, or peanut oil, for frying

recipeInstructions.text: Place cutlets, one at a time, in a heavy-duty zipper-lock bag and pound gently to 1/4-inch thickness using a meat pounder or the bottom of a heavy 8-inch skillet. Season generously with salt and pepper.

If using slices of fresh Japanese milk bread: Using a sharp or serrated knife, trim crust from milk bread; discard trimmings. Cut trimmed bread lengthwise into 1 1/2-inch-thick batons. Using a food processor fitted with the grater attachment, process bread into coarse flakes.

Fill 3 wide, shallow bowls or high-rimmed plates with flour, beaten eggs, and panko, respectively. Working with one cutlet at a time, dredge in flour with your first hand, shaking off excess. Transfer to egg dish, then turn cutlet with your second hand to coat both sides. Lift and allow excess egg to drain off, then transfer to breadcrumb mixture. With your first hand, scoop breadcrumbs on top of cutlet, then gently press, turning to ensure a good layer of crumbs on both sides. Transfer cutlet to a clean plate and repeat with remaining meat. If this is done properly, your first hand should touch only dry ingredients, while your second hand should touch only wet, making the process less messy.

Fill a large cast iron or stainless steel skillet with 1/3 inch oil. (To speed things up even more, use 2 skillets simultaneously.) Heat over high heat until shimmering and just shy of smoking, about 350°F (175°C) on an instant-read thermometer.

Using tongs or your fingers, gently lower cutlets into hot fat, laying them down away from you to prevent hot fat from splashing toward you. (Work in batches if necessary.) Fry, gently swirling pan and rotating cutlets for even browning, and adjusting heat as necessary for a steady, vigorous bubble (around 300 to 325°F; 150 to 160°C), until bottom side is set, about 1 1/2 minutes. Flip cutlets and fry until other side is set, about 1 1/2 minutes longer. Continue cooking, swirling frequently and flipping occasionally, until well browned on both sides, about 3 minutes longer. Transfer to paper towels to drain and season with salt right away. Repeat with remaining cutlets.
Slice tonkatsu into thin strips and serve immediately with shredded cabbage, lemon wedges, white rice, Japanese pickles (if desired), and tonkatsu sauce.

review.reviewBody:
@J. Kenji López-Alt

While it's not as lean as chicken breast, you don't explain why the same reasoning for brining chicken breasts doesn't also apply to pork cutlets?

Don't forget the Kewpie for the shredded cabbage!

Variation: get rice, put cabbage on top, add Kewpie. Boom. Nama-kyabetsu donburi!

Great, simple recipe. Although just plain cabbage is good, I felt like something a little more salad-y so dressed the cabbage in lemon juice, a little mirin, and some sesame oil, then sprinkled a little togarashi on top. Delicious!
I like Katsu a lot, but you know what I love more? Kastu-don. There is something about the cutlet over rice with the sweet light sauce, onion, and egg that is just the perfect food to me.
Katsu Sando! Pork Katsu with Bull Dog Katsu Sauce on plain, white sandwich bread.

headline: Summer Tomato Tonnato Salad
description: Italian tonnato (creamy blended tuna) sauce makes a nicely creamy accompaniment to peak summer tomatoes in this simple no-cook salad.
name: Summer Tomato Tonnato Salad
keywords: tuna
recipeIngredient: 1/4 cup (60ml) fresh lemon juice (from 2 whole lemons), divided
4 ounces (113g) oil-packed tuna, such as Ortiz, drained
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
Toasted black sesame seeds and coarse sea salt, for serving (optional)
15 to 20 fresh basil leaves, large leaves torn and small leaves left whole

recipeInstructions.text: For the Tonnato: Place egg, 2 tablespoons (30ml) lemon juice, anchovies, mustard, and capers in the bottom of an immersion blender cup or another tall-sided container that just fits the head of your immersion blender. Pour vegetable oil on top and allow to settle for 15 seconds. Place head of immersion blender at bottom of cup and turn it on high speed. Do not pulse or move the head. As mayonnaise forms, slowly tilt and lift the head of the immersion blender until all oil is emulsified; this should take between 30 and 45 seconds.

Turn off blender and remove from blender cup. Scrape down sides of cup using a rubber spatula, then add tuna and remaining 2 tablespoons (30ml) lemon juice. Return blender head to blender cup and blend just until tuna is thoroughly incorporated into a smooth sauce, 15 to 30 seconds. Avoid over-blending, as this can cause the sauce to become grainy.
Transfer sauce to a medium mixing bowl and slowly drizzle in olive oil while whisking constantly to emulsify. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Refrigerate sauce until ready to serve (see note).
For the Salad: Using a sharp chef's knife or serrated knife , cut tomatoes into an assortment of slices, wedges, and bite-size pieces.

Using a large spoon, spread tonnato in an even layer on a large serving plate or individual serving plates. Arrange tomatoes on top of tonnato, then dollop with small spoonfuls of Calabrian chiles. Sprinkle sesame seeds and sea salt (if using) over tomatoes, followed by basil leaves. If not using sea salt, season tomatoes with kosher salt. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody:
This is the perfect dish to hedonistically eat a zillion tomatoes from the farmer's market before the end of the world (aka winter produce selection).

The whole process took me about 15 minutes, including time to wash the immersion blender. Don't skimp on the quality tuna.

Can you make this without tuna? I want to make this for staff food at the Italian restaurant I work at and they have every ingredient listed except for tuna! Would be great to impress my co-workers with, especially as I am the commis-chef. Xx

I followed the recipe and the tonnato was too thin for my liking. I've made Josh McFadden's tonnato recipe from his book Six Seasons and it is a lot thicker, and would have made the dish a lot more enjoyable. My "mayonnaise" did not form at all like it does when I make Kenji's mayo recipe, I kept double checking the recipe here to see if I messed up. Not sure what happened but the thinness of the tonnato sort of messed the dish up for me.

For me the ratios were off, too much dressing for 2lbs of tomatoes. I used only half of the dressing and it was still more like tonnato soup. If I were to make this again (and I would probably use a different recipe to be honest) I would cut out the extra 1/2 of olive oil added at the end, and instead of putting the dressing on the plate first (it was too late once i realized it was way too much) I would drizzle it over the tomatoes to better control the amount.

headline: Tomato-Mint Sauce Recipe
description: In essence, this is a simple marinara with the addition of mint, but that one minor change makes a big difference.
name: Tomato-Mint Sauce Recipe
keywords: mint, quick, sauced, sauces, tomato
recipeIngredient: 2 teaspoons freshly minced garlic (about 2 medium cloves)
1/3 cup finely chopped fresh mint leaves
1/4 cup finely chopped fresh basil leaves
2 tablespoons freshly squeezed lemon juice from 1 lemon
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a medium saucepan over medium heat until shimmering. Add shallots and cook until softened, about 5 minutes. Stir in garlic and crushed red pepper and cook until fragrant, about 30 seconds.
Stir in tomatoes and bring to a boil. Reduce to low and simmer until sauce has slightly thickened, 15 to 20 minutes. Remove from heat.

Stir in mint, basil, and lemon juice. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Use immediately or transfer to an airtight container and store in refrigerator for up to a week. This Recipe Appears In 
 Sauced: Tomato-Mint Sauce

review.reviewBody: Can you freeze this?
Can you freeze this?

headline: Raspberry Dark Chocolate Macaroons Recipe
description: These fruit forward raspberry macaroons get a contrasting drizzle of dark chocolate. They make a great DIY gift on Valentine's Day.
name: Raspberry Dark Chocolate Macaroons Recipe
keywords: chocolate, Cookies, macaroons, Valentine's Day

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven racks to middle and upper positions and preheat oven to 325°F. Line two baking sheets with parchment paper.

In the bowl of a food processor combine coconut, sugar, salt, vanilla, egg whites, and almonds. Pulse to combine, about 8 short pulses. Add raspberries and pulse until evenly distributed, about another 8 pulses. Use a medium size cookie scoop (2 3/4-inch diameter, 1 1/2 Tbsp) to scoop dough and drop it onto the prepared baking sheet in rounded balls. Bake cookies until golden in color and dry to the touch, 30-35 minutes.
Let cookies cool for 5 minutes then transfer to a wire rack to cool completely. Melt chocolate in a double boiler or in the microwave. Drizzle chocolate over cookies and let stand until hardened.

review.reviewBody: Just made these. Holy cow were they good! I used frozen raspberries and I was a little worried but...I think they worked perfectly (can't say better since I haven't tried them with fresh.) The frozen raspberries stayed intact while mixing so mine came out with actual chunks of raspberries. (This of course only works with whole frozen ones, not the kind in syrup.) Also, these are easy to mix with just a bowl and rubber spatula so no need to worry if you don't have a food processor!

I will definately make these but not for V Day. I LOVE LOVE LOVE chocolate but Valentines Day may be the only day of the year I hate it. There is simply too much chocolate and too many heart candies one man can take. So my reply is lemons, lemons, lemons. What does Adam and Eve have to do with it? Find out at: Marc's Culinary Compass!
Any way to make these without the food processor? I'm without a blender at the moment as well...

I've gotta make these!! I just love chocolate and raspberries. Lets see, makes 2 dozen, and the guy doesn't like raspberries. 

ALL FOR ME!!!!!

headline: Tomato Jam
description: Tomatoes are perfect candidates for end-of-the-summer jam and this jam is absolutely delicious on a BLT, a grilled cheddar cheese sandwich, on burgers, or as an accompaniment to fish.
name: Tomato Jam
keywords: Jam, Preserved, tomato
recipeIngredient: 3 pounds best quality tomatoes, cored and chopped

recipeInstructions.text: If you are going to preserve jam, prepare jars and lids: place 3 half-pint jars on a rack in a large pot. Add enough water to cover jars, and bring to a boil over high heat. Boil for 10 minutes, then turn off heat and allow jars to rest in hot water. Meanwhile, put bands and lids in a small saucepan and cover with water. Heat over medium heat until water is simmering, then remove pan from heat and allow bands and lids to rest in hot water until ready to use.

Combine tomatoes, sugar, lemon juice, ginger, red pepper flakes, salt, cinnamon, and cumin in a large, heavy-bottomed pot and bring to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring frequently. Reduce heat and simmer until mixture reaches a thick, jam-like consistency, about 2 1/2 hours. Stir in pectin (if using) and simmer for 1 minute more.

Ladle hot jam into hot sterilized jars, leaving 1/4-inch headspace. Wipe rims of jars, cover with lids, and screw bands on until just barely tight. Place jars on rack in pot and cover completely with water. Cover pot and bring to a boil over high heat. Boil for 15 minutes. Turn off heat, uncover pot, and allow jars to rest in water for 5 minutes. Remove jars from pot and allow them to rest undisturbed on countertop for 6 hours or overnight.

review.reviewBody:
I made a batch of this recently...very good by the way.
I did not use pectin. How long should it last in the fridge?
Thanks
can we get this recipe in grams please

I made this with the Early Girls of which I had too many. Between the ginger and red pepper flakes it was a little too spicy. Perhaps halving each? But can't wait to try it with a substantial farm house cheddar. Didn't use pectin but I never do because the softer set is fine with me.
This is SO GOOD! I used 2 of my massive Hillbilly heirlooms for this and the taste is incredible!

I made this recipe, without the pectin, a week ago. It turned out great. I used it as a condiment for a family BBQ.
How long will this keep in the fridge after making it?
Thanks

headline: Tangy and Sweet Tomato-Bacon Jam With Onions and Garlic Recipe
description: This savory jam is loaded with onions and tomatoes that have been cooked in bacon fat until thick and spreadable. A touch of maple syrup, brown sugar, balsamic vinegar, and Dijon mustard gives it a sweet-tart edge that would be as good on a burger as it would served alongside a wedge of cheese.
name: Tangy and Sweet Tomato-Bacon Jam With Onions and Garlic Recipe
keywords: Jam, tomato

recipeInstructions.text: Cook bacon in a heavy-bottomed saucepan over medium heat until browned, about 5 minutes. Add onions and garlic and cook, stirring, until translucent and softened, 5 to 7 minutes. Drain excess bacon grease from pan.
Stir in remaining ingredients and reduce heat to low. Simmer uncovered, stirring occasionally, until reduced and thickened to a jam-like consistency, about 1 hour. Discard bay leaf.
Transfer to a blender and pulse to combine, leaving some chunks. Use immediately, or store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

review.reviewBody:
I have made this three times and it has always been great.
Two comments about this recipe.
1. It takes me much more time to slowly reduce it down the the right thickness. No problem, just allow more time.
2. It keeps a long time in the refrigerator. Over 6 months. Like any good jam, it is preserved. When cold, bits of bacon will look white.
3. When thick, depending on your blender, optionally, just put some of it in the blender to leave the remainder out for the "chunks".

Has anyone tried this without the bacon? I realize that's sort of an absurd question, but I'd like to make it for a party and we have a couple of vegetarians attending... I don't want anyone to accidentally eat bacon.

Just made this for a massive smorgasbord I have planned this weekend and it is SERIOUSLY GOOD! I can't wait to pair it with cheese and crackers. I just have to stop myself from "taste testing" it until then!

Comment for Hungry for the Next Meal: First of all, you don't need a pressure cooker (or a hot water bath) for jams, jellies, preserves, and marmelades. The high sugar content means that you're not at risk for botulism. Sterilize your jars and flat lids for canning, fill the just-drained jars w/hot jam, wipe the rim, add the flat lid & ring, tighten reasonably, and invert on a towel for 10-15 minutes. The turn the jars right-side up and let cool to room temperature. The heat from the jam will melt the lid seal enough to work and you can test the seal on the room temperature jars by pressing on the lid. If they haven't sealed, the jam is still fine, just needs to be refrigerated. The towel is in case a jar hasn't sealed and leaks all over the counter. Likewise, because of the acidity, you can get by w/a water bath treatment for things like pickles and chutneys. Once you start dealing with a low-acidity fruit like tomatoes, and particularly tomatoes combined with other veggies, botulism is a very real risk. I'm guessing that if you looked up the recommeded pressure & timing in a Ball canning book for a tomato mixture, you could use that as a guideline. Otherwise, you should check with your county's farm advisor or a find the equivalent on the state level. And what do you mean you're not using your pressure canner? Haven't you been reading Kenji's recipes for using a pressure cooker? And yes, I know the comments I made on his recipe for the corn soup should have been for a corn cob and not a corn husk.

Yum! Almost a BBQ sauce flavor I wasn't expecting, but SOOO good. Left out the brown sugar for a more tangy sauce, and didn't bother with the blender as I was worried my vitamin might over process. Topping for burgers tomorrow's dinner for sure!

headline: Cantonese-Style Tofu, Pine Nut, and Jicama Lettuce Cups (San Choi Bao) Recipe
description: The inspiration for this recipe comes from the san choi bao I grew up eating in New York's Chinatown, which were filled with minced squab stir-fried with pine nuts and finely diced water chestnuts and vegetables. The mix of crunchy, crisp, and tender bits works just as well with a new set of vegetable-based ingredients.
name: Cantonese-Style Tofu, Pine Nut, and Jicama Lettuce Cups (San Choi Bao) Recipe
keywords: lettuce, mushroom, shiitake, tofu
recipeIngredient: 1 tablespoon (15ml) Shaoxing wine or dry sherry
2 teaspoons (10ml) Chinese black vinegar or cider vinegar
4 tablespoons (60ml) hoisin sauce, plus more for serving
2 teaspoons (10ml) chili sauce, such as Sriracha or sambal oelek (optional)
2 1/2 ounces shiitake mushrooms, stems removed, cut into 1/4-inch dice (70g; about 1 cup diced)
3 scallions, white and pale green parts only, thinly sliced
4 ounces jicama, peeled and cut into 1/4-inch dice (about 1/2 of an apple-sized jicama; 120g) (see note)
2 ounces celery, cut into 1/4-inch dice (about 1 large stalk; 60g)
1 head iceberg or green leaf lettuce, picked into individual leaves, stored in ice water until ready to use

recipeInstructions.text: Cut tofu into 1/4-inch slabs. Press firmly between paper towels to remove excess moisture, then cut into 1/4-inch dice. Set aside.
Combine Shaoxing wine, soy sauce, vinegar, hoisin sauce, chili sauce (if using), cornstarch, and 1 tablespoon (15ml) water in a small bowl and mix with a fork until homogeneous. Set aside.
Combine pine nuts and 1 tablespoon (15ml) oil in a wok and place over medium heat. Cook, stirring frequently, until nuts are well toasted, about 5 minutes. Transfer to a large bowl and set aside.

Add 1 tablespoon oil to wok and heat over high heat until lightly smoking. Add tofu and cook, stirring occasionally, until tofu is well browned all over, 6 to 8 minutes. Transfer to bowl with pine nuts.

Add 1 tablespoon oil to wok and heat over high heat until lightly smoking. Add shiitakes and cook, stirring occasionally, until well browned all over, about 3 minutes. Transfer to bowl with tofu and pine nuts.

Heat remaining tablespoon oil in wok over high heat until lightly smoking. Add scallions, garlic, and ginger and cook, stirring and tossing constantly, until fragrant, about 15 seconds. Add jicama and celery and toss to combine. Return tofu, mushrooms, and pine nuts to wok and toss to combine. Stir sauce with a fork to reintegrate any cornstarch that may have settled to the bottom, then add to wok. Cook, tossing and stirring constantly, until all vegetables are evenly coated in sauce. Stir in cilantro (reserve a little for garnish) and season to taste with salt and white pepper. Transfer to a warm serving platter and sprinkle with reserved cilantro.
Serve immediately. To eat, spread a little hoisin sauce on the bottom of a lettuce leaf and spoon the filling into the lettuce. Eat with your hands.

review.reviewBody: I love this and have been making it for years. I just looked at it again this morning because it is also a great dish for these hot summer days. I prepare in the morning while it is still cool and either reheat or serve cold at dinner. It is great for picnics too. Today I added some leftover roasted red pepper and rice I had in the fridge.

You need to try this asap. That's it. So easy to make but the layers of flavor felt novel and exciting. You would need to shop for ingredients a bit if you don't have chinese cooking often, the jicama was nowhere to be found near me unfortunately...The result would be good as a meal prep block for the week if it lasted that long.

This recipe is so damned good. I am fortunate to have a shop near me where I can buy fresh tofu, which really elevates the dish. This only served 2 of us; we just could not stop eating! Served with brown rice and butter lettuce (*I live with an iceberg lettuce hater*). It's the sort of dish you can serve to people who think they won't like tofu, and they'll find themselves eating every last bite and then pouting when there's not enough for thirds. The jicama is brilliant. The pine nuts and cilantro seemed odd to me in the recipe, but they worked so well in this dish. I just finished eating and am already plotting on when I can get this into the rotation again.
Fabulous! Only served 2.5 people as it was so delicious. Tofu took a bit longer to crisp up, pine nuts less time to brown. Only substitution was gluten free hoisin. Thanks Kenji!

Made this tonight and despite some limitations due to no wok & no jicama, this was very good. I subbed water chestnuts and it was still so good. We included a spoonful of rice into our lettuce cups to make it a meal. I squirted sriracha into my servings so the kids could eat it as well. It was a huge hit! Can't wait to try more of these vegan recipes on this site! So happy to have this resource!

headline: Absinthe Frappe Recipe
description: Now that new bottlings of absinthe are all over, and it's high time to rediscover this pleasant drink. There are several ways of mixing an Absinthe Frappe. Here are two versions that are both very refreshing, and are sure to enliven a summer late afternoon.
name: Absinthe Frappe Recipe
keywords: absinthe, anisette

recipeInstructions.text: Add ingredients to a cocktail shaker and stir until sugar is dissolved (or you can make life easier by just using simple syrup). Fill shaker with ice and shake well for 10 seconds; strain into a chilled highball glass and top with two ounces of chilled soda water (or more, to taste).

For a longer, colder drink, fill the chilled highball glass with crushed ice, and strain the drink over ice before adding the soda water. You may wish to add less soda to this version, as the ice will provide additional dilution.

review.reviewBody:
Oy, soda water is entirely optional here! Frappe "my way" is now essentially the only way I drink absinthe of any kind (St. George Verte is my current favorite):

Pack a small rocks glass with crushed (critical) ice
Add dash of rich simple syrup over ice (if you like)
Pour absinthe in the measure of your choice (typically 1-2 ounces)
Stir if the spirit moves you, or not (don't blink, it louches quickly either way!)

Sip slowly and enjoy as the absinthe evolves from hot, sharp, nearly-neat and barely-sweetened to ice cold, mellow, smoothed out and luxuriously rich.

headline: Khao Khua (Thai Toasted-Rice Powder) Recipe
description: Slow and steady is the best way to coax deep, nutty flavors out of toasted-rice powder.
name: Khao Khua (Thai Toasted-Rice Powder) Recipe
keywords: lao, Laos, rice, rice powder, sticky rice
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup Thai sticky rice (3 1/2 ounces; 100g); see note

recipeInstructions.text: Place rice in a 12-inch stainless steel skillet and shake pan to distribute grains into an even layer. Cook over medium heat, shaking skillet frequently to redistribute rice into an even layer, until rice is lightly golden, about 10 minutes. If rice begins to scorch, lower heat to medium-low.

Continue to cook, shaking skillet frequently, until rice is deep golden brown, 15 to 20 minutes longer. Remove from heat, transfer rice to a rimmed baking sheet, and let cool to room temperature, 5 to 8 minutes.

Transfer toasted rice to a spice grinder or the bowl of a mortar and pestle. Grind to a coarse powder with a texture similar to that of ground coffee used for pourover brewing. Allow rice powder to cool to room temperature, then store in a dry, airtight container.

review.reviewBody: I know CooksIllustrated says you can use non-glutinous rice such as Thai Jasmine. Just curious what the difference is that you determined in your testing as you declare that it will not work so is not an acceptable substitute.
Can convection be used to more evenly crisp the skin? If so, then at what temp?
This is really cool. I like to cool it!
This is really cool. I like where you're going... first with the shallots and now the rice powder. I'm assuming some delicious Thai and Laotian recipes are coming soon, and I can't wait!

headline: Lao Hu Cai (Tiger Salad), à la Xi'an Famous Foods
description: Savory, refreshing, and tart, this dish is inspired by the lao hu cai, or "tiger vegetable salad," served at Xi'an Famous Foods.
name: Lao Hu Cai (Tiger Salad), à la Xi'an Famous Foods
keywords: celery, cilantro, easy, northern chinese, quick, salad, shrimp, tiger salad
recipeIngredient: 3 celery ribs (5 ounces; 140g), preferably cut from closer to the heart, peeled of tough fibers and cut into quite thick matchstick lengths
1/2 long hot green pepper (1/2 ounce; 14g), split in half, each half then cut on a bias (see note)
2 scallions, sliced thinly on a bias (2 ounces; 56g)
1 small bunch cilantro leaves and tender stems, torn by hand or chopped into 3-inch lengths (1 ounce; 28g)
3/4 teaspoon Diamond Crystal kosher salt; if using table salt, use half as much by volume
2 tablespoons tiny dried shrimp (0.2 ounce; 6g); see note

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium mixing bowl, combine celery, long hot green pepper, scallions, and chopped cilantro.
In a small bowl, combine rice vinegar, salt, and sugar, then stir to dissolve the salt and sugar completely. Add soy sauce and sesame oil and stir to combine.
Pour dressing over vegetables, tossing to ensure thorough distribution.
Mound vegetables on a serving plate and sprinkle dried shrimp all over the top. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: Allergy to shrimp... trying to think of a sub for that, small, salty pops?
Even when Xi'an had this on their menu, it was vegetarian, ergo your recipe shouldn't include "à la Xi'an Famous Foods" in its title. Both misleading and inaccurate.
I loved the dressing and everything avout the salad was fantastic. Next time i'll.ditch the tomatoesq
I do not eat shrimp or any shellfish. Can I sub in anchovies? Thanks.

There are the fancy dried shrimp - very light & crispy, often from Japan - & the cheap ones - a bit soft & almost mushy. The first kind are good sprinkled as garnish, but I've only used the other kind by soaking and grinding them first, and toasting them in a dry pan. Is this normal? What do I need to know about dried shrimp?

headline: Thomas Keller's One-Pot Roast Chicken Recipe | Cook the Book
description: Roasting a chicken is one of the most indispensable skills that a cook can hone, and no one has been championing the simple joys of a roast chicken more than Thomas Keller. So it's not surprising Keller chose to contribute a recipe for One-Pot Roast Chicken to In The Green Kitchen by Alice Waters, a collection of essential skills for home cooks.
name: Thomas Keller's One-Pot Roast Chicken Recipe | Cook the Book
keywords: Alice Waters, chicken, Cook the Book, In The Green Kitchen, one-pot meals, poultry, Thomas Keller
recipeIngredient: Fennel, squash, turnips, parsnips, or other vegetables (optional)

recipeInstructions.text: First prepare the chicken. To remove the wishbone at the top of the breast, use a small knife to scrape along the bone to expose it, then insert the knife and run it along the bone, separating it from the flesh. Use your fingers to loosen it further, grasp the tip of the wishbone, and pull it out. Tuck the wing tips back and under the neck.

Tying the chicken plumps the breast up and brings the legs into position for even roasting. Cut a length of cotton string. With the chicken on its back, slip the string under the tail and bring the ends up over the legs to form a figure eight. Loop over the end of each leg and draw the strings tight to bring the legs together. Draw the string back under the legs and wings on either side of the neck. Pull tight, wrap one end around the neck, and tie off the two ends. Salt the chicken evenly all around. Coarse salt has a good texture of large grains that makes it easy to calibrate how much salt you are putting on the chicken; sprinkle it from up high, so that it falls like snow. Season liberally with fresh-ground pepper.

Preheat the oven to 375°F, put all the vegetables and herbs together in the bottom of a large, heavy ovenproof pot, and season with salt and pepper. Set the chicken on top, dot with the butter, and roast uncovered for 45 to 60 minutes (or longer), depending on the size of the chicken. It is done when the leg joint is pierced with a knife and the juices run clear, not pink.
Let the chicken rest for a few minutes before carving, and serve family-style with all of the caramelized vegetables and juices from the pot on a platter and the chicken pieces on top.

review.reviewBody: I used small round golden Yukon potatoes, which were fabulous. The chicken I had was closer to 4 lbs, and the roasting took at least 1 1/2 hours before the juices ran clear. But, oh so good.
I thought this roast chicken tasted a little boring. I'm going to stick with my mom's lemon pepper and citrus roasted chicken. The vegetables however were very tasty.
Mmmmm....Looks tasty! Here's my Mom's recipe for chicken strips: [URL removed by moderator per Serious Eats's self-linking policy]

This is the one Keller recipe I don't agree with, and it probably has something to do with his own nostalgia as a child - I remember reading that he loved his Mom's simple roast chicken.

A three pound bird takes 35-45 minutes at 375-425 F. Prepare the bird as he states, but season the cavity heavily with salt, add some black pepper and stuff it with a lemon half, a split garlic head, thyme and rosemary. Sprinkle the outside with salt and pepper and pan sear the leg, breast and other leg in a 10-inch diameter saute pan. 

When it's equally golden brown, remove it from the heat but keep it in the saute pan, flip on it's back and rub evenly with unsalted butter (pommade consistency). Pop in the oven at 400 F for 10 minutes, then reduce to 375-380 F. Cook for 35-45 minutes, basting with the butter every 10 minutes. When done, let the juices assimilate for 5-10 minutes then portion.

The original version is my go-to Sunday night dinner. So easy; so delicious. Keller suggested serving it with mustard, something I had never considered before. Now, I make sure to check there's an ample supply of Dijon in the fridge before bird hits oven.

headline: Thin and Tender Flour Tortillas Recipe
description: Thin and semi-translucent thanks to plenty to lard, these flour tortillas are light and tender, with a mild yet delicious flavor. They're a perfect accompaniment to grilled and roasted meats and seafood like skirt steak, chicken, and shrimp, but we wouldn't be surprised if you also just ate a stack of them by themselves.
name: Thin and Tender Flour Tortillas Recipe
keywords: tex-mex, tortilla
recipeIngredient: 1/4 cup cold lard, preferably back lard (see note)

recipeInstructions.text: Place flour and salt in the workbowl of a food processor fitted with a steel blade and pulse to combine. Add lard and pulse until mixture resembles coarse crumbs. Add water and process until a cohesive dough forms.

Turn dough out onto a lightly floured work surface and knead until smooth, about 1 minute. Cover with a damp cloth or plastic wrap and let rest for 10 minutes. Divide dough into 10 equal pieces; roll each piece of dough into a ball. Cover dough with a damp cloth or plastic wrap and let rest an additional 15 minutes.

Heat cast iron skillet, griddle, or comal over medium-high heat. Meanwhile, place one ball of dough on a lightly floured work surface and pat down into a flat disc. Using a rolling pin, roll dough out to a very thin 8-inch round. Place dough in skillet and cook until bubbles form on top side and bottom side has light browned spots, 15-30 seconds. Flip tortilla and cook until second side develops light browned spots, 15-30 seconds longer. Transfer tortilla to a plate and cover with dish cloth. Repeat with remaining balls of dough. Serve immediately while still warm.

review.reviewBody: These came out incredibly subtle and delicious. I would like to add a hint to those who found the dough to come out too soft and sticky, or who needed to add more flour to make it workable: Add the second half of the water to the flour/lard mixture a couple of teaspoons at a time and then pulse for a few seconds in between. The mixture will appear to change very little as you add the water, but you will reach a point where suddenly the dough will start forming into a ball. At this point, do not add ANY more water! Adding even small amounts of water now will quickly turn your dough sticky and too soft. Adding flour to a too-wet dough is much more difficult than adding water to a too-dry dough. Just pulse the food processor a little longer until almost all of the dough sticks into a ball, and then move on to the kneading step.
I weigh my flour and lard and find that .5 cup of water makes a perfect, workable dough. I use 240g flour (half unbleached and half sprouted wheat) and 50g lard.

I used significantly less water than the 3/4 cup. I used ice water and mixed by hand. Lard set in freezer for a few minutes prior to use. This is so much easier than I thought it would be. Forgot to buy taco shells today and decided to try this. I have a farm source for leaf lard down the street. I have been experimenting with it recently, making pie crusts, biscuits and now these. I feel like the less preservatives and sugar I use is a win......everything at the store has sugar in it, EVERYTHING....its poison.
Instead of back lard I use bacon drippings.

I knew my dough was too soft but I decided to work with it through the stages. I used bacon fat instead of lard. I didn’t want to add TOO much flour because it would have a floury flavor. They came out fine.

But I made it work and they were delicious. Kudos to the recipe. I knew the dough was too soft because it didn’t make a ball, but I managed to get 12 tortillas out of what I whipped up.

So, don’t be afraid! Even if your dough is imperfect you will have delicious tortillas. The salt was very necessary in case anyone wants to omit it. It made a big difference in taste.

headline: Herb-Marinated Steak and Soft Scrambled Eggs Recipe
description: Herb-marinated steak makes a hearty brunch with eggs.
name: Herb-Marinated Steak and Soft Scrambled Eggs Recipe
keywords: brunch, egg, Sunday Brunch
recipeIngredient: 1 thai chili, finely chopped (or 1/2 teaspoon red pepper flakes)
Kosher salt and cracked black pepper
Kosher salt and cracked black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: For the Steak: In a large bowl, mix together oregano, thyme, tarragon, cilantro, parsley, garlic, chile, olive oil, and lime juice until all ingredients are evenly incorporated, then season to taste with salt and pepper. Or, combine all ingredients in a food processor and pulse until an even paste is formed.
Pour herb mixture over steak tips and mix until the steak is evenly coated. Using a fork, pierce each piece of steak on all over. Allow to sit for at least 1 hour, and up to overnight in the fridge.

When ready to cook, preheat your grill pan or grill to a high heat, then sear steaks until the center of the thickest piece of each steak is 135°F (57°C) for medium rare, let the steak tips rest while you cook your eggs.
For the Eggs: In a large non-stick skillet, melt the butter over medium low heat. When butter is melted add the eggs. Cook over medium low heat until eggs are softly cooked and custardy.
Slice the steak and divide between four plates. Divide the eggs between the plates as well and serve garnished with chopped chives and toast.

headline: Thick and Juicy Burgers Recipe
description: Note: Want to learn about the science behind big burgers? Check it out here....
name: Thick and Juicy Burgers Recipe
keywords: beef, burger, sandwiches, The Burger Lab
recipeIngredient: Kosher salt and freshly cracked black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Set oven rack to lower middle position and preheat oven to 200°F (95°C). Divide meat into four even 1/2-pound portions. Form into four 4-inch-wide patties, leaving slight depression in center of each. Season liberally with kosher salt and black pepper and place patties on wire rack set in rimmed baking sheet. Place in oven and cook until center of each patty registers 120°F (50°C) on an instant read thermometer for medium rare (110°F (44°C) for rare, 135 °F (57°C) and up for medium well to well), 15 to 30 minutes (time may vary depending on oven temperature cycling). Tent burgers loosely with foil.

Add vegetable oil to 12-inch heavy-bottomed stainless steel or cast iron skillet and heat over high heat until smoking. Add burger patties and cook until browned crust develops on first side, 45 seconds to 1 minute 15 seconds. Flip patties. Add cheese if desired. Cook until second side develops dark brown crust, additional 45 seconds to 1 minute 15 seconds. Transfer to buns, top as desired, and serve immediately. This Recipe Appears In 
 The Burger Lab: How Often Should You Flip a Burger?

review.reviewBody: I used a toaster oven @ 200F and it took a whole hour for the patties to reach 120F. Also, my whole house went up in smoke after putting the patties on the skillet. I don't think that was supposed to happen. I used avocado oil rather than vegetable.

These burgers are the best that I have ever made. But they are absolutely an every once in a while indulgence due to the fat content if you go 80/20 on your ground beef. So delicious and juicy though. I’m making them again tonight.
I imagine the "one flip" hamburger logic was something brought to us out of restaurants. It's a more efficient use of a grill cooks time to not be futzing with single patties over and over.
Fantastically easy, plus, super simple to set up for different levels of "cooked"! Left my husband's in the oven for an extra 5min!
amazing recipes thank you, I am so hungry right now! Any tips on how to make the perfect onion rings? I like those big wagon wheel ones.

headline: The Ultimate Sliders Recipe
description: There's more than meats the eye between these diminutive buns.
name: The Ultimate Sliders Recipe
keywords: beef, burger, sandwiches, sliders
recipeIngredient: 1 medium onion, peeled and grated on the medium holes of a box grater, juices and pulp reserved (about 1 1/2 cups)

recipeInstructions.text: Toss diced onion with 1 teaspoon kosher salt in a medium bowl. Set aside at room temperature until fragrant, about 10 minutes. Meanwhile, divide beef into 12 evenly sized balls. Using damp hands, press balls into even patties approximately 1/8-inch thick, and 3 1/2-inches wide. Place on a large plastic wrap-lined plate. Patties can be stacked with a layer of plastic wrap between each layer. Place in refrigerator until ready to cook.

Preheat a heavy-bottomed 12-inch skillet over medium-low heat until evenly heated, about 5 minutes. Reduce heat to low, and add half of diced onion, using spatula to spread into even layer across bottom of pan. Cook without moving until bottom of onions starts turning pale golden brown, about 5 minutes (onions should barely sizzle while cooking—adjust heat as necessary).

Add half of grated onions and their juice to skillet. Stir onions with rubber spatula to release browned bits from bottom of pan and spread into thin, even layer. Arrange 6 hamburger patties on top of onion mixture. Season top of patties with salt and pepper. Add 6 slices of American cheese if desired. Place bun bottoms, cut-side-down, on top of patties. Place bun tops, cut-side-down, on top of bun bottoms, staggering arrangement to maximize exposure to steam.

Continue cooking over low heat until burgers are cooked through and cheese is fully melted, about 3 minutes, adding extra onion juice if pan runs dry, making sure to reserve at least half for second batch (there should be no sizzling sound, and mixture should steam constantly—in some rare cases, substituting water may be necessary if onion juice all runs out). Remove from heat.

Lift bun with spatula. Pick up bun top, invert, and place underneath spatula (burger should now be fully assembled, upside down). Slide spatula out from between burger and bun top. Invert, and place on plate. Repeat with remaining 5 burgers. Spoon any remaining onions and melted cheese in skillet on top of each burger patty, along with 2 pickles, and condiments as desired. Consume immediately, before repeating with remaining 6 sliders.

review.reviewBody: This was another pandemic project for me and my teenage son. Unfortunately it was a little disappointing. We have a crappy electric stove and used a nicely seasoned 12" cast iron skillet to cook them. The cooking times and temps were way off for us. The first set of onions sat in there for over ten minutes without browning. Then the first batch of burgers took more than ten minutes as well. Eventually we just turned the heat up. The burgers were nice and moist and the kids said they were pretty good, but too oniony. Felt like too much fussing for the end product.

Phenomenal! I made a small test batch for myself before I make it for my family and they came out great. I deviated in a few ways. I used regular sized potato buns and wider diameter patties. I sliced the onions super thin instead of grating them and used some water to get more liquid. I let the patties cook for about 15 seconds on one side, pressed some diced onions on the raw side and flipped them. After that I did the rest of the steps with my pan mostly covered. First I let the buns steam (just about 15) then set them aside. Next I let the cheese melt over the patties (covered) to finish it up. The burgerlets came out so juicy with a really great onion flavor.

When I make the larger batch I'm gonna follow your directions exactly and expect they'll be even better than what I got today. Can't wait!

You don't fool around! We made ours a little "beefier" than your recipe calls for - as in, I had 12 ounces of beef, out of which I made 6 burgers. When I flattened them out (to about 3 inches in diameter), I left them about 3/8 of an inch thick, I would say. So I probably cooked them for 4 minutes instead of 3. But otherwise, I followed your recipe to the letter, and these were sensational.
I've done these three times in the last couple of months and I like them better each time These may be the perfect hamburger.
just made these... WOW! They closed the Krystal's by me a few years ago and this definitely satisfied my craving. It was like eating a fresh, high quality version of a Krystal burger. yummmmm

headline: Dinner Tonight: Broccoli Rabe with Asian Flavors Recipe
description: My go-to broccoli rabe recipe is really simple. Just boil the broccoli rabe for a few minutes, then saute with some olive oil, garlic, and red pepper flakes. I love how the heat of the chili plays with the slight...
name: Dinner Tonight: Broccoli Rabe with Asian Flavors Recipe
keywords: Asian, broccoli rabe

recipeInstructions.text: Cut the bottom 2 inches off broccoli rabe stems. Roughly chop the leaves into 1-inch pieces. Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add the broccoli rabe and cook for 2 to 3 minutes, or until tender. Drain in a colander, then dunk in a bowl of ice water. When cool, dry and set aside.
In a small bowl, whisk together the soy sauce, rice vinegar, sesame oil, and sugar.

In a large skillet, heat oil over medium heat until shimmering. Add the garlic, red pepper flakes, and ginger and cook for 2 to 3 minutes. Turn the heat up to medium-high, and add the chopped broccoli rabe and the soy sauce mixture. Stir well, and cook for about a minute until the broccoli rabe is warmed and the sauce has thickened. Season with salt and serve.

review.reviewBody: I love broccoli rabe! I make a different Asian version--I make it GOMAE style. It's a sweet sesame paste. Usually it's done with spinach or green beans. The sweet nicely complements the bitter green.

Broccoli and yummy don't usually co-exist in most vocabularies but an exception should be made for this recipe. I'd add toasted sesame seeds but it sounds good as is. 

Thanks, Nick.

headline: The Best Bloody Mary Recipe
description: How to make the best bloody Mary? Skip the mix and doctor up your tomato juice from scratch with horseradish, Worcestershire, and hot sauce.
name: The Best Bloody Mary Recipe
keywords: bloody mary, brunch
recipeIngredient: 1 tablespoon celery salt or (or plain kosher salt, if you prefer)
1/2 teaspoon freshly ground black pepper (or less to taste)
1/2 teaspoon freshly grated horseradish (or 1 teaspoon prepared horseradish)

recipeInstructions.text: Place celery salt in a shallow saucer. Rub rim of a 12-ounce tumbler with 1 lemon wedge and coat wet edge with celery salt. Place lemon wedge on rim of glass. Fill glass with ice.

Add Worcestershire, soy, black pepper, cayenne pepper, hot sauce, and horseradish to bottom of cocktail shaker. Fill shaker with ice and add vodka, tomato juice, and juice of remaining lemon wedge. Shake vigorously, taste for seasoning and heat, and adjust as necessary. Strain into ice-filled glass. Garnish with celery stalk and serve immediately.

review.reviewBody:
Hi Folks, as a Canadian foodie a few thoughts...
1) based on the possible original iteration of the drink as a Tomato juice based shooter with Oysters, perhaps a brief mention of the other ' Bloody Mary' of fame is the Bloody Caesar. 
2) Clam juice added to Tomato juice and blended with all the classic Bloody Mary additions. made from premixes or best of all bottled Clam Juice with all the favoured (cdn spelling) additions makes a great and very complex drink too. 
just a thought in this global world...
One change I would make - I always make my bloody mary's with gin, much more complex flavor
Love the suggested additions for variety.

A wide lane given to all for their choice of seasonings and ingredients. I prefer Aquavit over Vodka, but either works. I must disagree, however, on technique. Classically a Mary is rolled, not shaken. Shaking will, I believe, lead to excess dilution (a large point of shaking a drink is to incorporate water).
JLDalseg, what are the two places? The pepperoni/cheese/onion/pepper combo sounds familiar. (Too much garnish, IMO - if I want a chef's salad, I'll order one.)

headline: Braised Leeks With Lemon and Parsley
description: These braised leeks are silky, tender, and incredibly easy to prepare.
name: Braised Leeks With Lemon and Parsley
keywords: hanukkah sides, leeks, thanksgiving
recipeIngredient: 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for serving
12 to 16 large leeks, white and light green parts only, rinsed, split in half lengthwise
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
2 teaspoons juice and 2 teaspons zest from one lemon

recipeInstructions.text: Trim leeks to remove root ends, tough or damaged outer layers, and dark green top parts; reserve trimmings for stock if desired. Cut leeks in half lengthwise, then rinse each leek half under cold, running water, gently fanning layers open while being careful to keep leek halves intact, to wash away any sand or grit. Pat dry.

Preheat oven to 325°F (160°C) and adjust oven rack to middle position. Heat oil in a 12-inch heavy-bottomed skillet over medium-high heat until shimmering. Working in 2 batches, add as many leeks as you can fit in a single layer cut side down. Cook, pressing down gently with a spatula and shaking occasionally, until well browned, about 3 minutes. Transfer leeks to a 9- by 13-inch baking dish, arranging them in a single layer, cut-side up. Repeat with remaining leeks until all leeks are browned.

Pour wine and chicken broth into the skillet; bring to a simmer. Sprinkle leeks all over with salt and pepper, dot with butter, and then pour hot wine and broth mixture on top. Cover tightly with aluminum foil and bake for 30 minutes. Remove foil and continue to cook until leeks are completely tender and translucent, about 20 to 30 minutes longer, depending on thickness of the leeks.

Using a slotted spatula, carefully transfer leeks to a serving platter. Season lightly with salt. Transfer pan juices to a small saucepan (you should have about 1/2 cup). Bring to a simmer over high heat and cook until sauce is emulsified and reduced to about 1/4 cup, 5 to 10 minutes. Stir in parsley, lemon juice, and lemon zest, and season with salt and pepper. Pour braising sauce over leeks and serve, drizzling with extra olive oil if desired.

review.reviewBody:
The recipe doesn't specify, but the axis you cut the leeks on is a big deal.

Looking at the leeks elliptical cross section, I assumed you would cut down the longer major axis, to maximize the surface area for browning. This causes the leeks to totally delaminate into a pile of scraps. You must cut along the shorter major axis to have any hopes of coherent leeks, especially if you halved the leeks for easier plating.

so, after buying "only" 9 leeks, cutting off the dark green ends, and then still cutting the remain leek in half length wise, I would say 12-16 leeks for 10 servings is completely insane. 

After cleaning, I would consider that most people will probably eat 1/4 - 1/2 of a leek (already cleaned and trimmed). I would buy one large leek for 2-4 people. 

I assume I'll be eating alot of leek-bean soup in the coming weeks.

There are so delicious! Yes, the time is off. If you brought the stock to a boil before pouring it over the leeks you might have them cook in that long, but mine baked about 45 minutes covered plus the additional 10 minutes uncovered in order to get tender. Otherwise the recipe is great!

This didn't work out as well as I'd hoped. I followed the directions exactly, but the leeks ended up pretty chewy. I covered them and put them back in the oven hoping they'd soften, but no good. The flavor was great, but not the dish I was hoping for. I may try a variation and cut the leeks into much smaller pieces and see how that goes. If that works, I'll update the comments.
might make this this week to go with stuffed pork chops, in a not-related-to-Easter dinner. sounds easy, unique, and delicious

headline: Whole Roasted Suckling Pig
description: Whole tender, juicy, crisp-skinned suckling pig for the holiday table.
name: Whole Roasted Suckling Pig
keywords: holiday entrees, pork, suckling pig
recipeIngredient: 1 whole suckling pig, about 20 pounds (see note)
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
One 6-inch piece fresh ginger, cut into 1/2-inch slivers

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 300°F (150°C). Have a large work table ready and lined with plastic to make cleanup easier. Season pig inside and out with plenty of salt and pepper. Fill cavity with garlic and ginger. If pig fits on a single rimmed baking sheet or roasting pan, place it on the baking sheet back-side-up and transfer to the oven. If pig is too large, remove a rack from the oven and place on your range. Overlap 2 rimmed baking sheets so that they fit on the oven rack and line the whole thing with foil. Transfer the pig to the overlapped baking sheets then lift the whole oven rack and return to the oven so that the pig is in the center.

Roast until an instant-read thermometer inserted into the deepest part of the shoulder blade registers at least 160°F (71°C), about 4 hours. If ears or tail begin to burn, cover with foil and continue roasting.

Increase oven temperature to 500°F (260°C) and cook until skin is crisp all over, about 30 minutes longer (see note). Remove pig from oven, tent with foil, and allow to rest for 30 minutes. Serve by tearing skin into serving-sized pieces and removing flesh with your fingers and piling it onto a serving platter.

review.reviewBody: I see the recipe didn’t work for few people. We had a wild piglet, weighed in at about 13lbs, after gutting and cleaning. Used these instructions but did olive oil and salt on the entire pig skin, reduced cooking time to 3 hours (checked out perfectly at 160F), then hit it with 500 for 15-20 mins. Let it rest covered for 30 mins. DELICIOUS! Crispy golden skin, very soft and moist meat. This is a great recipe. Definitely recommend doing the olive oil rub - or you can use lard or butter or a combo.

In Louisiana when we say Cochon de lait. We buy a live pig and butcher it ourselves. We inject the pig with butter and spices,rub the pig down with alot of spices. (sometime they put potatoes, onions garlic etc and sew up the belly (anything you want really , its whatever you like the most). Then we dig a big hole in the ground we put alot of pecan wood in there and let it burn until we have lots of red coals (add more wood as needed). Then we box the fire with walls and a top. Then we put the pig on a heavy duty rod. We attach the rod to a rotisserie and cook for hours and hours (someone watching over it all the time) and I have never cooked a whole pig in the over or heard of cooking it that way.

I must be an idiot, because it did not turn out. I am a pretty decent cook, so I thought it would be a doddle. I have an oven thermometer and a ThermaPen, so I know the temperatures were right. I cooked everything exactly as described, but the pig was already at 180 after only 2.5 hours. I took it out and let it cool for about 45 mins, the put it back in at 500. After 45 minutes the skin still wasn't crisp. I took it out after an hour at 500 because it was smoking. Although it did taste really porky and delicious, the meat was overcooked and dry. The skin was like leather, no one liked it. All in all it was a total failure and waste of almost $300. I feel bad for the poor little guy.

I roasted a tender little piggy a couple months ago for a friend's birthday, without the benefit of this advice. But you're right - even a dumbo like me, flying blind, ended up with a delicious table full of porky goodness. GO PIG!

I've done this a few times, and these temperatures/times are what I generally follow.
Typically, I'm roasting a 20-25 lb whole pig in a relatively small oven-it barely fits.
Any time you cook whole pig-there are a lot of variables, and you have to watch it as it browns. In my case, the pig is sitting on its legs, so the back of the big tends to brown faster than the rest, as it is near the top of the oven. I have to usually cover the top with foil at some point.

headline: Sweet Potato Cake with Toasted Marshmallow Frosting Recipe
description: Instead of those puffed up mini-marshmallows, this Ode to a Casserole Cake is mounded with a spiced and spiked, pecan-flecked Italian meringue frosting that bronzes and crisps under the blaze of a hot flame.
name: Sweet Potato Cake with Toasted Marshmallow Frosting Recipe
keywords: cake, Let them eat cake, marshmallow, meringue, sweet potatoes
recipeIngredient: 2 ½ pounds sweet potatoes, peeled and cut crosswise into ½-inch thick slices
3 tablespoons orange juice and 1 tablespoon finely grated orange zest
6 large egg whites, at room temperature

recipeInstructions.text: For the Sweet Potatoes: Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 375°F (190°C). Arrange sweet potato slices in foil-lined 13- by 9-inch baking dish or foil-lined rimmed baking sheet.

In medium bowl whisk together orange juice, melted butter, brown sugar, bourbon, and salt. Pour mixture over sweet potatoes and bake until they’re tender and syrupy, about 1 hour, stirring to coat in liquid every 15 minutes.

Transfer dish to cooling rack and cool sweet potatoes for 10 minutes. Pulse sweet potatoes and any syrup in food processor until smooth. Measure out 2 cups and transfer to bowl; cool to room temperature, about 15 minutes.
Reduce oven temperature to 350°F (180°C).
For the Cake: Grease a 13- by 9-inch baking dish with butter.
In medium bowl, whisk together flour, orange zest, cinnamon, ginger, allspice, baking soda, and salt.

In separate large bowl, beat sugar, dark brown sugar, and eggs on medium speed until thickened and lightened in color, about 2 minutes. With mixer running, slowly add orange juice, oil, bourbon, and vanilla. Reduce speed to low and add flour mixture in three additions, alternating with sweet potatoes. Mix just until combined, scraping down sides and bottom of bowl with rubber spatula as needed.

Pour batter into prepared baking dish and bake until toothpick inserted in middle of cake comes out clean, about 1 1/2 hours. Transfer cake to cooling rack and cool completely in pan, 1 1/2 to 2 hours.

For the Toasted Marshmallow Frosting: Stir sugar, cinnamon, ginger, allspice, bourbon, and corn syrup in large heavy-bottomed saucepan over medium-low heat until sugar dissolves. Increase heat to medium-high and boil syrup until it registers 238°F. on candy thermometer, 8 to 10 minutes.

While syrup boils, in large bowl, beat egg whites and salt with whisk attachment on medium-low speed until whites begin to loosen and froth, about 1 minute. Increase speed to medium-high and beat whites until soft peaks form, 1 to 2 minutes.

With mixer running on medium-high speed, slowly and carefully add syrup to egg whites. Beat until outside of bowl is cool to the touch and whites are thick and glossy, about 7 minutes. Fold in pecans.

Spread topping on cooled cake with a spatula, pulling up on meringue to create decorative peaks. Torch meringue to lightly toast. If you don’t have a torch, adjust oven rack to upper third and set oven to broil. Broil until golden, 1 to 2 minutes.

review.reviewBody: I was skeptical of the 90-minute baking time, and I decided to check on it after 45 minutes. It was completely done and 210ºF in the center. I would suggest 45 minutes or less. Be cautious, and don't let your cake get over-baked!
Can I make this recipe, or any parts of it in advance?

headline: Suffering Bastard Recipe
description: There are a number of recipes for the Suffering Bastard floating about. Some are merely Mai tai variations with extra rum, while some call for brandy instead of bourbon, and others for rum.
