Today's drink historians generally settle on bourbon as one of the two base spirits, along with a shot of gin. The drink is then leavened with the healing powers of lime juice and bitters (the lime juice can range anywhere from a teaspoon to an ounce) and lengthened with a good dose of ginger ale.
name: Suffering Bastard Recipe
keywords: bourbon, cocktails, gin

recipeInstructions.text:
Pour ingredients into an ice-filled Old Fashioned glass and top with ginger ale, adding more ice if needed. Garnish with a sprig of mint or an orange slice. This Recipe Appears In 
 Tiki Revival Hits its Stride with New Recipe Book 'Beachbum Berry Remixed'

review.reviewBody:
Paul, it's been a rough few weeks.....definitely feeling like a "Suffering Bastard", pun intended. My wife is mixing as we speak. She has decided to make a variation for females by adding a stemmed cherry. She has christened it the "Suffering Bitch."
Thanks for the history lesson, and the recipe.
Was skeptical about the Suffering Bastard (though I like the back story) - bourbon AND gin? - and it truly was awful! Should've stuck to my bourbon Old Fashioneds. This bastard suffered!
Rongovian Embassy, Trumansburg, NY! l.o.l.o.l.o.l.
G&T's have been my go-to drink for several years now...might be time for a change. this drink sounds 'absolutely fantastic' (tyler florence)
drinking one now. delicious!

headline: The Silver Palate's Corn Bread-Sausage Stuffing With Apples Recipe
description: Although Ed Levine is a self-proclaimed semi-homemadeoholic when it comes to preparing Thanksgiving dinner, he does have a few tried-and-true recipes that he can count on to make the meal less "semi-homemade" and just plain "homemade." He admittedly uses Pepperidge...
name: The Silver Palate's Corn Bread-Sausage Stuffing With Apples Recipe
keywords: stuffings, thanksgiving, The Silver Palate

nutrition.servingSize: enough stuffing for a 20-pound turkey, 12 to 14 portions

recipeIngredient: 3 tart apples (Jonathan and Winesap are good), cored and chunked; do not peel
1 pound lightly seasoned bulk sausage (breakfast sausage with sage is best)
3 cups coarsely crumbled white bread (French or homemade preferred)
Salt and freshly ground black pepper, to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 325°F.

Melt half of the butter in a skillet over medium heat. Add the chopped onions and cook, partially covered, until tender and lightly colored, about 25 minutes, Transfer the onions and butter to a large mixing bowl.
Melt the remaining butter in the same skillet. Add the apple chunks and cook over high heat until lightly colored but not mushy. Transfer the apples and butter to the mixing bowl.
Crumble the sausage into the skillet and cook over medium heat,stirring, until lightly browned. With a slotted spoon, transfer the sausage to the mixing bowl and reserve the rendered fat.
Add the remaining ingredients to the ingredients in the mixing bowl and combine gently. Cool completely before stuffing the bird; refrigerate if not used promptly.

If you do not wish actually to stuff the bird (goose or duck. for example, can make the stuffing greasy), spoon it into a casserole. Cover the casserole and set into a large pan. Pour hot water around the casserole to come halfway up the sides, Bake for 30 to 45 minutes, basting occasionally with the cooking juices from the bird or with the reserved sausage fat if necessary.

review.reviewBody: I have been making this dressing for years and my family would have nothing else. It is by far the best dressing I've ever had.
My family has been making this for decades, always the most requested item.
My family wants this dressing every year. It is absolutely wonderful. I bind it a bit with chicken or turkey broth.
I’ve been making this stuffing for over 15 years and once you eat it you will never want any other
I made this for the first time for my not yet family-in-law in 1988 and have made it every year since!

headline: Hui Guo Rou (Sichuan Twice-Cooked Pork)
description: Twice-cooked pork—a classic Sichuan recipe—gets deep, savory flavor from fermented black beans, chili bean paste, and sweet bean paste. The two-stage cooking process starts by simmering the pork belly for tenderness, and finishes with a stir-fry to make it brown and slightly crispy.
name: Hui Guo Rou (Sichuan Twice-Cooked Pork)
keywords: chichi's chinese, pork, pork belly, sichuan
recipeIngredient: about 12 ounces fresh boneless, rind-off pork belly
6 baby leeks, 12 ramps, or 12 green onions, sliced on a steep bias into 2-inch long segments
2 teaspoon sweet bean paste (tian mi jiang)
2 teaspoons fermented black beans, or 1 tablespoon fermented black bean paste

recipeInstructions.text: Bring a large pot of water to a boil. Add pork and simmer until just cooked through, about 25 minutes. Remove pork from water and let cool. (Water can be set aside for use in stock, or discarded.) Place belly in refrigerator until flesh is firm, about 1 hour.
Slice pork thinly into 1/4-inch-thick rectangles.

In a wok, heat oil or lard over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add pork and stir-fry until fat has rendered somewhat and skin is brown and somewhat crisp, about 2 minutes. Push pork to one side of wok and add chili bean paste. Stir-fry until oil is red, then add sweet bean paste and black beans and stir-fry for a few seconds longer. Mix everything together, then stir in soy sauce and sugar.
Add leeks (or ramps or green onions) and ginger and stir-fry until they are just cooked, 30 seconds to 1 minute. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: I think I read in my Fuschia Dunlop cookbook that hoisin can be used as a substitute for sweet bean paste. As for the chili bean paste, it is called douban jiang, and can be found in a good Chinese market. If no luck with that, you can substitute gochujang which can be found at most Korean groceries.

- midimastah: I'd guess the bean paste ingredient is this, in which case your sauce sounds about right to me. My experience has been that various brands formulate their 'classic' Chinese condiments/sauces (e.g., Shaoxing wine) quite differently -- so just look for one that you like, and don't worry about the exact ingredients.

Chichi, looks fantastic! Would you please provide some tips on finding sweet bean paste? I've had a lot of trouble finding this at my local asian market. Like, what ingredients to look for? Other things it might be called? I have something called "sweet bean paste sauce" with wheat flour, soybean paste, soy sauce, sugar and mushroom extract. The last two ingredients don't exactly seem right, but I really don't know. It's Janex Int'l brand, from Taiwan.

headline: Tuscan Pappa al Pomodoro (Tomato and Bread Soup) Recipe
description: Just because it's no longer tomato season doesn't mean it's time to stop eating tomatoes. The Tuscan tomato-bread soup known as pappa al pomodoro, for instance, is perfect made with good-quality canned tomatoes and plenty of olive oil.
name: Tuscan Pappa al Pomodoro (Tomato and Bread Soup) Recipe
keywords: bread, Italian, soup, tomato, tuscan
recipeIngredient: 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for drizzling
1 (28-ounce) can whole plum tomatoes, crushed by hand, with juices
2 sprigs fresh basil, plus torn leaves for serving
1/3 pound (about 6 ounces) fresh or stale rustic bread, torn or cut into 1-inch chunks (see note)
2 cups warm Quick and Easy Vegetable Stock , plus more as needed (see note)
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: In a large saucepan, heat 2 tablespoons olive oil over medium heat until shimmering. Add red pepper flakes and garlic and cook, stirring, until garlic just begins to turn golden. Add onion and cook, stirring, just until softened, about 5 minutes. Add crushed tomatoes and their juices, along with basil sprigs, and bring to a simmer.

Stir in bread. Ladle stock on top, stirring to combine. Simmer bread, adding more stock as needed, until bread is completely softened and custardy and soup has thickened to a porridge-like consistency, about 25 minutes. Season with salt and pepper. Discard basil sprigs.
Spoon into bowls, generously drizzle with olive oil, and grind black pepper on top. Garnish with torn basil leaves and serve.

review.reviewBody: I made this tonight. I did add in a couple spoonfulls of Calabrian chili paste, But, must say this is a delish dish. So comforting.

This was my first time making or tasting Pappa al Pomodoro and it turned out great. This recipe came together very quickly and easily, also the ingredients should be on hand in most Western kitchens. I didn't experience any issues halving the recipe, but will warn that the portions are large. This soup is most certainly meant to be served as a main dish, not a side. 
I will be adding this recipe to my regular rotation.

Of course, as usual, I ignored most of the directions and just threw everything into the pot and simmered for 25 minutes. It was FANTASTIC!!! I didn't have fresh basil so I used the squeeze stuff and it was still great. Perfect for a below zero day in the Hudson Valley.

This is one of my favorite dishes when i'm In Tuscany. I've tried other recipes and they've all been disappointing. I had my doubts about this one too But I'm delighted to report that it makes a very, very good version of Pappa al pomodoro. I found that the bread didn't break down as much as I like so I used my pastry blender and it yielded perfect results. Break out your best extra virgin olive oil to finish.
Made this tonight. Absolutely delicious! I love the textural contrast between the completely custardized pieces of bread and the crust, which almost takes on the texture of a loose dumpling.

headline: Turmeric Chicken with Sumac and Lime from 'The New Persian Kitchen'
description: For a totally different take on the basic roasted chicken thigh, enter Louisa Shafia's Turmeric Chicken with Sumac and Lime from The New Persian Kitchen. This super-simple braised dish is bright, tangy, and brilliantly yellow—it's a far cry from most muddled braised chicken dishes and even further from the typical roasted bird.
name: Turmeric Chicken with Sumac and Lime from 'The New Persian Kitchen'
keywords: chicken, Cook the Book, garlic, gluten free, louisa shafia, mains, poultry, sumac, the new persian kitchen, turmeric
recipeIngredient: Sea salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: In a small bowl, mix the turmeric with 1 tablespoon salt and 2 teaspoons pepper. Place the chicken on a rimmed baking sheet and sprinkle with the spice mixture, turning to coat both sides.

Heat a large skillet over medium-high heat and add the oil. Brown the chicken well on both sides, about 7 minutes per side. Pour in the water, then add the garlic, stirring it into the water. Bring the water to a boil, then turn down the heat to low and cover. Braise the chicken for 25 minutes, until the inside is opaque. Transfer the chicken to a serving platter, turn up the heat to high, and reduce the cooking liquid for a few minutes, stirring occasionally until it’s slightly thickened. Season to taste with salt and pepper, and pour the sauce over the chicken.
Dust the chicken with sumac and pepper, garnish with lime halves, and serve.

Vegetarian Option: Use whole portobello mushrooms in place of the chicken, or use 1 pound firm tofu, well drained and cut into slabs 1 inch thick. You will need a little extra oil for searing than what is called for in the recipe.

review.reviewBody: This is one of my favorite weeknight recipes! I usually use boneless thighs, which has the added benefit of cutting down on the cooking time. 1 Tbs. Diamond kosher salt was not overwhelmingly salty--some does get lost on the baking sheet.

I used the amount of sea salt specified and had no problem with saltiness. This was super quick, really easy, and best of all, delicious. A really clever take on Persian flavors for a quick weeknight meal. Here's a photo of my rendition: http://instagram.com/p/s_MNEjqRqq/?modal=true

Waaay too salty, but otherwise great. I made this recipe with four chicken legs, so 2X the chicken, and next time will use maybe 1 tsp of salt for the whole thing. Served with a basmati pilaf and Persian grated carrot salad (http://www.food.com/recipe/persian-style-carrot-salad-437223). Fab meal.
Omitting the garlic and grilling the chicken on the bbq also makes an amazing dish. We serve ours with whole greek yogurt on the side and extra sumac :)

I have tried an similar turmeric chicken but it was a deep fried one. I applied yoghurt, turmeric and salt to chicken and kept that for half n hour. Then just deep fry it and enjoy the fried chicken. check out these Pantry Cabinets.

headline: Turkish-Style Vegan Tofu Scramble (Vegan Menemen) Recipe
description: Menemen—eggs scrambled with olive oil, onions, chilies, and tomatoes—is traditionally made by slow-cooking onions and hot chilies in olive oil, then seasoning them with dried chilies and oregano and stewing them with tomatoes. The eggs go in at the last moment and are cooked until just barely set. With so many strong flavors and a texture easily captured by silken tofu, it works great as a vegan breakfast.
name: Turkish-Style Vegan Tofu Scramble (Vegan Menemen) Recipe
keywords: breakfast, easy, Istanbul, menemen, quick, tofu, turkish
recipeIngredient: 3 tablespoons (45ml) extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for serving
1 small onion, finely diced (about 3/4 cup; 4 ounces; 115g)
3/4 cup finely diced shishito, padrón, or Chinese green long peppers (4 ounces; 115g)
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1/2 cup chopped peeled ripe fresh tomatoes or drained canned tomatoes (4 ounces; 115g)
1 (14- to 16-ounce; about 400g) block soft silken tofu

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium nonstick or cast iron skillet, heat olive oil over low heat until barely warm. Add Urfa chilies, oregano (if using), onion, and peppers. Season with salt and a very generous amount of black pepper. Cook, stirring frequently, until very soft, about 8 minutes. Add tomatoes and continue to cook, stirring frequently, until deepened in color, about 5 minutes longer. Remove half of mixture and reserve.

Add tofu and season with salt and pepper. Cook, folding gently, until tofu is heated through and broken into large curds. Gently fold in reserved vegetable mixture. Sprinkle with chopped parsley and serve with bread.

review.reviewBody:
Made this tonight, sort of (some substitutions happened due to quarantine- didn't have urfa peppers but had a jar of "Turkish Breakfast Sauce" that's been kicking around my pantry for ages, so I cracked that open- it's a pureed pepper paste with walnuts and spices). Didn't have parsley so I garnished with scallions, used green and red bell peppers for the pepper portion. Used a mixture of chopped fresh tomatoes and passata for the tomato portion.

 It was absolutely fantastic, best tofu dish I've had. Such a luxurious texture. I've never had this dish with eggs, but I can't imagine it would be better than the tofu. Served with grilled Italian bread and olives.
I added 1/4 tsp kala namak for the eggy flavor. Very delicious recipe. Thank you

The link for the urfa chilies is broken. Will you re-post please?
Thank You!

I'm confused as to what a "Chinese green long pepper" is. My local Oriental supermarket has something they call "Chinese green long hot peppers," but I'm unclear as to whether or not these are supposed to be HOT peppers. Padron and shishito are supposed to be generally mild, so I'm guessing the "Chinese green long peppers" you refer to must be sweet. Is this correct?
can you use firm tofu for this recipe? don't really want to buy silken tofu right now

headline: Turkey Paitan Ramen With Crispy Turkey and Soft-Cooked Egg Recipe
description: A rich and creamy turkey broth flavored with miso and sesame with crispy braised turkey meat, a soft boiled egg, and Brussels sprouts leaves.
name: Turkey Paitan Ramen With Crispy Turkey and Soft-Cooked Egg Recipe
keywords: Asian, noodle, ramen, soup, thanksgiving

nutrition.servingSize: Makes about 3 quarts broth, serving 6 to 8

recipeIngredient: 3 pounds turkey backs and wings or leftover roasted turkey bones and carcass, roughly chopped with a cleaver or a heavy duty chef's knife
1 large onion, skin on, roughly chopped
2 whole leeks, washed and roughly chopped
2 dozen scallions, white parts only (reserve greens and light green parts for garnishing finished soup)
6 ounces whole mushrooms or mushroom scraps
1/2 cup red or white miso paste
12 Brussels sprouts, divided into individual leaves
6 to 8 servings ramen-style noodles, store-bought or homemade
6 to 8 marinated eggs , or sous-vide soft boiled eggs
2 to 3 tablespoons mayu (black garlic oil) or toasted sesame oil, for serving

recipeInstructions.text: Place turkey bones and drumsticks or thighs in a large stockpot and cover with cold water. Place on a burner over high heat and bring to a boil. Remove from heat as soon as boil is reached.

While pot is heating, heat 2 tablespoons vegetable oil in a medium cast iron or nonstick skillet over high heat until lightly smoking. Add onions, 12 cloves garlic, and ginger. Cook, tossing occasionally until deeply charred on most sides, about 15 minutes total. Set aside.

Once pot has come to a boil, dump water down the drain. Carefully wash all bones and meat under cold running water, removing any bits of dark marrow or coagulated blood. Bones should be uniform grey/white after you've scrubbed them. Meat should be lightly rinsed.

Return turkey to pot along with charred vegetables, leeks, scallion whites, and mushrooms. Top up with cold water. Bring to a rolling boil over high heat, skimming off any scum that appears (this should stop appearing within the first 20 minutes or so). Use a clean sponge or moist paper towels to wipe black or gray scum off from around the rim of the pot. Reduce heat to a bare simmer and place a heavy lid on top.

Once the lid is on, check the pot after 15 minutes. It should be at a slow rolling boil. If not, increase or decrease heat slightly to adjust boiling speed. Boil broth until turkey legs/drumsticks are completely tender, about 3 hours. Carefully remove turkey legs/drumsticks with a slotted spatula. Transfer to a sealed container and refrigerate until step 7. Return lid to pot and continue cooking until broth is opaque with the texture of light cream, about 3 to 5 hours longer, topping off as necessary to keep bones submerged at all times. If you must leave the pot unattended for an extended period of time, top up the pot and reduce the heat to the lowest setting while you are gone. Return to a boil when you come back and continue cooking, topping up with more water as necessary.

Once broth is ready, cook over high heat until reduced to around 3 quarts. Strain through a fine-mesh strainer into a clean pot. Discard solids. Skim liquid fat from top with a ladle and discard. Return to a medium pot on the stovetop and keep warm.
Whisk miso paste and tahini into broth. Grate garlic cloves and whisk into broth. Season to taste with salt and/or soy sauce.

Pick turkey meat from turkey legs and finely shred by hand. Place in a cast iron or nonstick skillet and heat over medium-high heat. Cook, flipping and breaking up the meat occasionally, until crusty and browned all over. Season to taste with salt and transfer to a bowl. Set aside.

Heat remaining tablespoon oil in a large skillet over high heat until lightly smoking. Add Brussels sprouts leaves. Season to taste with salt and cook, tossing frequently, until bright green and charred in spots, about 2 minutes. Transfer to a bowl and set aside.

Cook ramen noodles according to package directions. Drain and transfer to individual serving bowls. Top with broth, Brussels sprouts leaves, sliced scallion greens, shredded turkey, and an egg. Drizzle with mayu or toasted sesame oil. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody:
I didn't have tahini so I toasted like 5 tbs of sesame seeds and 
ground them up. Out of the resulting 1/4 cup of ground sesame I only 
added half and it was VERY pronounced in the broth.




For best results use store bought tahini as it is milder. Or only use a small amount of homemade tahini.




. I also added like 2 tbs of rice wine vinegar which damped the extreme flavors of the my last-second tahini.

TL;DR: Just do what kenji says

@Kenji - this looks amazing, but with such a long prep time I'd like to be able to make the broth in advance. I assume I could stop after step 6 and put this in the fridge for a couple of days, right? Would it freeze well? Thanks!

thank you, THANK YOU, THAAAANK YOU SO VERY MUCH!!!!

Sorry for the hyperbole but since I cant eat pork or beef and i often have a huge craving for ramen, this pretty much will be a life saver. I can imagine myself making a large amount of really concentrated broth, freeze it and use it up with some egg noodle when the craving strikes.....mmmm. maybe a runny egg and some crisply fried chicken with a teriyaki glaze and some roasted chili oil will seal the deal for me.

Again, thank you so much. This made my day!
Could you give the miso and tahini measurements in grams for 1 litre of stock and what would you add after that to it?
Sorry, the timing was a little off. It should have been 6 to 8 total, not additional time. I've corrected it, it should all be set to go!

headline: Roast Turkey in Parts
description: Roasting your Thanksgiving turkey in parts is the best way to achieve even, thorough cooking from breast to leg, regardless of tradition.
name: Roast Turkey in Parts
keywords: low carb, thanksgiving, turkey
recipeIngredient: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 large onion, peeled and roughly chopped (about 2 cups)
1 large carrot, peeled and roughly chopped (about 1 cup)
2 large ribs celery, roughly chopped (about 1 cup)
2 medium cloves garlic, peeled and smashed
1 quart (900ml) homemade or store-bought low-sodium chicken stock, divided

recipeInstructions.text: Using a sharp knife, remove legs from turkey and set aside. Using a large cleaver or heavy chef's knife, cut backbone and carcass away from the turkey breast. Separate turkey wings from breast. Chop backbone and carcass into rough pieces with the cleaver. Season liberally with salt and pepper. For best results, transfer turkey parts to a wire rack set in a rimmed baking sheet and let rest, uncovered, overnight in refrigerator (see notes).

Adjust oven rack to lower-middle position and preheat oven to 275°F (135°C). Spread onions, carrots, celery, garlic, bay leaves, and black peppercorns evenly across a rimmed baking sheet. Pour 1 cup (240ml) stock into baking sheet; reserve remaining stock. Place a wire rack on top of the baking sheet. (It may rest directly on top of vegetables—this is okay.) Set aside. Place turkey on top of rack on top of vegetables, trying to leave a little space between the turkey pieces.

Roast turkey until an instant-read thermometer inserted into the center of a breast piece registers 150°F (66°C), 2 to 3 hours total. Remove breast and set aside. Continue roasting legs until an instant-read thermometer registers 170°F (77°C) when inserted into leg, about 30 minutes longer. (Depending on the pieces' arrangement, the legs might finish at the same time as the breasts.) The turkey pieces will not be browned. Set aside at room temperature for at least 30 minutes and up to 2 hours. Set a fine-mesh strainer over a large bowl. Strain vegetables from tray. Reserve liquid and discard vegetables.

While Turkey Is Roasting, Make the Gravy: Roughly chop carcass and neck into 1-inch chunks. Heat vegetable oil in a large saucepan or Dutch oven over high heat until just beginning to smoke. Add turkey carcass and cook, stirring frequently, until well browned on all surfaces, about 10 minutes. Add remaining stock. Add water until turkey pieces are barely covered. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and allow to simmer while turkey roasts.

While turkey is resting, pour stock through the same strainer and add to reserved stock from strained vegetables. Discard solids. If desired, cut giblets into 1/4-inch pieces. Heat butter in a medium saucepan over medium-high heat until melted. Add giblets and cook, stirring frequently, until lightly browned, about 2 minutes. Add flour and cook, stirring constantly, until flour is light blond in color. Slowly whisk in reserved stock, Marmite, and soy sauce. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer. Cook until desired consistency is reached, about 10 minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
30 Minutes Before Serving Turkey: Preheat oven to 500°F (260°C). Place turkey in oven and cook until crisp and browned, turning breast once during cooking. Serve immediately with gravy.

review.reviewBody: For the folks who've made this recipe, are you supposed to complete to remove the bone from the breast or keep the bone/ribs on when roasting?
I'm a bit confused on the final internal temperature. Aren't we supposed to cook all poultry to 165F? I know there is carry-over temp, but cooking the breast to 150F seems a bit low.
Hi Kenji, can I do everything in advance until step 5, refrigerate the turkey, then let it reach at room temp the next day before proceeding to step 6? Will this dry out the breast? Thanks!

For the busier cook: I bought turkey parts already cut. We like dark meat only, so thighs, legs, and wings. I followed Kenji's separate article for dry-brining (3 nights). I used Trader Joe's prepared mire poix rather than chop my own veg (2 containers as I used a double-size tray for the turkey). I cooked until a leg was at 167 and took the tray out (fearing that I would have dried out meat if I went to 170 as the recipe directs, given that the tray would go back in at 500 for 30 minutes). Looking at the pale, salty skin when it came out of the oven the first time, I was nervous that it would not properly crisp up and that the meat would be dry with the high-temp additional cooking. I should not have feared - it crisped up perfectly to a beautiful golden brown in 30 minutes and the meat was juicy and delicious! We all agreed it was our best turkey ever. For the gravy, I used a shortcut as well: Trader Joe's makes a good prepared gravy that can be doctored up to delicious. I couldn't fit all of my turkey parts on the tray for the oven so I seared and braised a couple of thighs in a dutch oven on the stove, and then added the drippings (judiciously) to the store-bought gravy. Quick, easy, and very tasty gravy.

Kenji, is there any value in putting oil on the skin before the roasting or browning steps? And in step 6 where you say turn the the breast, do you mean rotate it or flip it over to brown the underside?

headline: Tsukune (Japanese Chicken Meatballs) Recipe
description: Lightly seasoned chicken meatballs are threaded onto skewers, grilled, and finished with a sweet and salty tare sauce.
name: Tsukune (Japanese Chicken Meatballs) Recipe
keywords: chicken, easy, meatball
recipeIngredient: 3 medium cloves of garlic, smashed and peeled
1 tablespoon whole black or white peppercorns
2 teaspoons finely minced fresh garlic (about 2 medium cloves)
8-10 wooden skewers, soaked in water for 30 minutes prior to use

recipeInstructions.text: For the Tare Sauce: Combine mirin, soy sauce, sake, brown sugar, sherry vinegar, garlic, scallions, ginger slices, and peppercorns in a medium saucepan. Bring to boil over high heat, then reduce to a simmer, whisk to combine, and cook until mixture is thick and syrupy, about 45 minutes. Strain through a fine-mesh strainer. Set aside or store in an airtight container in the refrigerator until ready to use.

For the Meatballs: Using hands, mix together chicken, bread crumbs, scallions, egg, ginger, garlic, sesame oil, salt, and white pepper until thoroughly combined. Form mixture into 1-inch meatballs and thread onto skewers.

Light one chimney full of charcoal. When all charcoal is lit and covered with gray ash, pour out and spread coals evenly over entire surface of charcoal grate. Set cooking grate in place, cover grill and allow to preheat for 5 minutes. Clean and oil grilling grate. Careful transfer skewers to grill, if necessary supporting meatballs from bottom to prevent them from falling off skewers. Grill until first side is well browned, about 3-4 minutes. Using tongs, rotate meatballs and cook until well browned on second side, about 2-3 minutes. Repeat for remaining two sides.

Brush tare sauce all over meatballs and allow to cook for 15-30 seconds longer. Transfer skewers to a plate or serving dish, brush lightly with sauce again and let rest for 5 minutes. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: Amazing flavor! I tried this with pre-ground chicken, which was too watery, so I added additional panko. I put the meatballs in the freezer for half an hour, till they firmed up enough to skewer. I broiled them in the oven in a well-oiled metal pan, instead of grilling them. They stuck to the pan and were impossible to turn, so I took them off the skewers to broil on all sides. Despite everything, the meatballs and sauce were fantastic. I can't wait to try them again!

I just got back from being in Japan for 5 months and will be trying the recipe this coming weekend. I have a four year old kiddo who is crazy for yakitori after we spent several meals at the autoyakitori machine. He keeps asking for chicken ball Yakitori and I can't wait to try this one. 

Side note...we made the chicken and onion recipe you posted last week and it tasted just like the chicken off the carts...oishi!

Great recipe! I'm interested in the issue of binders. It seems that both egg as binder and cornstarch as binder don't solve the problem of shaping the meat onto the skewer since they both require heat to trigger their binding properties (reference). In "The Japanese Grill" by Ono and Salat, they recommend kneading the meat until it's sticky enough to form the meatballs. I found a video demonstrating this technique put out by Japan's public broadcasting company. Finally, I would imagine that the type of skewer is also important. Yakitori is traditionally cooked with the flat style teppogushi skewers which have more surface area than the thin kind used in this recipe.

@laerm This recipe from the site suggests using gelatin in chicken meatballs and they turn out great for me every time. I didn't have any gelatin one time and just went without it and they came out much less moist, so I'd recommend it.

I may try some tips from this recipe for hamburgers for the meatballs that uses fish sauce and mayo for umami and moisture (I substituted soy sauce for the fish sauce, because I was out, and it was great). The fish sauce shouldn't really be detectable, just a background flavor.
http://www.thekitchn.com/how-to-make-burgers-on-the-stovetop-cooking-lessons-from-the-kitchn-217722

I learned from my Japanese ex-husband about kneading meat to tenderize it and it seems to be one of those things where you have to commit - if you don't knead enough you make it tough. So either be gentle with ground meat or knead it til sticky.

headline: Tropical Pineapple, Mango, and Coconut Fools Recipe
description: The classic British fool, a dessert of fruit and whipped cream, is an ideal warm weather dessert because it's light and balance of sweet and tart fruit flavors. Spooned into this tropical take are layers of juicy mango, pineapple, and toasted coconut.
name: Tropical Pineapple, Mango, and Coconut Fools Recipe
keywords: cream, custard, dessert, english, fool, whipped cream
recipeIngredient: 3 cups chopped fresh pineapple (from a 2 1/2-pound pineapple)
1/2 cup sweetened, shredded coconut, lightly toasted

recipeInstructions.text: Place pineapple and 1 tablespoon sugar in medium saucepan. Cook over medium heat, stirring occasionally, until fruit has softened and mixture becomes jammy, about 15 minutes. If pineapple looks too dry during cooking, add a teaspoon of water at a time. Remove from heat and stir in lemon juice. Adjust to taste with sugar and lemon juice. Chill until completely cold before using, about an hour.
Using mixer fitted with whip attachment, whip cream on high speed to soft peaks. Fold in yogurt, pineapple compote, and 1/2 of the coconut.
Spoon pineapple cream into glasses, alternating with fresh mango. Top with remaining coconut. Serve chilled.

review.reviewBody: u can try to use bablimas instead of mango.

headline: Tricolor Sweet Pepper Relish Recipe
description: This fresh, tangy, and fruity sweet pepper relish livens up a humble hot dog in a way fitting for the start of a new grilling season.
name: Tricolor Sweet Pepper Relish Recipe
keywords: condiments, pepper relish, relish, sauced, sauces
recipeIngredient: 1 large red bell pepper, cored, seeded, and cut into 1/8-inch dice
1 large yellow bell pepper, cored, seeded, and cut into 1/8-inch dice
1 large orange bell pepper, cored, seeded, and cut into 1/8-inch dice

recipeInstructions.text: Bring 4 cups of water to a boil in a small saucepan over high heat. Remove from heat, add in diced peppers and let steep for 5 minutes. Strain peppers through a fine-mesh strainer.
Add in vinegar, sugar, mustard seeds, salt, and celery seeds into now empty saucepan. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, stirring to dissolve sugar.

Add peppers and simmer, stirring occasionally, until little liquid remains, 15-20 minutes. Transfer relish to a jar, let cool slightly, then cover and place in refrigerator until completely chilled. Store in refrigerator for up to 2 weeks.

review.reviewBody: Is the water from the steeped peppers good for anything? Can I save it and add it to tea or soup? Lol sorry if this is a stupid question 😅
Can this Tricolor sweet relish be canned ?

headline: Tri-Tip Beef Roast With Shallot Jus Recipe
description: Using the reverse-sear method, you can turn the underappreciated tri-tip into a special-occasion beef roast, without breaking the bank.

video.description: This reverse-seared roast beef can hold its own as a special-occasion main course or as a top-notch sandwich filler. [Video: The Serious Eats Team]
video.name: How to Make Roast Beef and Beef Roast

name: Tri-Tip Beef Roast With Shallot Jus Recipe
keywords: beef, beef stock, holiday, jus, reverse sear, roast beef, shallot, winter
recipeIngredient: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 quart (950ml) beef stock or brown chicken stock (see note)

recipeInstructions.text: The Day Before Roasting: Using butcher's twine, tie tri-tip at 1-inch intervals using butcher's knots . Season generously with salt and pepper. Transfer to a wire rack set in a foil-lined rimmed baking sheet and refrigerate, uncovered, at least overnight and up to 2 nights.

When Ready to Cook: Adjust oven rack to center position and preheat oven to 225°F (105°C). Place baking sheet with rack and tri-tip in oven and roast until internal temperature registers 115°F (46°C) on an instant-read thermometer at the tri-tip's thickest point, about 1 1/2 hours.

Meanwhile, in a 3-quart stainless steel saucier, combine stock and 1 cup (240ml) red wine over medium-high heat. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, then reduce to a simmer. Simmer, occasionally scraping down sides of saucier with a rubber spatula, until mixture thickens slightly and is reduced to 2 cups (475ml), 15 to 20 minutes. Turn off heat.

Just before tri-tip comes out of the oven, add oil to a 12-inch cast iron, carbon steel, or heavy stainless steel skillet and heat over high heat until smoking. Add tri-tip to skillet and cook, using a small cast iron skillet or weight to press down on tri-tip for even browning. If the beef begins to char or the skillet begins smoking aggressively, reduce heat to medium-high. Cook until tri-tip is evenly browned on all sides and internal temperature registers 130°F (54°C), about 5 minutes.

Transfer tri-tip to a cutting board and allow to rest for 5 to 10 minutes. Meanwhile, add shallots to now-empty skillet, season lightly with salt and pepper, and cook, stirring frequently, until shallots are softened and lightly browned, about 6 minutes. Add remaining 1/4 cup (60ml) red wine to skillet and use a wooden spoon or rubber spatula to scrape up any browned bits from the bottom of the pan.
Transfer shallot mixture to saucier with reduced stock and red wine mixture and stir to combine. Bring jus to a simmer over high heat and stir in soy sauce. Season to taste with salt and pepper.

Cut and remove twine from tri-tip, then cut into 1/4- to 1/2-inch-thick slices if you are serving the beef as a main course. Slice into thin, 2-inch-wide pieces if you plan to serve the beef in sandwiches. Serve right away, passing shallot jus at the table.

review.reviewBody: If you use twice as much meat, you don't need twice as much jus. It just ended up being too much for us. A lot of folks did not even partake of the jus.

Being in CA I fix Tri-Tip a lot. Instead of the oven I use a smoker, and I finish off on the grill. But I cannot, for the life of me, figure out how you tied a Tri-Tip to get it into that shape. Description, please.

We made this a NYE last year. The leftovers may have stollen the show though! 

Question for this year, we are making this for a larger group. Has anyone finished on the grill? I am thinking searing multiple tri tips inside will be a bit smokey. 

Last round the au jus was a bit lack luster. Followed the steps as written. I am wondering as well if anyone had tips? I was planning to use a little Demi glacé to boost flavor.

5 stars !!!
 This recipe turned out great! My wife reports this is the best Tri-Tip she's ever tasted. 
Using a weight on the meat while searing was a brilliant trick...it speeded up that process. [I had a smaller cast iron skillet placed on the roast and then put a small saucepan holding bit of water for more wt., and it worked splendidly.]
A great result fot.my 3.5# Tri-Tip.

Been using your oven temp and cook times combined with a sear for my tri-tips and eat them like steak. Comes out perfect every time! Didn't really use the whole recipe so cannot comment on that. I like to buy tri-tip on sale (~$4-5/lb) and enjoy it like a good steak. I like the simple flavors and methods =)

headline: Tres Leches Cake Recipe
description: This creamy, moist sponge cake is soaked with a three-milk mixture, topped with cream cheese-enriched whipped cream, and served thoroughly chilled.
name: Tres Leches Cake Recipe
keywords: cakes, desserts, Serious Sweets, tres leches

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 325°F (160°C).
Combine flour and baking powder in a small bowl; set aside.

In the bowl of a stand mixer, beat egg whites and salt with whisk attachment on medium-low speed until whites begin to froth, about 1 minute. Increase speed to medium-high and beat whites until soft peaks form, 1 to 2 minutes. Slowly add the sugar and continue beating until stiff peaks form, 2 to 3 minutes. The mixture may look a bit thick.

Add egg yolks and beat just until combined. Decrease speed to low and add flour in 3 additions, alternating with the milk, scraping sides and bottom of bowl as necessary. Add vanilla and beat just until combined.

Scrape batter into an ungreased 13- by 9-inch baking dish. Bake until cake tester inserted in center comes out clean, 30 to 35 minutes (see note). Transfer cake to cooling rack and cool completely in pan, 60 to 90 minutes.

Once cooled, poke cake all over with fork. Combine evaporated milk, sweetened condensed milk, and 1 1/2 cups heavy cream in large bowl. Pour mixture evenly all over cake. While cake soaks, make whipped cream.
Combine gelatin and water in a small bowl. Microwave until gelatin dissolves, about 20 seconds. Cool to room temperature, about 5 minutes.

In the clean bowl of stand mixer, beat cream cheese, confectioners’ sugar, and cooled gelatin with whisk attachment until soft and whippy, about 2 minutes. Add remaining 1 1/2 cups cream and beat to soft peaks, about 2 minutes.
Spread whipped cream over cake and refrigerate until thoroughly chilled, at least 2 hours (see note). Serve.

review.reviewBody: Called into the Milk Street Radio show and Chris Kimball solved the mystery of the sunken cake for me. Don't whip the egg whites in step #3 to a stiff peak. That can break them down too much. Instead, bring them to a soft peak only before moving to step #4. I did that plus the other fixes that seemed to help (room temperature eggs, high sided plan, wrapped with damp towel and cooled upside-down). The result was a perfectly level cake, and moreover, the cake really absorbed the tres leches soak quickly. This fix worked so well that I will skip the other steps in the next go around to see if those aides are really needed.

This was really excellent and totally not shameful at all. This is the fourth or fifth tres leches cake I've made and this recipe just perfectly nailed the texture. (Soak overnight!)

One problem with the overall recipe is that it lacks a bit of "depth" as written -- it's just pure milkiness. I think there are a couple of opportunities to make it even better:

- The "sauce" can be enhanced by turning one or both cans of condensed milk into dulce de leche
- It can be further enhanced with the addition of a shot of rum or brandy
- A dusting of cinnamon under the whipped cream mixture is highly recommended - really brings things together. I think a very small amount of cocoa powder could be interesting too.
- The cream cheese in the whipped cream mix really helps cut the sweetness. I went a bit further by dropping the sugar level just a bit, and I added a bit of almond extract to get a bit more mileage out of that component.
- Garnish with fruit! Strawberries especially are highly recommended.

I wish I read the comments first! This was too big for my 9x13; it almost overflowed. The middle also did sink so I think an 11x16 would've been better. There was also too much liquid. Probably could've halved one or two of the milks. Overall though, this was a hit! Everyone loved it and it tasted fantastic. I did the whipped cream without the cream cheese and gelatin but it was still solid, especially with a dusting of cinnamon.

This recipe is specified for a 13 x 9-inch baking dish. As compared to other recipes, one for this size and one for a 16 x 11 baking dish, this recipe calls for more flour, more baking powder, more sugar, and nearly twice as much of the milks. I've made these other recipes and I'm concerned about the sugars in this one. What are the advantages of using more sugar?

Like many other readers my cake sunk in the middle. A huge crater that could probably be hidden with whipped cream if I wasn't planning on serving it to friends. I'm a better than average baker so it's not a beginner's mistake. 

It's disappointing that despite the many comments that no one from the Serious Eats team has given any suggestions on why this might be happening.

headline: Traditional Sukiyaki (Japanese Beef Hot Pot)
description: How to make flavorful, traditional Japanese sukiyaki (beef hot pot) at home.
name: Traditional Sukiyaki (Japanese Beef Hot Pot)
keywords: beef, hot pot, sukiyaki, Sunday Supper, tofu
recipeIngredient: 1 1/2 pounds sirloin beef, sliced into 1/4- to 1/8th-inch strips
8 ounces firm tofu, cut into 1-inch cubes
8 ounces mushrooms, sliced (shiitake, portabello, button, enoki or a variety)
1 yellow onion, sliced into thin rings
1 small head bok choy or napa cabbage, leaves cut into 1- to 2-inch segments

recipeInstructions.text: Bring mirin, sake, soy sauce, dashi, and sugar to a simmer and stir until sugar is dissolved. Remove from heat and reserve.
Arrange beef and tofu on separate platters (or dinner plates) cover with plastic wrap and refrigerate. Arrange mushrooms, onion, scallions, and bok choy on a serving platter and set aside.

Rinse rice in a fine-mesh strainer until water runs clear. Place in a small pot and cover with 2 cups water, bring to a simmer then turn heat to low and cover with a tight fitting lid. Steam until all the water is absorbed, about 30 minutes.
Set up butane burner or electric hot plate, and carefully ignite. Place a thick bottomed, low sided pan over burner and pour in sauce mixture. Bring to a simmer.

Divide rice among 4 small bowls. Place platters of ingredients around burner and cook as you eat by transferring to simmering broth and cooking to the desired doneness. If desired, break egg into a separate bowl, beat, and use to dip steaming hot ingredients into.

review.reviewBody: This recipe sounds like a hybrid of shabu shabu and sukiyaki. Do you proofread your recipes? In step 4 you talk about puting the rice noodles in hot water. Your list of ingredients makes no mention of rice noodles only udon or shirataki neither of which are made with rice.
Just want to say thanks to Ken G for the Goma sauce recipe. It was wonderful.
Sorry about that @Sweetie - all fixed up now :)

I like to serve Sukiyaki with Goma Sauce for dipping.

Goma Sauce
1	Cup	Sesame Seeds, Toasted
1	clove	Garlic, Minced
1/2	Cup	Soy Sauce
1/4	Cup	Vegetable Oil
2	Tbsp	Sesame Oil
2	Tbsp	Rice Vinegar
1	Tbsp	Mirin
3/4	Cup	Beef Broth
Toast sesame seeds in frying pan until golden brown
Grind to a paste in blender, then add other ingredients
Also good with Dashi instead of Beef Broth

headline: Old Fashioned Cocktail
description: The classic Old Fashioned features little more than whiskey, sugar, and bitters. Done right, it's a perfectly balanced, timeless crowd-pleaser.

video.description: If bourbon is the king of American whiskey, surely the Old Fashioned is the king of bourbon cocktails. Here's how to make it right.
video.name: How to Make an Old Fashioned

name: Old Fashioned Cocktail
keywords: bourbon, cocktail, drink, rye, toasted sugar, whiskey
recipeIngredient: 1 teaspoon (5g) superfine sugar, toasted sugar , or 1 sugar cube
2 to 3 dashes bitters (Angostura bitters are traditional and work well; Fee Brothers’ Whiskey Barrel-Aged Old Fashioned Bitters are better)
Orange and/or cocktail cherry, such as Luxardo to garnish (optional)

recipeInstructions.text: Combine whiskey, bitters, and sugar in a mixing glass. Add several large ice cubes and stir rapidly with a bar spoon to chill. Strain into a rocks glass with fresh ice. Garnish, if you like, with a slice of orange and/or a cherry.

review.reviewBody: This is NOT how to make a good Old Fashioned. An orange slice will make the drink pulpy, use the rind of an orange instead. In fact, once you get the simple syrup (recommended) and bitters mixture going (and technically you should use orange bitters in addition to Angostura), throw in the orange rind and muddle to release the oils of the orange rind. That will give the drink a next-level authenticity. Stir 50 times with a 2" ice cube. Do NOT add maraschino cherries, which are basically candy. Instead, add 1-2 Luxardo cherries. So, in total, orange rind and luxardos, NOT orange slice and maraschinos.

Rye, maple syrup, and black walnut bitters garnished with a Luxardo or other good cocktail cherry of your choice (not those repugnant bright red things) makes an excellent version. A single large ice cube in the glass, preferably. 
 And no sliced citrus, please.

I personally am a big fan of the muddled sweet mess of a 1950's era old fashioned. Whether you want to call that by a different name than a classic old fashioned is immaterial...those drinks are awesome.

May I suggest to others who enjoy an occasional sloppy old fashioned--my particular recipe is to muddle (I use normal proportions--teaspoon of sugar, slice of orange, cherry and three dashes bitters). Then stir in 1oz of Rye. Then pack the glass with CRUSHED ice (just wrap the ice in a towel and beat it to hell) and top the glass off with Rye.

It's basically a Rye snow cone but the trick is that the head of the drink is basically pure whiskey with no sweetness and then the drink gets sweeter as you get to the bottom of the glass. The beauty of this is the second (and subsequent) rounds, because after enjoying the sweet frutiness of the end of the drink your next round cleanses your palate less sweet rye at the top.

Try it--you'll love it!

If,IF, you're ever going to put any fruit in an old fashioned, it should simply be a twist of orange to compliment the bitters and the sweetness of the bourbon. When you start muddling fruit in there, you're making an entirely different drink. 

If I go to a bar and get a feel that they are going to make some terrible facsimile of an old fashioned, I simply order a manhattan.

This is barely an Old Fashioned, and certainly not preferable to the prohibition style cocktail. For starters, use an orange rind instead of an orange slice. Pulp is not preferable in a cocktail. Feel free to muddle the rind with your sugar liquid and bitters, which will help bring out the aromatics of the orange. Stir 50x with a large ice cube (2" preferred). That's an Old Fashioned. Also, I prefer mine with Rye, not Bourbon, because Bourbon is already sweet, and adding sugar will just make it sweeter. Rye and sugar are a great offsetting combo.

headline: Traditional Jewish Mandelbrot (Mandel Bread) Recipe
description: Family recipes aren't as set in stone as we all like to think. Like for example, this mandel bread. I called my mom for the recipe, which I'd attributed to my Grandma...
name: Traditional Jewish Mandelbrot (Mandel Bread) Recipe
keywords: Cookies, holiday cookies, Jewish holidays, mandel bread, mandelbrot, Nick Malgieri, SE Cookie Swap 2010
recipeIngredient: About 1 cup golden raisins, mini chocolate chips, and walnuts or a combination of the three (Malgieri's recipe calls for almonds, and no raisins or chocolate chips.)
1 teaspoon vanilla extract (Malgieri calls for a teaspoon of almond extract in addition to the vanilla extract, but I skip it.)
1/2 cup grapeseed or other neutral oil
1/2 cup sugar mixed with 1 teaspoon cinnamon for finishing

recipeInstructions.text: Set rack in middle level of the oven and preheat to 350°F.
In a bowl, combine flour, baking powder, and salt; stir well to mix.
In another bowl, whisk eggs by hand until well mixed. Add sugar and whisk until smooth. Whisk in extract and oil.
Fold flour mixture into egg mixture until all flour is absorbed. Fold in nuts, raisins, and chocolate chips.

On a lightly floured surface, press dough together. Divide dough in half and roll each half into a log the length of your pan (14 to 18 inches). Place each log on pan and flatten slightly. Bake until well-risen and firm, about 25-30 minutes. Cool the logs on the pans and racks.

Reset racks in upper and lower thirds of oven. Using sharp serrated knife, slice baked logs diagonally about every 1/2 inch. Place cinnamon-sugar mixture in a shallow dish and turn the cut cookies in it. Return biscotti to the pans, cut side down, and bake until dry and crisp, up to 20 minutes longer.
Store cooled cookies between sheets of parchment or wax paper in tin or plastic container with tight-fitting container.

review.reviewBody: "Mandelbrot" is German/Yiddish for almond bread, so the name's got to change if you're using walnuts. Almonds are such a great flavor too so I have no idea why you'd leave them out.

How can it be mandelbrot without the mandel??????? The almond extract is what makes it mandelbrot!!!

Harvey

What use is the last step for? The slices are already too dry to absorb the cinnamon-sugar mixture. Wouldn’t it have been easier to apply the cinnamon-sugar mixture on top when log was still moist?!! 

Like the OP, I used walnuts. I used Olive oil instead of grape seed oil 
I don’t like overly sweet pastries, so it came out Ok. This is supposed to be crisp like a biscotti with a “hint” of sugar-cinnamon?
I followed the recipe but used almonds. I didn't have either vanilla or almond extract, but these still came out great! I'll make them again, but will add almond extract when i can get it.
instead of chocolate chips we crush Heath bars and they are to die for.

headline: White Chocolate and Raspberry Frozen Mousse Bombes Recipe
description: If you're ever in the mood to put together a fancy dessert at home, mousse bombes are a fantastic way to go. They satisfy my craving for many things at once; a little cake, a little frozen mousse, and a surprise bit of fresh fruit, jelly, or nuts. Best of all, they have a gorgeous, smooth shell of chocolate that looks as beautiful as it tastes, giving you the dramatic payoff of a plated dessert with just a little effort.
name: White Chocolate and Raspberry Frozen Mousse Bombes Recipe
keywords: cakes, chocolate, frozen desserts, mousse
recipeIngredient: 4 ounces white chocolate, melted and tempered
1 teaspoon gelatin, bloomed in 2 tablespoons water
6 ounces heavy cream, whipped to soft peaks and chilled

recipeInstructions.text: To Prepare the Molds : Place dome mold sheet onto a sheet pan. Using a pastry brush, paint melted, tempered chocolate evenly on surface of each mold cavity, making sure chocolate goes straight to the edge. Place molds into fridge to set.

To Prepare the Cake : Preheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Make an X with butter on surface of a rimmed baking sheet, then line it with parchment. In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with paddle attachment, cream butter and sugar on high speed until light and fluffy, scraping down sides of bowl periodically. Add eggs and yolks one at a time, mixing well after each addition. Sift dry ingredients together. Turn mixer down to low speed and add half of the dry ingredients, followed by half the buttermilk. Mix on low until just incorporated, then add rest of the dry ingredients and buttermilk and mix until just incorporated. Remove bowl from stand mixer and finish mixing by hand with a large rubber spatula. Pour batter into prepared pan and spread it out evenly with an offset spatula.

Bake cake for 15 to 20 minutes, rotating halfway through, until tester inserted into center comes out clean and cake begins to pull away from sides of pan. Allow cake to cool for 15 minutes in pan, then run paring knife around edges. Place a piece of parchment on cake, followed by an inverted sheet pan, then turn cake upside down. Gently peel back top parchment from cake and allow cake to rest for 10 minutes before punching out circles with round cutter the same size as mold cavities.

To Prepare the Mousse: In a large bowl set over simmering water, melt white chocolate. Add the 2 ounces of cream a little at a time, stirring until mixture becomes smooth and warm to the touch. Melt bloomed gelatin in microwave (stop every 15 seconds to check) and stir into chocolate mixture. In a separate bowl, whisk together egg yolks and salt, then gradually whisk it into chocolate mixture. Continue whisking chocolate mixture for 1 minute over double broiler, then remove bowl from heat. Place bowl in fridge to cool to room temperature (mixture should be neither warm nor cold, about 20 minutes). Whisk firmed chocolate mixture to smooth it out. Stir 1/4 of the chilled whipped cream into chocolate mixture to lighten it, then gently fold in remaining cream.

To Assemble the Bombes: Place mousse in a piping bag and pipe it into each chilled chocolate mold, taking care to only fill just to the top. Place a raspberry or two into each bombe and smooth mousse over top. Place a circle of cake over each mold and gently press cake into mousse. Place sheet pan of molds in freezer and allow them to set for at least 4 hours.

To Make the Sauce: Place frozen raspberries and sugar in a saucepan over low heat, stirring occasionally. As raspberries begin to melt, stir to help break them up. When fruit begins to simmer, remove from heat. Press fruit pulp and juice through a fine-mesh strainer. Discard seeds and chill sauce.

To Serve: Place a tablespoon of sauce onto each plate. Create a design by dragging the back of a spoon through sauce. Loosen edges of bombes, then turn each cavity inside out to unmold them. Let bombes sit for 20 minutes to allow cake time to thaw, then carefully place bombes onto prepared plates and serve.

review.reviewBody:
How much leaf gelatine should I use instead of powdered? 
Thanks.

I've made mousse before and the plain gelatin smell was so horrible! I plan to make the above recipe this week, and don't have time to find/order the gelatin you state as having a milder smell. So...this is a horrible question, but can I substitute raspberry jello for the gelatin, or is that a recipe (ha!) for disaster. I can use the plain, which I actually already have, I just dread it!
Can this be frozen a few days in advance before Step 5?
Amazing recipe Lauren and I can't wait to try it out, however I'm a vegetarian who doesnt eat eggs of Gelatine, anyway you can suggest substitutes for that please??

Lauren, beautiful picture and lovely recipe! My friend made maple syrup mouse for our Game of Thrones dinner and marathon so I'm on a bit of a mouse kick (don't get me started about the GoT addiction).

I know that we all should be weighing our ingredients for baking but since I'm moving overseas in two months, I'm trying to avoid acquiring any new kitchen gadgets - even the all mighty kitchen scale. Any chance your recipe can show both volume and weight? If not, no worries, I'll do the conversion myself.

headline: Traditional Irish Bacon, Cabbage, and Parsley Sauce Recipe
description: According to Darina Allen, author of Forgotten Skills of Cooking, bacon and cabbage is Ireland's national dish. Here's her version of a traditional recipe.
name: Traditional Irish Bacon, Cabbage, and Parsley Sauce Recipe
keywords: cabbage, Cook the Book, Darina Allen, Forgotten Skills of Cooking, irish, UK
recipeIngredient: About 5 pounds loin, collar thick-cut bacon
salt and freshly ground black pepper
About 4 tablespoons freshly chopped curly parsley

recipeInstructions.text: Cover bacon in cold water in a large pot and bring slowly to a boil.
If bacon is very salty there will be a white froth on top of the water, in which case it is preferable to discard the water and start again.

It may be necessary to change the water several times, depending on how salty the bacon is. Finally, cover bacon with hot water, place a lid on the pot, and simmer until bacon is almost cooked, allowing 20 minutes for every 1 pound.

Meanwhile, trim the outer leaves of the cabbage and cut it into quarters, removing core. Discard core and outer leaves. Slice cabbage across the grain into thin shreds. If necessary, wash it quickly in cold water. About 20 minutes before the end of cooking the bacon, add shredded cabbage to the pot of simmering bacon.
Stir, cover, and continue to boil gently until both cabbage and bacon are cooked, about 1 3⁄4 hours.
To make roux, melt butter in a pan and cook flour for 2 minutes on low heat, stirring occasionally. It will keep for two weeks in the refrigerator.

To make the sauce, add cold milk to a saucepan and add herbs and vegetables (if using). Bring mixture to simmering point, season with salt and pepper, and simmer for 4-5 minutes. Strain milk, bring it back to a boil, and whisk in 4 tablespoons roux until sauce is a light coating consistency. Season again with salt and pepper. Add chopped parsley and simmer over very low heat for 4 to 5 minutes. Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary.

review.reviewBody:
I was recently in Ireland and I ate bacon every single day I was there. Often more than twice a day, actually... I'm going to have to find a way to get it here. 

I never had it boiled, though...
Irish bacon is cured, not smoked. It is loin. Around here, we like to get it from Oscar's Adirondack Smoke House. Wonderful products!
I also love it cooked with ruthabagas, especially if you can’t digest green cabbage!
I also love bacon cooked with ruthabagas, especially if you can’t eat dark cabbage anymore ❤️

The cut of meat that is used for this recipe, is a "sweet pickled cottage roll" or a brined shoulder butt, or pork shoulder. It's a brined or salted cut of pork.

It's not smoked, it's not ham. Ham is from the leg. It's not back bacon. Yes, back bacon is a thing, but it's not used for this recipe. In Ireland, "bacon" can mean any cut of pork other than ham.

headline: Traditional French Cassoulet
description: Here's how to make a traditional French cassoulet at home, complete with a trio of meats and beans with a rich sauce, all topped with a savory dark brown crust.
name: Traditional French Cassoulet
keywords: bean, casserole, cassoulet, chicken, duck, easy, fall, pork, winter
recipeIngredient: 3 tablespoons kosher salt; for table salt, use half as much by volume
1 quart homemade or store-bought low-sodium chicken stock
3 packets (3/4 ounce) unflavored gelatin, such as Knox (see note)
8 ounces salt pork, cut into 3/4-inch cubes
6 to 8 pieces of chicken thighs and drumsticks, or 4 whole chicken leg quarters
1 pound garlic sausage (2 to 4 links, depending on size)

recipeInstructions.text: In a large bowl, cover beans with 3 quarts (2.8L) water and add salt. Stir to combine, then let stand at room temperature overnight. Drain and rinse beans; set aside.

Adjust oven rack to lower-middle position and preheat oven to 325°F (160°C). Place 4 cups (946ml) stock in a large liquid measuring cup and sprinkle gelatin, if using, over top. Set aside. In a large Dutch oven, heat duck fat (if using), salt pork, and pork shoulder and cook over high heat, stirring occasionally, until browned all over, about 9 minutes (if not using duck fat, cook pork with no additional fat). Using a slotted spoon, transfer to a large bowl, leaving rendered fat in Dutch oven, and set aside.

Season chicken or duck thighs with pepper (do not add salt) and place skin side down in Dutch oven. Cook without moving until well-browned, 6 to 8 minutes. Transfer to a plate and let cool to room temperature.
Add sausages to Dutch oven and cook, turning occasionally, until well-browned, about 2 minutes per side. Transfer to bowl with salt pork. Drain all but 2 tablespoons fat from pot.

Add onion to Dutch oven and cook, stirring and scraping up browned bits from bottom of pot, until onion is translucent but not browned, about 4 minutes. Add drained beans, carrot, celery, garlic, parsley, bay leaves, cloves, and stock/gelatin mixture. Bring to a simmer over high heat. Reduce to low, cover Dutch oven, and cook until beans are slightly softened but retain a bite, about 20 minutes.

Cover cooled chicken or duck and transfer to refrigerator. Using tongs, remove carrots, celery, parsley, bay leaves, and cloves from pot and discard. Add pork and sausages to pot and stir to incorporate. Beans should be almost completely submerged. Transfer to oven and cook, uncovered, adding remaining 1 cup (237ml) stock halfway through by pouring it carefully down side of pot as necessary to keep beans mostly covered, until a thin crust forms on top, about 1 hour 30 minutes.

Break crust with a spoon and shake pot gently to redistribute. Nestle chicken or duck into the Dutch oven, skin side up. Return to oven and continue cooking, stopping to break and shake crust every 30 minutes, until crust is deep brown and thick, an additional 1 hour 30 minutes. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: Question about the garlic- peeled? Skin on? Entire bulb? or #cloves?

This is PHENOMENAL. I've made it about a dozen times and:

1) I've made this with chicken and with duck and find that it comes out best when I DON'T put the either back in until the very end, just long enough to cook through. The beans are incredibly flavorful with the fat, salt pork, and simmered (but removed!) aromatics, and the chicken does dry out and the brown crust gets soggy in the pot for the entire time in the oven.
Same for the sausage, which ALWAYS gets mealy after hours in the oven (and I've tried different kinds of sausage).

2) The BEST versions I've made forgo chicken and use prepared duck confit legs (from D'Artagnan, sold at my local megamart, or from my local butcher), browned after the salt pork and then shredded and added at the very end.

3) This tastes richer and more complex with homemade stock (I don't bother with the gelatin in this case). I've also used chicken fat skimmed from making stock instead of the duck fat when I've used duck confit instead of chicken legs! Fewer specialty ingredients this way.

3) No need to peel the garlic! I do cut a few slits into the cloves through the papery skin before I throw the whole head in, though.

4) The cloves kind of float to the top or are otherwise easy to spot when giving the beans a gentle stir before putting in the oven.

5) I forgot to soak the beans once or twice and just cooked the entire pot a little longer ... it turned out great, with no adverse effects on the bean texture!

I made this very close to Kenji's original recommendations, and it's amazing. I didn't soak the beans overnight, but gave the whole thing about an hour and a half extra. Looking at the full article attached to the recipe article, this seems a really minor issue, so long as you monitor and adjust liquid/time accordingly. I also used Great Northern beans, since I wasn't able to find dried Cannellini beans. Also for full disclosure, I misread the full article and included minced garlic equivalent to a head (hey; I love the stuff), and I used spicy Portuguese sausage after a quick Google search for garlic sausage instead of reading Kenji's responses to comments and the full article attached to the recipe article.

Nonetheless, it works beautifully. Test the beans when you check the crust and add water as you need. The salt pork and sausage add plenty of salt (and the dish is salty overall, but it's a bean/sausage/salted pork stew after all). Using the gelatin will get the crust if you are patient (and using an enameled Dutch oven seems to help).

The whole point seems that with some general guidelines, cassoulet has a lot of leeway in making it to suit tastes, available ingredients, and the poor reading comprehension of certain emulators (read: me). I have found my new thing to cook for the week ahead.

I think some people are confused by the 4 hour cook time in the summary. You don’t cook the chicken/duck for 4 hours, the poultry only cooks for an hour and a half.

The first hour is taken up with sautéing the onions, browning the pork, sausages and chicken, and cooking the beans for 20 minutes on the stovetop. Then it goes in the oven WITHOUT the chicken/duck for 90 minutes. Then you break the skin, add the poultry and put it back in the oven for 90 more minutes, doing the skin breaking thing every 30 minutes.

So if you do happen to have mutton (buying mystery meat in a Mongolian market without having a grasp of the language - what could possibly go wrong?), do you treat it the same way you would the chicken?

headline: The Food Lab's Beef Pho
description: Roast beef bones, fresh vegetables, and warm spices make for a traditional, soul-warming Vietnamese beef pho.
name: The Food Lab's Beef Pho
keywords: Asian cuisine, beef, noodle soup, phở, soup
recipeIngredient: 1 large hand ginger (about 6 inches long), split in half lengthwise
3 pounds beef shin, with meat attached
2 pounds oxtail, cut into 1/2 to 1-inch thick slices
1/4 cup fish sauce, plus more to taste
1 pound beef flank steak, sliced thinly against the grain
2 to 3 cups mixed herbs (cilantro, basil, and mint)

recipeInstructions.text: Place a wire cooling rack or grill grate directly over the flame of a gas burner set on high. Place onions and ginger on top and cook, turning occasionally, until deeply blackened on all sides, about 10 minutes total. Alternatively, adjust oven rack to 3 to 4 inches from broiler element and preheat broiler to high. Place onions and ginger on a foil-lined broiler tray. Broil, turning occasionally, until charred on all surfaces, about 25 minutes total. Set aside.

Meanwhile, combine beef shins, oxtail, chuck, and brisket in a large stockpot. Cover with cool water. Bring to a boil over high heat. Boil for 15 minutes, then dump water and meat into sink. When cool enough to handle, rinse parts under cool running tap water, carefully scrubbing debris off of any bones and out of cracks in the meat, then return them to the pot. Cover with cool water.

Add charred onions, ginger, anise, cinnamon, fennel, cloves, coriander, fish sauce, sugar, and 1 tablespoon salt. Bring to a boil over high heat, reduce to a bare simmer, and cook, skimming occasionally, until brisket and chuck are tender but not falling apart, about 1 1/2 hours. Transfer brisket and chuck to a small bowl and cover with cold water. Refrigerate until ready to serve.

Continue simmering broth for a further 4 hours, topping up with water as necessary. Strain broth through a fine-mesh strainer. If desired, pick meat and connective tissue from oxtails and beef shins. Discard bones and aromatics. You should end up with about 4 quarts broth. Dilute with water or reduce as necessary to reach 4 quarts. Keep hot.

Carefully skim fat off of surface of broth and discard. Season broth to taste with additional fish sauce, salt, and/or sugar. It should be highly seasoned. Slice cooked beef into thin slices or rough chunks.

Prepare pho noodles according to package directions. To serve, place re-hydrated noodles in individual noodle bowls. Pour hot broth over noodles. Serve immediately, allowing guests to top with cooked meat and slices of raw flank steak, herbs, aromatics, lime, and sauce as they wish.

review.reviewBody:
@Kenji

Have made this pho recipe a bunch of times and it compares favorably to my mom's recipe as well as reasonably close to the real deal in Saigon. Just have a few questions and wanted to post some minor refinements to your recipe that worked for me.

1. Scraping the blackened bits off the charred onions and ginger prevents it from dissolving and darkening in the soup.

2. The parboiling step is too long. Most of the gunk and proteins come off after 5-10 minutes. Also, why would you overcook the brisket and chuck in boiling water for 15 minutes? Adding them to simmering stock afterwards doesn't add a noticeable amount of debris.

3. I like my soup more herbal, and add about 1.5x-2x spices as well as black/green cardamom. This is totally optional and your ratio is pretty good. But you need to toast the spices(strange as you advocate this in many of your other recipes). I toast the bigger spices on the wire rack over flame with the onions and ginger and smaller ones either in oven or in pan on stovetop. 

4. My family never adds fish sauce to the soup while its boiling. 1/4 cup over 4 hours = smelly kitchen and doesn't add noticeable difference. I add at the end before serving and some on the table to add to taste.

Other than these steps, everything else makes a great soup! The rehydrated noodles are key to avoiding the soggy boiled noodles you get at home. I hope you update this recipe soon because it is close to excellent. 

Last thing - please change the awful picture at top. Everything is wrong! Mint in the soup is just wrong, looks like rice vermicelli instead of banh pho, flank is cut too thick and lemon cut oddly. It doesn't do this recipe justice.

I made this for pho tai. I used beef trimmings saved in the freezer plus a few bones. I skipped the dumping step but did everything else per the recipe. I bought thinly sliced round steak for the tai. Wow! Just like restaurant pho. (Whenever we have steak I save the trimmings in the freezer for stock. I do the same with "doggy" bag bones.)

If I wanted to make a big batch of broth alone to freeze for future pho adventures, which of the meats would you recommend using? I was leaning towards the shin and oxtail, but I'd love get @Kenji's input. Thank you!

You've got it down to a science :). I just made some yesterday for my family in the crock pot. I recommend adding a couple of celery sticks and 1 carrot (both cut into 2 - 3 pieces), or adding 1 daikon cut into 2" pieces for extra flavorful broth. Depending on how large my pot is and whether these 3 varieties are in my fridge, sometimes i add only carrots, sometimes carrots and celery, and for an extra large pot all 3. I've found oxtail, flank and brisket can cloud up your soup so be sure to parboil them with bones and remove impurities. You can also use a fine mesh strainer to make the borth clear as well. I did not have to strain the broth yesterday at all. I also placed it in the fridge to let the fat coagulate the next morning for a delicious healthy soup. It takes practice to get the soup this good and flavorful but worth learning how to do it right. The best part about cooking it in a crock pot is you don't have to worry about it throughout the day. It's done when you get home and the house smells amazing. Bon appetit!

I'm a bit late to the party but how the hell did they calculate 139 grams of protein when there's only 500 gram of beef. Seems like they took the the nutrition facts for the entire pot and forgot to divide

headline: Dinner Tonight: Tortellini with Brown Butter and Sage Recipe
description: Brown butter with sage is almost archetypal, but the deliciousness (and simplicity of preparation) of brown butter never ceases to amaze me. The process is simply to cook butter gently in a skillet until the water in the butter has...
name: Dinner Tonight: Tortellini with Brown Butter and Sage Recipe
keywords: brown butter, fall recipes, pasta, sage, tortellini
recipeIngredient: 1/2 pound dry pasta or two servings of frozen tortellini
1/3 cup sage leaves, about 10 to 15, left whole or thinly sliced
1 tablespoon lemon juice, or to taste

recipeInstructions.text: Bring a pot of water to a boil; add salt. Cook the pasta or tortellini according to package instructions, then drain.

In a small skillet, melt the butter over medium heat. Continue cooking until the butter begins to brown, keeping a very close watch to ensure it doesn't burn. Keep in mind that the temperature will continue to rise even off the heat. When the butter is nearing completion, add the sage leaves to crisp in the hot fat. Remove from heat and add the lemon juice to halt the cooking, plus a pinch of salt (unless you're using salted butter).
Toss the drained pasta into the skillet, coating well with the sauce. Finish with black pepper and Parmesan, if desired. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: @chanterelle: Sorry for the missing step; it's back in now!
Step two comes up blank. No instructions for the sauce.

Spaghetti Warehouse in Atlanta used to have a wicked browned butter sauce for pasta. Drain the pasta REALLY well before adding. I'd have to pass on the sage, though. Definitely Parmesan, but go with the shaved instead of grating it. I use a twist of FRESH lemon occasionally--great for adding that bit of brightness to a dish, especially a good chicken and rice soup or dish.

headline: Ultra Crispy Burgers Recipe
description: This crispy burger is made of a mix of sirloin, brisket, and oxtail for intense beefy flavor. Thin patties cooked over high heat is the secret to a crispy exterior.
name: Ultra Crispy Burgers Recipe
keywords: beef, burger, sandwiches
recipeIngredient: 6 ounces beef sirloin, trimmed of gristle, and cut into 1-inch cubes
5 ounces beef brisket, trimmed of gristle, and cut into 1-inch cubes
12 ounces oxtail, fat and meat carefully removed from bone and trimmed of silverskin, bones discarded or reserved for another use (about 5 ounces of combined meat and fat)
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
4 soft white burger buns, lightly toasted

recipeInstructions.text: Place feed shaft, blade, and 1/4-inch die of meat grinder in freezer until well-chilled. Meanwhile, place meat chunks on rimmed baking sheet, leaving space between each piece and place in freezer for 10 minutes until meat is firm, but not frozen.
Combine meat in large bowl and toss to combine. Grind meat directly onto parchment or foil-lined rimmed baking sheet.

Without picking the meat up, divide it into four piles on baking sheet and gently press piles into patties approximately 4-inches wide and 1/2-inch thick. Patties should remain loose and have ragged edges. Season generously with salt and pepper. Using wide spatula, carefully flip patties over (some may fall apart - just push them together again). Season second side with salt and pepper and refrigerate until ready to use (can be stored on sheet tray covered with plastic wrap in refrigerator for up to 1 day).

Heat vegetable oil in heavy-bottomed 8-inch sauté pan over high heat until smoking. Carefully transfer patty to skillet and cook without moving until dark crust forms, about 2 1/2 minutes (open your window, disarm your fire alarm, and be prepared for splatters). Using spatula, carefully flip patty and top with cheese. Continue to cook for one to two minutes longer until desired doneness is reached (patty will be at least medium, but will still remain juicy even until well-done)

Meanwhile, place pickles and onions on burger bun bottom if desired. Top with cooked patty, close buns, and eat immediately. Repeat with remaining burgers, discarding all but 1 teaspoon fat from skillet between burgers. This Recipe Appears In 
 The Burger Lab: The World's Best Burger for a Single Man (or Woman)

review.reviewBody:
Last night I made a very fake flubbed version of this but I think the concept held in the outcome. I used 80/20 beef from the grocery, spread it loosely with my fingers on a sheet pan into loose, fairly thin, piles of burgers. The pan sat in the fridge overnight. Patties were heavily salted/peppered before gently placing 2-per 8” thick-bottomed non-stick, nearly smoking hot pans. 
There was enough of a pool of fat around the patties to fry and crisp both sides up well and the insides were a bit over cooked but still tender. The slice of Kraft American was SO bom! I’m not sure I’ll grease up my kitchen (windows open, fan and exhaust on high!) but everyone loved the burgers!! Cheers to those who did the work of figuring this out - I just don’t have the money or will to go as far as the instructions but appreciate the whole idea. Cheers!

Tried this after getting a grinder for Christmas. I can get used to these real fast! 

I used a chuck roast that I portioned, with a little additional suet that WF gave me for free. Probably a little more than 16oz overall, the patties were just slightly larger than 4" in diameter. Anyway, chilled all the grinder parts in the freezer, cubed up the meat and suet and chilled that for 15-20 minutes. Ground the meat/suet mix directly to a lined cookie sheet then used the spat to form/gently press into patties. After forming, I put the cookie sheet with patties back in the freezer for a bit (5-10 min) while I heated up the pan. I think this helped them maintain shape when transferring to the pan. 

Since the patties were a little larger than 4" diameter...and I was cooking for two, I used an 11" saute pan instead of the 8". Fired up the burner to warm the pan, added a little Canola, turned the exhaust on low (we have a 36" Wolf range and a big exhaust hood with a commercial style external blower...on high, this sucker can pull smoke and flame out of the fireplace!). For grease spatters, I used a, well, spatter guard. No fuss, little muss for grease and smoke. 

Pulled the patties out of the fridge, salt and peppered one side then gently slid the spat under and transferred two patties (salt-n-peppered side down) to the now smoking hot pan. Then salt and peppered the top side. The patties held up perfectly. After about 2.5 minutes, gently flipped the patties...again they held up, no breaking apart, and coated the top with some grated cheddar (grate the cheese well ahead of time and let it come to room temperature, mellow).
