Another two minutes and onto a toasted kaiser roll (will use softer bread next time!), a little lettuce and onion and viola!

Big beefy, juicy flavor...I can definitely get used to this!

Other than the roll being a little too crusty, the
Lol the people using sous-vide for hours to make hamburgers.

Made this recipe for the 2nd time today. One deviation: I'm using 100% ground chuck (it was on sale) and ground in a food processor (burger lab technique), not a meat grinder. The idea here is fantastic, and the meat has come out tasting awesome. But I'm encountering an issue: when I gently press the ground meat together, the "patty" falls apart when put in the frying pan, and flipping was a disaster. Happened twice in a row. I don't want to overwork the meat, but has anyone else had falling apart problems? 

Is it using chuck, or grinding in a food processor? Should I pick up the meat and try to form it a little bit?

headline: Ultra-Creamy Spinach and Mushroom Lasagna Recipe
description: An ultra-creamy, rich, and hearty vegetarian lasagna stuffed with spinach, mushrooms, and cheese. Rich enough to appease even the most hardcore meat eater.
name: Ultra-Creamy Spinach and Mushroom Lasagna Recipe
keywords: Italian, lasagna, mushrooms, pasta, spinach, The Food Lab
recipeIngredient: 8 tablespoons (1 stick) unsalted butter, plus more for greasing baking dish, divided
2 pounds washed fresh spinach leaves, roughly chopped
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1/2 cup chopped fresh parsley leaves, divided
24 ounces button, cremini, or shiitake mushrooms, stems removed, finely chopped (see note)
12 ounces whole milk mozzarella, grated, divided

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust an oven rack to the upper-middle position and preheat oven to 400°F (200°C). Melt 3 tablespoons butter in a large saucepan over medium-high heat until foaming subsides. Add garlic and cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add spinach in batches, allowing previous batch to wilt before adding next. Once all spinach is added, add 1 cup heavy cream. Bring to a boil, and reduce to a strong simmer. Cook, stirring frequently, until thick and reduced, about 15 minutes. Add nutmeg, and season to taste with salt and pepper.

While spinach is cooking, combine cottage cheese, egg, and 6 tablespoons parsley in the bowl of a food processor. Process until combined and cottage cheese is broken up to the texture of ricotta cheese, about 5 seconds.

Combine cooked spinach and cottage cheese mixture in a large bowl. Meanwhile, place lasagna noodles in a 8- by 13-inch baking dish and cover with warm water. Allow to soak, agitating occasionally to prevent sticking, until lightly softened, about 15 minutes. Transfer in a single layer to a clean kitchen towel to dry.

While noodles soak, wipe out spinach pot and return to medium-high heat. Add 3 more tablepsoons butter and heat until melted. Add mushrooms and cook, stirring occasionally, until liquid evaporates and mushrooms start to sizzle, about 10 minutes. Add shallots and thyme and cook, stirring frequently, until fragrant and softened, about 2 minutes. Add soy sauce and lemon juice and stir to combine. Add remaining heavy cream. Bring to a simmer, and cook until lightly thickened, about 3 minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Transfer mixture to another bowl.

Wipe out pot and return to medium-high heat. Add remaining 2 tablespoons butter and heat until melted. Add flour and cook, stirring constantly with a whisk, until light golden blond. Slowly pour in milk, whisking constantly. Bring to a simmer, then remove from heat. Stir in 2/3 of mozzarella and Parmesan, then season to taste with salt and pepper.

To assemble lasagna, dry the 8- by 13-inch baking dish and grease with butter. Add 1 cup cheese sauce to bottom of dish. Lay three sheets of noodle on top of it, spacing them evenly across the bottom of the dish (there will be about 1/4-inch gap between each sheet of noodle and the edge of the pan. This is fine). Top noodle evenly with half of mushroom mixture, then top with another three sheets. Top with half of spinach/cottage cheese mixture, then top with another three sheets of noodle. Repeat layers with remaining mushroom mixture, spinach mixture, and noodle, ending with a layer of noodle. Pour remaining cheese sauce over top and spread evenly. Sprinkle remaining 1/3 of grated mozzarella evenly over top.

Bake until lasagna is bubbling around the edges, about 20 minutes. Switch broiler on and broil until top is lightly browned, about 5 minutes longer (if you have an under-oven broiler, you'll have to transfer it to the broiler after baking). Let cool for 10 minutes, then slice and serve, garnish with chopped parsley.

review.reviewBody: Sounds amazing! But I cannot justify 2 cups of cream and a stick of butter in lasagna for a regular dinner ... maybe for a special occasion one of these days.
Why not ricotta? Wouldn't you get better flavor?

1. this is absolutely delicious
2. My only complaint is the active time estimate, I think it easily took me double that
3. next time I might go with frozen spinach just to make life easier.
It may be a silly question, but how many layers of noodles am I using? Is it 4 or 5 layers of three noodles each? I count 4 from the instructions, but the ingredients call for 15 sheets. Thank you.
After 20 minutes in preheated oven at 200c my lasagna registered only 35c internal temp. Why is the recipe baking time so short?

headline: Ultimate Sriracha Burger Recipe | Cook the Book
description: The Ultimate Sriracha Burger from The Sriracha Cookbook begins with a grilled patty infused with Sriracha and soy, and is topped with a towering pile of bacon caramelized onions, Swiss cheese, tomato, arugula, bacon, and an improbably delicious blue cheese-Sriracha dressing.
name: Ultimate Sriracha Burger Recipe | Cook the Book
keywords: beef, Cook the Book, Randy Clemens, sandwich, Sriracha, The Sriracha Cookbook

recipeInstructions.text: In a large mixing bowl, combine the ground beef, soy sauce, 5 tablespoons of the Sriracha, and the pepper. Do not overmix. Form the mixture into 8 patties, and set aside, on a parchment-lined baking sheet, covered, in the refrigerator.
Preheat a charcoal or gas grill to medium high heat.

In a medium frying pan over medium-low heat, cook the bacon, turning as necessary. While the bacon is cooking, peel and quarter the onions. Cut each section into 1/4-inch slices. Once the bacon is cooked through and slightly crispy, remove the slices from the pan, cut each in half crosswise, and drain onto paper towels, reserving the remaining bacon fat in the pan. Cook the sliced onions in the bacon fat over medium-low heat until they caramelize, 20 to 25 minutes.
Grill the burgers, turning once, 4 to 4 1/2 minutes on each side or until a meat thermometer registers 130° to 135°F for medium-rare.
While the burgers are cooking, in a small bowl, combine the blue cheese dressing with the remaining 5 tablespoons Sriracha. Lightly toast the buns on the grill during the last minute of cooking time.

To assemble, spread the blue cheese mixture on both halves of each hamburger bun. Stack a burger patty, Swiss cheese slice, bacon, caramelized onions, tomato slice, and a small handful of arugula between each hamburger bun.

review.reviewBody: Made this today for Memorial Day. Soooooo good.
I'm trying to turn this into a chili recipe for our chili cook off this week at work....

There are a few brands of sriracha that not only taste significantly different from others, but also have different textures and heat levels. The recipe should say which brand they are using in order to give an idea to the reader.

Personally, I don't need the advice, but it may prevent the more amateur cook from over-sriracha-ing their burgers and ruining the recipe for them.

I just made this burger...actually made the exact recipe with half the beef (misread the beef and didn't notice until I had everything mixed up)...and I think it's the best kitchen accident I've had in a long long while :) Being mexicans, we like strong flavours, so doubling the sauces ended up being a good idea...I transported the mod'ed recipe to my recipe book...never thought about using sriracha in a burger...excellent idea!
Is this the perfect burger?

headline: The Ultimate Poutine Recipe
description: A perfect poutine is a trifecta of the best of its three ingredients—fries with a crisp exterior and soft interior, fresh and soft squeaky cheese curds, and a beefy brown gravy that's just flavorful enough without overwhelming the fries or curds. Getting each piece of the puzzle together for an ultimate version like this takes some time, but once complete, the reward is so good you'll go gaga even if you're totally sober.
name: The Ultimate Poutine Recipe
keywords: cheese, gravy, potato, poutine
recipeIngredient: 1 pound chicken necks, backs, or legs
4 medium cloves garlic, smashed and peeled
1 quart homemade chicken stock or low-sodium broth
4 large skin-on russet potatoes (about 2 pounds), cut into 1/4-inch sticks on a mandoline
12 ounces freshly made white cheddar cheese curds (preferably not more than 24 hours old), either store-bought or homemade , at room temperature and broken into bite-size pieces

recipeInstructions.text: For the Gravy: Melt butter in a medium saucepan over medium-high heat until foaming. Whisk in flour and cook, stirring constantly, until golden blonde, about 2 minutes. In a steady stream, gradually whisk in stock. Bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and cook until reduced to 2 cups, 10 to 15 minutes. Remove from heat, stir in vinegar, and season with salt.

For the Fries: Place potatoes in a large bowl and cover completely with cold water. Let soak for at least 1 hour, or, alternatively, drain water and rinse again, changing water until it runs completely clear. Drain potatoes and dry thoroughly with paper towels.

Heat oil in a large Dutch oven or wok to 350°F (177°C). Working in batches, add potatoes and cook, stirring and turning frequently until pale blonde, about 5 minutes. Transfer potatoes to a paper towel-lined baking sheet. (For crispiest fries, see note about adding a freezing step.)
Heat oil to 425°F (218°C). Add potatoes and cook, stirring and turning frequently, until deep golden brown, about 3 minutes. Transfer to paper towel-lined bowl and season with salt to taste.
Reheat gravy over high heat until hot. Place fries in a shallow bowl or dish, top generously with cheese curds, and ladle on gravy. Sprinkle with minced chives (optional). Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody:
@shannikinz I live in SF, cheese curds are pretty easy to get even in Sac. Check out Spring Hill Cheese http://www.springhillcheese.com/ They're based out of Petaluma, and they make fantastic Cheese Curds. They're always at local Farmers Markets throughout the Bay and they sell online. You should be able to find any of their stuff in specialty markets or cheese stores in Sac. 

Also, http://sacramento.cbslocal.com/top-lists/best-cheese-shops-in-sacramento/
I love that our delicious "heart attack on a plate" is making it's way further and further throughout North America. :D

Im sure its good, but the cost of making it would be pretty costly, since Oxtails arent cheap and getting bones arent cheap like they used to be.
Be like a $20 plate of Poutine.
Queso Fresco works quite well if curds aren’t readily available.
When you go by the recipe it doesn't tell you to add celery when your cooking the carrots onions and garlic, but it does on the main page. Don't forget like me (:

headline: The Ultimate Homemade McRib (Smoked Rib Sandwich)
description: A step-by-step guide to making McDonald's McRib, the rarely available pork-and-barbecue-sauce sandwich with a cult-like following.
name: The Ultimate Homemade McRib (Smoked Rib Sandwich)
keywords: mcrib, mcdonald mcrib, mcdonalds mcrib, mcrib recipe
recipeIngredient: 1 recipe Easy All-Purpose Barbecue Sauce and Rub (see note)
1 1/2 pounds (700g) boneless pork shoulder, cut into 1-inch cubes

recipeInstructions.text: For Smoking the Ribs: Place ribs, bone side up, on a cutting board. Using paper towels to grip, pull the transparent membrane off the bones. It should come off easily in one large strip (see photo for reference). Rub ribs generously on all surfaces with barbecue rub, then split them into 4- to 5-rib sections with a sharp chef's knife or boning knife. Transfer to a covered container and refrigerate for at least 4 hours and up to overnight.
Meanwhile, in a large bowl, combine pork shoulder, salt, and sugar and toss to coat. Transfer to a zipper-lock bag and refrigerate for at least 4 hours or up to overnight.

Open bottom vent of a charcoal grill completely. Light large charcoal chimney starter filled 1/3 of the way with charcoal briquettes (about 2 quarts). When top coals are partially covered with ash, pour evenly over half of the bottom grill grate. Place a few wood chunks directly on top of charcoal. Set cooking grate in place, cover, and open lid vent completely. Heat until 275°F (135℃), about 5 minutes. Clean and oil cooking grate then arrange ribs, bone side down, on cooler side of grill. Cover, with vents over ribs. Smoke, covered, adjusting vents as needed and adding more coals as needed to maintain a grill temperature between 225°F to 275°F (105℃ to 135℃), and adding a wood chunk every 45 minutes, until ribs show a gentle bend when you lift them and show only slight resistance when a toothpick is inserted between the bones and an instant read thermometer inserted in thickest portion registers between 190°F to 200°F, 4 to 5 hours.

Brush tops and sides of ribs with barbecue sauce, cover, and continue smoking for 10 minutes. Repeat process 2 more times (about ½ cup sauce total), then transfer to a cutting board. Let cool slightly, about 15 minutes.

For Making the McRib Patties: Once cool enough to handle, twist bones out of ribs and discard bones. Roughly chop the meat. Spread on a large plate in a single layer and refrigerate until thoroughly chilled, about 2 hours.

In a food processor, pulse 1/4 of the chilled rib meat with ¼ of the pork shoulder until roughly ground, about 12 pulses. Transfer to a large bowl and repeat the pulsing process with the rib meat and shoulder meat in 3 batches, keeping the meat refrigerated until ready to pulse. Toss the pulsed meat together with hands to evenly mix.

Set a double layer of parchment paper measuring 9-by 18-inches on work surface. Transfer meat mixture to the center of parchment paper. Cover mixture with parchment paper, then, using your hands over the parchment, spread mixture out to form a 9- by 18-inch rectangle.

Using a sharp chef's knife and cutting through the parchment paper, cut the large rectangle into 8 individual patties measuring 4 1/2 by 4 1/2 inches each. Slide the patties with the parchment to a rimmed baking sheet and refrigerate until ready to use. (Patties can be stacked with their parchment paper intact and stored in the refrigerator for up to 3 days, or in a freezer bag in the freezer for several months. If freezing, cook directly from frozen.)

Open bottom vent of charcoal grill completely. Light large charcoal chimney starter filled with charcoal briquettes (6 quarts). When top coals are partially covered with ash, pour evenly over bottom grill grate. Set cooking grate in place, cover, and open lid vent completely. Heat grill until hot, about 500°F (260℃), about 5 minutes. Cover and allow to preheat for 5 minutes.

Clean and oil cooking grate. Transfer prepared patties to grill and sprinkle with remaining spice rub. Cook, flipping once halfway through, until well charred, about 2 minutes per side. Brush patties with barbecue sauce (about 1 cup sauce total), cover, and cook until patties are cooked through and barbecue sauce forms a lacquered glaze, 1 to 2 minutes. remove from grill and transfer to plate. Toast cut sides on grill until golden brown, 1 to 2 minutes.
For Assembling the Sandwiches: Place one patty on each bun bottom. Brush with remaining sauce, and top with pickles, onion, and bun top. Serve.

review.reviewBody:
Man, Kenji, I don't want to bitch, but every time I turn in to one of your recipes, it either has 3-dozen ingredients (including something like Chinese rice wine, west of the Yangtze, 1978, before the rains, but only a half tsp and it will go back in to the pantry and forever forgotten). Or, they are like this one where you start out w/ 5-1/2 lbs of pork. A bit excess for a couple living together. 

I'm not ripping you up, but damn, there needs to be a medium ground between McD's and a weekend worth of work, y'know?

Kenji - I have to say that this is one of the most fabulous projects I've ever undertaken (and I've made the sous-vide-deep-fried-all-belly-porcetta)...

First, I have a laundry list of food intolerances I've discovered through years of trial and error (mostly error), so the only way I can eat BBQ of any kind is if I make it myself. Second, I am one of THOSE parents who will never, ever, ever, not ever take my kid to McDonald's, which means some of the food memories I treasure, I can't experience with said offspring unless it comes directly from my kitchen. I absolutely have to eat a certain way if I want to be able to function and that means any form of purchased junk food is 100% off the list. Third, I LOVE these super-involved, time-intensive, labors of love, especially for football food! The Vikes are playing at home for the official season opener, so that means junk-food-football-food! Away games are tailored to regional specialties. 

Using this magnificent piece as a template, I was able to create a garlic-free, tomato-free, paprika-free, capsicum-free, gluten-free representation of a "junk" fast food item that would have otherwise been unattainable. 

I started by rubbing the ribs last Tuesday with my own rub that was riffed off your all-purpose rub, getting them into their water bath on Thursday. After a 36 hour soak, they chilled until I was ready to smoke on Saturday with heavy amounts of hickory smoke. The pork shoulder was also cubed and salted then. On Sunday, I ground and formed the meat mixture and made my BBQ sauce (which starts with making Stella's cherry reduction from her BraveTart site to get super dry pureed cherries as a stand-in for tomato paste) using the Balsamic BBQ sauce on here as a rough template. I always have a batch of the dilly refrigerator pickles available, so I didn't need to do anything else with those. Sadly, as I've never been able to create a not gross gluten-free bun that actually holds up under a decent level of fillings, the short-cut store-bought version had to be subbed in here.

So good! So, so, so freaking good!!! Worth the work, worth the wait. I was nearly at stalker-level-fan-girl before....now my love for you (in an "I know you don't know me but because internet I can think and pretend I know you kind of way") and all you've done to expand my cooking skills is way over the top. Thank you seems under-serving for my level of appreciation.

I have to ask about cheating. What if I wanted to get my smoked ribs from a good barbecue place? How much post-cooked, bone-in weight are we talking about? Because let's be real--this sounds great, but I'm never gonna spend hours cooking a whole dish just to chop it up and mix it into another dish.

It seems like you've basically made a grilled sausage with a mix of shoulder and pre-smoked rib meat. It seems like you could get a long way there by 'just' making the pork shoulder sausages (with the rub, and maybe some of your bbq sauce, mixed in), smoking them, and then finishing on the grill.
this one is truly for the diehard cooking hobbyists. a half a day for something that will be inhaled in under 5 minutes? not for the faint of heart!

headline: Planked Figs With Pancetta and Goat Cheese Recipe
description: Sweet figs plus salty meat make for an automatic win, but little additions in this recipe like goat cheese, honey, and grilling on a plank make these pancetta-wrapped figs something special.
name: Planked Figs With Pancetta and Goat Cheese Recipe
keywords: figs, goat cheese, pancetta, quick
recipeIngredient: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
4 ounces pancetta, sliced thin and cut into 1/2-inch strips lengthwise
2 cedar planks, soaked for 1 hour prior to use

recipeInstructions.text: Place figs, cut side up, on a plate. Drizzle with Grand Marnier and season heavily with pepper and lightly with salt. Let sit for 15 minutes. Wrap each fig with one strip of pancetta; secure with toothpick.
Dice remaining pancetta. Place pancetta in medium skillet over medium-high heat. Cook pancetta until crisp, 7-10 minutes. Transfer pancetta to paper towel lined plate. Set aside.

Light one chimney full of charcoal. When all the charcoal is lit and covered with gray ash, pour out and arrange the coals on one side of the charcoal grate. Set cooking grate in place, cover grill and allow to preheat for 5 minutes. Place planks over hot side of the grill until they start to char and smoke. Flip planks over and move to cool side of grill and arrange figs on top. Sprinkle figs with goats cheese and crisped pancetta. Cover grill and cook until figs soften and uncooked pancetta browns, about 15 minutes.
Remove planks from grill. Drizzle figs with honey. Let cool for 5 minutes, then serve.

review.reviewBody: This dish is not vegetarian. Please take it out of the Vegetarian/Vegan section.

headline: Gluten-Free Cheesy Broccoli Soup Recipe
description: The secret ingredient to this gluten-free cheesy broccoli soup? Velveeta.
name: Gluten-Free Cheesy Broccoli Soup Recipe
keywords: broccoli, cheddar, gluten free, soup
recipeIngredient: 1 clove garlic, minced or put through a garlic press
4 cups homemade chicken stock or store-bought gluten-free reduced-sodium broth
1 large carrot (2 ounces), peeled and grated
8 ounces Velveeta, cut into small cubes (see note)

recipeInstructions.text: In a large pot, melt the butter over medium-high heat. Add the onion and cook, stirring frequently with a wooden spoon, until translucent and soft, about 2 minutes. Add the garlic and cook for 1 minute. Continue to stir frequently. Add the mustard and stir to combine.

Stir in the sweet rice flour until a paste forms. Cook, stirring constantly, until the paste is a light golden brown, about 4 minutes. Whisk in the chicken stock in a slow and steady steam. Whisk in the milk. Bring to a boil, reduce to a bare simmer, then add the broccoli, carrot, hot pepper sauce, and black pepper. Simmer (look for occasional gentle bubbles) for 30 minutes.

Using a slotted spoon, transfer the broccoli from the soup to a blender or food processor. Add a generous splash of soup, about 1/2 cup. (Don’t fill the blender more than halfway. Work in batches if you have a small blender.) Blend until the broccoli is almost smooth but not a paste.

Return the broccoli to the soup. Stir to combine. Add the Velveeta. Using a wooden spoon, stir until the Velveeta is melted (see note). Season to taste with salt and simmer for 5 minutes. Serve. Store leftover soup in a covered container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days.

review.reviewBody: I'm not gluten free but this did not taste like panera at all! It was super bland even with the hot pepper sauce. Really disappointing, try "Almost famous broccoli chedder" on food network for soup that's closer to the mark and super delicious.

So I made this and it got great reviews. Variations: I used wheat flour and fresh broccoli instead of mochiko and frozen. I'll make it again. If for no other reason, I've still got the other half pound of Velveeta. ;-)
(my rating didn't show up) YUM!

Oh how I miss a good broccoli cheese soup, THANK YOU! It's great that you offer up cheddar if folks aren't into Velveeta -- not *the* healthiest option, but my sister makes a dip with it and people rave about it and always ask for the recipe! (and sometimes when you are gluten-free, you just want "regular" stuff, just like everyone else!) Also, my grandma's recipe for broccoli-cauliflower soup uses Velveeta -- maybe Panera got the recipe from her?! 

I'm guessing @jim554 doesn't have to eat gluten free for a living -- if he did, he'd know that "idiots" put gluten in all kinds of hidden sources every single day... probably the same type of people that start off a recipe review with "this is dumb."

headline: Hearty Winter Vegetable Soup
description: A quick and hearty vegetable soup with carrots, potatoes, leeks, and kale. 100% plant-based, 100% satisfying.
name: Hearty Winter Vegetable Soup
keywords: kale, potatoes, quick, soup, vegetable soup
recipeIngredient: 1 recipe Hearty Vegetable Stock , along with re-hydrated mushrooms from the stock
2 leeks, white parts only, split in half lengthwise, cut into 1/4-inch slices
1 cup cooked chickpeas, rinsed and drained (or any other cooked canned bean)
1 small bunch kale, thick stems removed, leaves roughly torn
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 tablespoon cornstarch mixed with 1 tablespoon water
1 to 2 tablespoons fresh juice from 1 lemon

recipeInstructions.text: Chop reserved re-hydrated mushrooms kept from making hearty vegetable stock into half-inch pieces. Add mushrooms, broth, leeks, carrot, celery, potato, chickpeas, kale, and soy sauce to a large saucepan. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat, reduce to a simmer, and cook, stirring occasionally, until potatoes are completely tender and beginning to fall apart, about 25 minutes. Stir in cornstarch slurry and allow to simmer 2 minutes longer.
Season to taste with salt and pepper, stir in lemon juice and parsley, and serve, drizzling extra-virgin olive oil into bowls as you eat.

review.reviewBody: How can I get access to the original recipe before the 2019 update? I loved that other recipe!

Kenji, how much of the vegetable stock is used for the soup? I do not have the time to make the homemade stock and am using store-bought vegetable stock instead.

Thanks.
Two stalks of celery? Should that be ribs?
Sweet potatoes are also excellent at thickening a soup and giving a rich mouthfeel. They mostly dissolve totally, but add a lot.

@Jbout

They are spent, just like with any stock. I mix them in with my dog food (except for the onions).

headline: Hearty White Bean and Spinach Soup with Rosemary and Garlic Recipe
description: White beans in a garlicky rosemary broth with wilted spinach make for a quick and easy, balanced, and delicious 30-minute meal in a bowl.
name: Hearty White Bean and Spinach Soup with Rosemary and Garlic Recipe
keywords: soup, spinach, white beans
recipeIngredient: 1 (15 ounce) can white beans, drained and rinsed
1 bunch spinach (about 4 ounces), trimmed and washed
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Heat 2 tablespoons oil in a medium saucepan over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add onions, celery, garlic, and rosemary. Cook, stirring frequently, until onions and garlic are softened but not browned, about 4 minutes. Add broth, bay leaves and beans. Bring to a boil, reduce to a bare simmer and cook for 10 minutes. Add spinach and continue cooking until completely wilted, about 5 minutes longer. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Stir in lemon juice. Serve immediately, drizzling remaining olive oil over bowls.

review.reviewBody: My family loved this recipe - only changes to recipe was we added an extra can of beans and also more spinach. It's a keeper!

For such simple ingredients, this soup was ridiculously good. Seriously, it had no business being this delicious. I made it as-written, but feels like it could be endlessly riff-able. Thank you so much for this little gem.

A great way to trick my family into being vegan one night a week! 
Also, a great base to work in a ton of other flavors.

Flavorful and yummy. Husband loved it too.

Ps, cut the spinach in half or quarters if the leaves are 2" or more.

This is a good, simple weeknight soup (and I'm sure makes for a great base for other add-ins). I started with less lemon as I was a-scared, but ended up using most, if not all of it. Admittedly, I did add a piece of parmesan rind which un-vegan-ed it. Will make again. Thanks!

headline: The Best BLT Sandwich
description: The secret to the best bacon, lettuce, and tomato? Use the best tomatoes. Put away the fancy bread. Slow-cook the bacon. And most importantly: Don't mess with it.
name: The Best BLT Sandwich
keywords: blt, essential, lettuce, sandwich, tomato
recipeIngredient: 3 strips thick-cut, naturally cured bacon (see note)
2 slices high-quality sandwich bread, such as shokupan
2 tablespoons (30ml) homemade or store-bought mayonnaise (see note)
1 1/2 cups finely shredded iceberg lettuce (see note)
Coarse sea salt, such as fleur de sel or Maldon

recipeInstructions.text: Place a griddle or skillet over medium-low heat. Add bacon and place a bacon press, skillet, or masonry trowel on top of it to keep it flat as it cooks. Cook until lightly browned on first side, about 5 minutes, then flip, cover again, and continue cooking until bacon is browned on both sides and fat has rendered, about 3 minutes longer. Transfer bacon to a paper towel–lined plate and set aside.
Place bread on same skillet or griddle and toast in bacon fat over medium-low heat, swirling occasionally, until evenly browned on first side. Flip and brown second side.

Lay toasted bread on a work surface and spread mayonnaise on both top faces. Divide lettuce evenly between both pieces of bread. Layer tomato slices on 1 piece of bread and sprinkle generously with coarse salt and freshly ground pepper.

Break bacon slices in half and layer them onto the sandwich in 2 layers of 3 half slices each, alternating the orientation of bacon in each layer for more structural stability. Close sandwich and cut in half diagonally. Serve immediately.

review.reviewBody: I agree with almost everything in this recipe, but this year I hit upon another “rule” this is omitted here: Slice your excellent tomato thick, and use a single layer of this thick slice. With a really exceptional Brandywine or similar, you can get a single thick slice (say 3/4 inch) to cover the entire sandwich. For years I have used a layer of thinner tomato slices, as in the photo, but I have finally come to realize that as the joy of the BLT is showcasing this star, the most luxurious way to do so is with a steak like slab of wonderfulness.

On the slab theme: buy a head of iceberg lettuce (cheaper than a bag anyway), and slice center slabs of it to lay on your salted tomato slab. It's a more integrated lettuce structure than loose shredded, and fresher, and cheaper. The resulting 'cross section' orientation gets maximum mayo/tomato/grease absorption, and you bite into it vertically as well, which matters. It really is The Best Sandwich

The shredded lettuce as well as the order items is essential to not have the tomatoes slide out as you take a bite. Shredding the lettuce has been a game changer for sandwiches that have slippery components i.e. leaves of lettuce/tomatoes/mayo/avocado etc.... You can tell this is the product of a former MIT student. I agree with 99 44/100ths of what is written.
What an enjoyable and well written article . I enjoyed it for the writing alone !

I love a Club House sandwich which is constructed like a BLT but with added chicken, cheese, onion and what have you. To me the tomatoes are not down graded with the other flavours, they still are the central focus. I also have a little trick I use in cooking the bacon. I like to form a lattice with the cut to size bacon strips, so that they fry as one sandwich sized piece. I do this to make the construction of the sandwich easier (no bacon strips sliding out).

headline: Peanut Butter Sesame Breakfast Bars Recipe
description: These soft peanut butter bars get a flavor boost from toasted sesame seeds and a crunch from puffed cereal.
name: Peanut Butter Sesame Breakfast Bars Recipe
keywords: breakfast bars, sesame
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup puffed rice cereal, such as Kashi

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat oven to 350°F. Place sesame seeds in a small saucepan over medium heat. Saute until toasted and golden, about 2 minutes. Let cool.
In a medium bowl, stir together honey, egg, vanilla extract, and peanut butter until evenly combined. Stir in sesame seeds and rice cereal.
Spread mixture in baking dish. Bake until golden, about 25 minutes. Let bars cool completely before cutting.

review.reviewBody: This sounds delicious. I'll substitute the egg for something more vegan but ultimately this is a perfect breakfast bar for me or my daughter in the morning.

headline: The Ultimate Beef Stroganoff Recipe
description: In our version of beef Stroganoff, the beef is cooked as a whole steak to maintain a more tender, medium-rare center, while the sauce is carefully layered to optimize its flavor.
name: The Ultimate Beef Stroganoff Recipe
keywords: beef, beef stroganoff, comfort, pasta, sour cream, winter
recipeIngredient: 2 (.25 ounce) packets unflavored powdered gelatin (about 5 teaspoons)
2 cups homemade or store-bought low-sodium chicken stock
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
4 (1 1/2- to 2-inch thick) beef tenderloin steaks, 6 to 8 ounces each (see note)
8 ounces peeled pearl onions (about 24 onions, see note)
1 cup sour cream, plus more for serving

recipeInstructions.text: Sprinkle gelatin over chicken stock in a small bowl or liquid measuring cup. Set aside. Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil.

Combine 1 tablespoon salt, 1 teaspoon pepper, and half of paprika in a small bowl. Season steaks generously on all sides with mixture (you may not need all the mixture) and press with the flat of your hand to adhere. Heat half of vegetable oil in a large skillet or sauté pan over high heat until lightly smoking. Add meat and cook, turning occasionally, until well-browned on both sides and center of steaks register 115°F (46°C) at the thickest part for rare or 125°F (52°C) for medium-rare. Remove from pan, transfer to a plate, and set aside.

Add remaining vegetable oil to the same pan and add the mushrooms. Return to medium heat and cook, stirring and tossing frequently, until mushrooms have released their liquid and are just starting to brown, about 8 minutes. Add 1 tablespoon butter and pearl onions and continue to cook, stirring, until onions and mushrooms are softened and well-browned, about 6 minutes longer.

Add shallots, thyme, and remaining paprika, and cook, stirring, until fragrant. Add soy sauce, Worcestershire sauce, fish sauce, and mustard and cook, stirring, until mostly evaporated, about 30 seconds. Add any collected juices from the plate with the meat, followed by white wine. Cook until reduced to just a few tablespoons.

Add broth/gelatin mixture and bring to a heavy simmer. Carefully pour off liquid into a heatproof cup or liquid measuring cup. Add sour cream to a medium bowl. Whisking constantly, slowly pour hot liquid over sour cream and whisk until fully homogeneous.

Return sour cream mixture to pan along with remaining 2 tablespoons butter. Bring to a boil over medium-high heat and season to taste with salt and pepper. Return steaks to pan until barely warmed through, about 1 minute. Remove from heat.

Cook noodles according to package directions. When cooked, drain and return to pot, reserving 1 cup of pasta cooking water. Transfer steaks to a cutting board and pour the sauce, mushrooms, and onions over the noodles. Stir to coat pasta, adding pasta cooking water as necessary until it reaches a loose, creamy consistency. Stir in half of minced parsley.

Thinly slice steaks. To serve, divide pasta and cream sauce evenly between 4 hot serving bowls. Top with sliced steak, spooning a little extra sauce over them. Add a dollop of sour cream, sprinkle with remaining parsley, and serve, advising guests to remove large thyme sprigs as they find them.

review.reviewBody:
Beef stroganoff has been a favorite dish of mine since childhood and my mom strove for the gourmet restaurant version rather than the hamburger helper version. This recipe is truly one of the best. 

I used a tenderloin cooked to 135 sous vide then just quickly seared on all sides. You can avoid having your sauce come out too thin or too skimpy by cooking the mushrooms until ALL their juices evaporate, cooking the umami concoction until completely evaporated, reducing the wine until it is mostly gone then using a little judgement about how much to reduce the chicken stock mixture and how much pasta water to use at the end, if any. It really makes a generous amount of silky, flavorful sauce for any reasonable amount of noodles for 4 servings (again, you might need to use some judgement).

I followed the recipe exactly because I absolutely trust Kenji and it did take me more like an hour and a half but it should go faster next time now that I am familiar with the recipe.
Try with a good red wine instead of white. Amazing flavors.
If Kenji makes ice cream I am sure he puts fish sauce in it. WTF?

I typically avoid using clichés, but OMG! I doubled this recipe, per my usual M.O. When I learned to cook, my volume guidelines were predicated on feeding 8 hungry people. My husband likes leftovers, so this works for him. I hit it out of the park with this endeavor. After the second night I froze individual portions. My husband requested and devoured beef stroganoff eight consecutive nights and was visibly disappointed when it was no longer a dinnertime option. I followed the recipe more closely than usual. I did use a less tender cut of meat, jaccarded and sliced it. I made a dry rub of the salt, pepper and smoked paprika and braised it while a prepped the other ingredients. The layers of flavor created a sophisticated and addictive blend. I made this recipe about six months ago and my husband requested it for his birthday dinner this Wednesday. I plan on tripling the recipe this time around. Kudos to the person who perfected the Ultimate Beef Stroganoff.

Okay what am I missing here....I've made this twice because it is so promising and have followed the recipe To. The. Letter. 

The result is intensely disappointing. The pasta drinks up ALL the sauce and I'm basically left with marinated, fairly dry, and fairly flavorless pile of noodles with a steak on it...

headline: Beet Salad with Black Garlic Vinaigrette Recipe
description: [Photograph: Max Falkowitz] Even raw, beets are a wonderfully sweet vegetable. Sweet and funky black garlic bridges the gap between them and a very lime-based vinaigrette. Blending the black garlic into the dressing makes it, well, ugly, but lets the...
name: Beet Salad with Black Garlic Vinaigrette Recipe
keywords: beets, black garlic, salads, Spice Hunting
recipeIngredient: 1 pound beets (about 3 medium), peeled and sliced into 1/8th-inch julienne on a mandoline or V-slicer
1/2 cup roughly chopped parsley or cilantro
1 tablespoon coriander seed, toasted and ground

recipeInstructions.text: Toss beets and parsley in large bowl. Combine black garlic, lime juice, olive oil, and coriander in blender and blend until smooth. Season to taste with salt and sugar (start with 1 teaspoon sugar and add more totaste). Toss beets with vinaigrette and serve immediately.

headline: The Ultimate Bacon Cheeseburgers Recipe
description: The ultimate bacon cheeseburger with beef cooked in bacon fat, a bacon fat mayonnaise, onions caramelized in bacon fat, buns toasted in bacon fat, and a crisp bacon weave topping.

video.description: Discover the mouthwatering delight of the Ultimate Bacon Cheeseburger with our easy-to-follow recipe video. Elevate your burger game to perfection with layers of savory, juicy beef, crispy bacon, and gooey melted cheese, all perfectly nestled between toasted buns. Crafted with the finest ingredients and expert techniques, this recipe guarantees a burger experience that is both decadent and irresistible, satisfying your cravings for the perfect classic bacon cheeseburger.
video.name: The Ultimate Bacon Cheeseburger Recipe

name: The Ultimate Bacon Cheeseburgers Recipe
keywords: beef, burger, cheeseburgers, sandwich, The Burger Lab, The Food Lab
recipeIngredient: 1 tablespoon spicy brown or dijon mustard
24 ounces (1 1/2 pounds) freshly ground beef chuck

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven rack to center and bottom positions, place a 12-inch cast iron skillet on the bottom rack, and preheat oven to 400°F (200°C).

Meanwhile, line a rimmed baking sheet with heavy duty aluminum foil. Place 6 slices of bacon on baking sheet side to side running perpendicular to the edge of the counter. Fold down the top halves of 1st, 3rd, and 5th slices. Place a slice of bacon across the top of the folds, running perpendicular to the first 6 slices, then unfold the bacon so that the new slice is woven over and under every other slice. Fold down the 2nd, 4th, and 6th slices and lay another slice of bacon across the top of the fold. Unfold the slices. Repeat until all 12 slices of bacon have been laid on the baking sheet in an interwoven pattern. Place baking sheet in oven and cook until bacon is crisp, about 25 minutes.

While bacon cooks, combine mayonnaise, ketchup, mustard, relish, and 1 teaspoon black pepper in a medium bowl. Stir to combine. Form ground beef into 4 (6-ounce) patties slightly wider than the buns. Press the center of each patty to make a slight indentation with your fingertips. Season liberally with salt and pepper on all sides. Set aside.

When bacon is cooked, remove baking sheet from oven and set broiler to high. Pour off excess bacon fat into a small bowl and set aside. Transfer bacon to a paper towel-lined plate, being careful not to break it. Allow to drain for 30 seconds, then transfer to cutting board. Cut the bacon weave into 4 smaller squares and set aside.

Pour 2 tablespoons of rendered bacon fat into mayonnaise mixture and stir to combine. Brush hamburger rolls on inside surfaces with bacon fat and place on a broiler pan or baking sheet brushed-side up.

Remove cast iron skillet from oven using oven mitts or a folded kitchen towel. Place over medium-high heat. Add remaining bacon fat to skillet. Add burger patties and cook, turning occasionally, until well-crusted and center of each burger registers 120°F (49°C) on an instant-read thermometer. Top with cheese and continue cooking until cheese is melted and burgers register 125°F (52°C) for medium rare or 135°F (57°C) for medium. Transfer to a large plate.
Add onions to skillet and cook, stirring frequently, until softened and lightly browned, about 5 minutes. Season to taste with salt and pepper and transfer to a bowl.
Place burger buns under broiler while onions cook and broil until golden brown and toasted, about 2 minutes.
Spread mayonnaise mixture on both sides of burger buns. Place 3 pickles on each bottom bun. Top with a burger patty, a pile of onions, and a square of bacon weave. Close buns and serve.

review.reviewBody: Sweet relish is a vulgar abomination.
The only thing, in my opinion, that could make that mayonnaise mixture better is diced jalapenos, rather than relish. Get some!
Our go-to burger recipe that we just have to have at least once a month. Would not change one single thing. Thanks so much Kenji, you just might be my spirit animal :)

@Helldog, @Glanton, agree that sweet relish is pretty abominable. But years ago I adapted an Emeril sweet pickle recipe to be less sweet, and added a lot of fresh sliced jalapenos. Fire and Ice. Perfect addition for this secret sauce.
Perfect bacon cheeseburger: bacon, cheese, burger & one, count 'em, ONE additional topping. Any more than that proves you are either a beef hater, wannabe vegan, or a combination of both.

headline: Two-Minute Aioli
description: Classic aioli is made with nothing but garlic and olive oil pounded in a mortar and pestle. Our updated version uses egg yolks to help bind the sauce along with a hand blender to make it 100% foolproof and extremely quick.
name: Two-Minute Aioli
keywords: aioli, easy, mayonnaise, quick, sauce
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup canola, vegetable, or light olive oil oil
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Place egg, garlic, and lemon juice in the bottom of an immersion blender cup. Pour canola (or vegetable or light olive) oil on top and allow to settle for 15 seconds. Place head of immersion blender at bottom of cup and switch it on. As aioli forms, slowly tilt and lift the head of the immersion blender until all oil is emulsified. (For food processor instructions, see note).

Transfer aioli to a medium bowl. Whisking constantly, slowly drizzle in extra-virgin olive oil. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Store in a sealed container in the refrigerator for up to two weeks.

review.reviewBody: I could not get this recipe to work when I tried it with a whole egg - it stayed liquidy. I tossed it and started over with egg yolk instead and had great success! Please revise this recipe to reflect that it is egg yolk only! 0 stars as written, 5 stars with the change to yolk

"If you don't have an immersion blender with a cup, you can make the aioli in a food processor. "

It's worth keeping in mind those folks at a website called Serious Eats say this isn't true:

"Through multiple rounds of testing, the phenomenon of bitterness in blended olive oil failed to make itself obvious. I never noticed it, and my blind-tasters failed to describe any clear correlation between blending and increased bitterness. "
https://www.seriouseats.com/2018/06/does-blending-olive-oil-make-it-more-bitter

This resulted in a watery, inedible mess. I tried fixes including adding slowly to fresh room temperature egg yolks . This didn't work. Then I tried a little hot water, this didn't work either. I've been making mayo for 40 years without a problem. I tried this and it's wasted a lot of expensive ingredients. I'm going back to the old method, just yolks and adding oil very, very slowly
Do we use a full egg or just an egg yolk? Headline says "egg yolk," but ingredient list says "whole egg."

I'm not sure why, but this came out bitter and tasting sharply of garlic to me - and I usually love garlic, even when it's so sharp it burns. And I whisked in the olive oil.

I dunno, it just didn't really work for me.

headline: 2-Ingredient Cream Biscuits
description: These two-ingredient biscuits have one of the lowest effort-to-greatness ratios of any recipe I can think of. They take practically no effort or practice to pull off, yet produce some of the lightest, tenderest, tastiest biscuits around.
name: 2-Ingredient Cream Biscuits
keywords: biscuit, bread, breakfast, cream, easy, quick, shortcake, Southern
recipeIngredient: 2 tablespoons sugar (if making sweet shortcake-style biscuits)
10 ounces (about 1 1/4 cups) heavy cream, plus more for brushing

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven rack to center position and preheat oven to 450°F. Place flour in a large bowl. If making sweet biscuits, whisk in sugar. Stirring with a wooden spoon, drizzle in cream. Stir until a lumpy dough is formed. Do not over mix.

For Drop Biscuits: Using a 1-ounce cookie scoop, scoop balls of dough onto a parchment-lined baking sheet, spacing them 2 inches apart. Brush tops with cream and bake until golden brown, about 12 minutes. Let cool slightly and serve.

For Flaky Rolled Biscuits: With a rolling pin, roll the dough into a 12-inch square. Using a bench scraper, fold the right third of the dough over the center, then fold the left third over so you end up with a 12-by-4-inch rectangle. Fold the top third down over the center, then fold the bottom third up so the whole thing is reduced to a 4-inch square. Press the square down and roll it out again into a 12-inch square. Repeat the folding process once more, then roll the dough again into a 12-inch square. Use a 3- to 4-inch biscuit cutter to cut out rounds and transfer to a parchment-lined baking sheet, spaced 2 inches apart. Press together scraps to form additional biscuits. Brush tops with cream and bake until golden brown, about 12 minutes. Let cool slightly and serve.

review.reviewBody: In the text of the article, Kenji suggests the biscuits will be done in 10 minutes at 425F. In the recipe, 450F for 12 to 15 minutes is suggested. Not a big deal for an experienced baker, but a bit vexatious to a newbie.
Used all purpose flour and it was moist and tender. Great recipe, easy to make and remember.
This is an old Southern Living recipe, 1980 Book, page 77. Have used it for years and so easy!

I will have to try this. I make 'traditional' biscuits but I pat them into a rectangle and just cut them into 'squares - no left over dough that way. Most of the time when I make biscuits its for sausage and gravy and they wind up torn into chunks in the bottom of a bowl :)

Great recipe, and nicely presented!
I do have one quibble, though. You are not the only source that does this.
"3/4 teaspoon of kosher salt" is not enough information.
Different brands have nearly 2:1 difference in weight per volume, and that can make or break a biscuit. 
When specifying Kosher Salt, PLEASE either mention the brand, or far better, weigh it in grams!

headline: Grilled Polenta With Marinara, Parmesan, and Basil Recipe
description: Rich and flavorful polenta is grilled and then topped with marinara, basil, and parmesan to give this side dish the hearty feeling of a whole, satisfying meal.
name: Grilled Polenta With Marinara, Parmesan, and Basil Recipe
keywords: Italian, polenta

nutrition.servingSize: serves 4 as a main course or 8 as a side dish

recipeIngredient: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1/4 cup finely sliced fresh basil leaves

recipeInstructions.text: Bring chicken stock to a boil in a medium saucepan over high heat. Slowly whisk in cornmeal. Reduce heat to low and simmer until mixture has thickened, 30 to 45 minutes, stirring occasionally. Stir in 1/2 cup of Parmesan and butter. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Pour polenta into a 10-inch round cake pan and let cool to room temperature. Cover with plastic wrap and place in refrigerator until completely chilled and firm, 2 to 3 hours or up to overnight.

Light one chimney full of charcoal. When all charcoal is lit and covered with gray ash, pour out and spread the coals evenly over entire surface of coal grate. Alternatively, set all burners on a gas grill to medium high heat. Set cooking grate in place, cover grill and allow to preheat for 5 minutes. Clean and oil the grilling grate. Remove polenta from pan and cut into 8 equal slices. Brush slices on both sides with olive oil and place on grill. Cook until polenta browns, about 3 minutes per side.
Transfer polenta to a platter. Top each slice with a dollop of marinara sauce, basil chiffonade, and a sprinkling of parmesan. Serve immediately while warm.

review.reviewBody: @veggie815: been eating leftover polenta my entire life. Just use a cast iron pan on medium high heat with a little olive oil. About 3 mins first side, turn and 2 mins second side will get the job done.
Thanks for the tips!!
@bookgeek221 Thanks for pointing that out, accidentally omission that's now fixed. It's 2 tablespoons unsalted butter.
In the directions it says to add butter but there is no butter in the ingredients. How much butter should we add?
@veggie815 Sure, you can use a grill pan or just a skillet with some oil, either should work fine.

headline: Chicken-Green Bean Yellow Chili Stir-Fry Recipe
description: This quick and easy Thai-style chicken and long bean stir-fry flavored with fish sauce, chilis, and kaffir lime comes together in under fifteen minutes and uses a simmering/reducing technique that packs in the flavor without overwhelming your kitchen with smoke.
name: Chicken-Green Bean Yellow Chili Stir-Fry Recipe
keywords: chicken, green beans, long beans, my thai, quick
recipeIngredient: 4 yellow or red jalapeño or Serrano peppers
3/4 pound chicken breasts or tenderloins, cut against the grain into bite-size pieces
2 large cloves garlic, peeled and minced (about 1 tablespoon)
1 tablespoon fish sauce (more or less to taste)
1/4 cup homemade or store-bought low-sodium chicken stock
1/3 pound long beans or green beans, trimmed and cut crosswise into 1/4-inch pieces
4 to 5 fresh makrut lime leaves, hand-torn into pieces and lightly bruised

recipeInstructions.text: Cut yellow chilies crosswise into 1/2-inch pieces and pound them in a mortar until they're broken up into small chunks, about 1/4-inch in size; set aside. (If you don't have a mortar, place cut-up chilies in a plastic zipper bag, seal bag well and get rid of trapped air, wrap bag with a kitchen towel, then pound on it with a meat tenderizer or something heavy.)

Heat oil in a 10- or 12-inch skillet over medium-high heat. Add chicken, minced garlic, fish sauce, oyster sauce, chicken stock, and sugar. Cook, stirring occasionally, until chicken is almost cooked through, 2 to 3 minutes. Add long beans, crushed chilies, and kaffir lime leaves. Continue to stir-fry until chicken is cooked through and long beans are still crisp and retain their green color, 1 to 2 minutes longer. Season to taste with more fish sauce if desired. Transfer to a serving platter and serve with steamed rice.

review.reviewBody: nobug - Ah, thank you!
Here is a click-able work-around to get to that page, using Bit.ly: Click here for that page.
Got it. Khob Khun Mak Krop.
ravi347 - Failed again. Just go to my site at http://shesimmers.com It's there.
ravi347 - Okay, that didn't work. Let's try again. Go to this page for the recipe.

headline: Tom Collins Recipe
description: Gin, lemon, and soda come together for one of the cocktail world's enduring classics.
name: Tom Collins Recipe
keywords: alcohol, club soda, cocktails, drinks, gin, Tom Collins

recipeInstructions.text: Combine ingredients other than club soda in a cocktail shaker with ice, and shake until well-chilled. Strain into a Collins glass with lots of ice and top with chilled club soda. Insert straw and do what comes natural.

review.reviewBody: Tom Collins is my favourite drink and has been for some time ... again, I too get funny looks as a twenty-something gal. But then again I've been known to order campari as well ...

We love this classic cocktail ! You're right, what a great cocktail to close out summer! Recently, we made a blackberry version of the Tom Collins and it was a hit at our parties. http://whiteonricecouple.com/blog/?p=291
The Tom Collins in second only to the gimlet in my book of summer cocktails. I like mine with Bombay (Dry, not Sapphire). And if collins mix gets anywhere near my drink I'm going to be cranky.

I am known as the queen of the vodka collins. One of my many voddie favs.
I don't drink gin.

this is my favorite drink to order in a bar - I always get funny looks. apparently 24 year old girls don't often order "old man" drinks. 

ha.

headline: Hearty Vegan Polenta and Kale Soup With Miso and Toasted Sesame Oil
description: This easy one-pot polenta and kale soup hails from Italy, but we give it a distinctly Japanese twist: In place of the Parmesan called for in a traditional recipe, we finish ours up with the addition of miso paste, soy sauce, and scallions. It's savory, rich, and 100% vegan.
name: Hearty Vegan Polenta and Kale Soup With Miso and Toasted Sesame Oil
keywords: Asian, easy, Italian, kale, miso, polenta, quick, soup
recipeIngredient: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
2 quarts homemade vegetable stock or an equivalent amount made with Better Than Bouillon No Chicken Base
1 quart packed roughly chopped kale leaves (stems removed)

recipeInstructions.text: In a large saucepan, heat olive oil, leeks, and a pinch of salt over medium-low heat, stirring often, until very soft but not browned, about 6 minutes. Add garlic and red pepper flakes and cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add vegetable stock.

Whisking constantly, slowly pour in the polenta. Stirring frequently, bring to a boil over high heat, reduce heat to low, cover, and cook, stirring occasionally, until polenta is tender and the soup is thickened, about 15 minutes.

Stir in kale, cover, and cook, stirring occasionally, until kale is tender, about 5 minutes. Stir in miso, soy sauce, and half of scallions until miso is fully incorporated. Season to taste with salt, pepper, and/or additional miso and soy sauce, if desired.
Serve, drizzling with sesame oil and sprinkling with remaining scallions. Extra soup can be stored in the refrigerator in a sealed container for up to 5 days.

review.reviewBody: My only issue with this recipe is that the kale leaves (a solid) are measured using quarts (a liquid unit, AFAIK). Why not go by weight?

I made this two nights ago and agree about the saltiness levels - it was intense! Had to dilute it a LOT and squeeze some lemon into it before serving to make it edible, and that's sans soy sauce. The leftovers congealed into a terrifying blob of solid polenta which surprised me as I'd added so much extra water to compensate for the salt! Great potential but didn't work for me as written - no big deal as I cook from these recipes all the time and this is the first that hasn't worked out. :)
yep, too salty for me as well. i ended up adding a bit of white wine to cut the richness. otherwise very good.

This was surprisingly excellent and is fast enough for an easy weeknight meal. It had great umami and tasted very rich, especially considering it's vegan. I also thought it was a bit salty (and I love salt), so next time I'll go with a low-sodium broth and add salt if needed. I'd suggest adding more kale if you'd like it more greens-heavy.

This was really good! A tad salty for me, I might start with less soy sauce next time. This will make it into regular rotation. I also might up the kale a bit... mine seemed to have less than your picture.

headline: Marinated Kale and Chickpea Salad With Sumac Onions Recipe
description: This salad keeps fantastically in the fridge, retaining its crunch and developing its flavor over time.
name: Marinated Kale and Chickpea Salad With Sumac Onions Recipe
keywords: chickpea, kale, onion, salad, sumac, thanksgiving
recipeIngredient: 1 bunch kale, tough inner stems discarded, leaves roughly torn (about 1 pound)
1 clove garlic, grated on a microplane grater
1 (14-ounce) can chickpeas or white beans, drained and rinsed

recipeInstructions.text: Combine kale leaves with olive oil and 1 teaspoon salt in a large bowl. Toss until evenly coated. Allow to rest at room temperature until kale is lightly wilted, about 1 hour.

Meanwhile, place onions in a medium bowl and cover with cold water. Allow to rest for 15 minutes. Rinse in several changes of water then carefully dry with a salad spinner lined with paper towels. Combine onions with sumac and sesame seeds. Season to taste with salt.

Combine lemon juice, garlic, and mustard in a small bowl. Once kale is wilted, toss kale, lemon juice mixture, and chickpeas in a large bowl. Season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve salad topped with sumac onions. This Recipe Appears In 
 Vegan: 2 Ways To Eat Kale, Chickpeas, and Sumac-Marinated Onions 
 Serious Entertaining: 'I'm Sick, Make Me My Dinner!' 
 The Importance of Hearty Make-Ahead Salads 
 Serious Entertaining: The Vegan, One Meal Convince-A-Meathead Challenge

review.reviewBody: This is one of my favorite recipes. Ever. So easy and you can have salad for a week that only gets better. Amazing.

@B art I make this all the time because I like it very much.

How about to each his own?
Can I omit the mustard? I can't stand its smell (though love mustard seeds very much and use them all the time).
You can also get Sumac from an online spice merchant like Penzey"s or Spice House. I asked for a bunch of extra packets of sumac last time I ordered persian food so I'm set for a little while.
I will try that thank you.

headline: Vegan Dan Dan Noodles Recipe
description: Classic dan dan noodles are made with pork, pickled vegetables, and plenty of chili oil. In this version, we pack in all the flavor and texture with mushrooms fried until golden brown and chewy.
name: Vegan Dan Dan Noodles Recipe
keywords: Dan Dan noodles, mushrooms, noodle, sichuan
recipeIngredient: 4 tablespoons roasted chili oil with some chili sediment (see note)
1 tablespoons fermented chili broad bean paste (see note)
3 tablespoons finely chopped preserved Sichuan mustard root or stems (see note)

recipeInstructions.text: Place mushrooms in the bowl of a food processor and process until pieces no larger than 1/2-inch remain, about 6 short pulses. Transfer to a small saucepan. Add vegetable oil and stir to combine. Place over medium-high heat and cook, stirring occasionally, until mushroom pieces shrink and are deep golden brown, about 8 minutes. Pour through a fine-mesh strainer set over a small bowl. Reserve mushroom pieces and discard all but 1 tablespoon oil.

While mushrooms are cooking, combine soy sauce, vinegar, tahini, sugar, chili oil (with its sediment), and broad bean chili paste in a medium bowl. Set aside. Bring 1 quart of salted water to a simmer in a medium pot and keep hot.

Heat reserved 1 tablespoon of mushroom oil in a large skillet or wok over high heat until shimmering. Add chopped Sichuan vegetables, fried mushrooms, and garlic. Cook, stirring and tossing constantly until fragrant, about 45 seconds. Add Shaoxing wine and stir to combine. Transfer mixture to bowl with sauce.

Return pot of water to a hard boil and add noodles. Cook, stirring regularly to prevent noodles from sticking to each other or the bottom, until barely cooked through with a springy bite, about 4 minutes. Drain, reserving 3/4 cup of cooking liquid. Add cooking liquid to bowl with sauce and stir to combine.
Place noodles in bowl and pour sauce with solids on top. Garnish with scallions and cilantro, and serve, stirring vigorously just before eating to pick up sauce.

review.reviewBody:
Thinking this could be really good with crumbled-up tempeh that's been 
marinated and then toasted, along with or instead of mushrooms!

At the risk of causing offence, is there any way of preparing a variant of dan dan noodles using beef or some other meat that is not pork, for those of us who don't eat it? Kenji, your blog is out of this world good! My eyes are opening to this beautiful world of szechuan cooking!

@Kenji -- Is there a substitute for black bean paste/sauce? My BF & I are vegan but he is also allergic to soy and wheat :'[ ... I've researched making your own fermented beans, but wanted to know if there was an easier way... Thanks!!

@Kenji -- this recipe (the basics) is quite a bit different than your original Dan Dan recipe you published here : http://www.seriouseats.com/dan-dan-noodles-recipe . Perhaps it's time to update / revise the original to more closely match the taste profile here? Seems like now you add chile bean paste, and use chicken stock etc. none of which are in the original? Cheers!

Maybe it's because I used homemade chili oil made with ground Sichuan chilies, but I didn't think this was too spicy and I sometimes have trouble with the spice level in Kenji's recipes. 
I only used 1/2 cup of the cooking water because it seemed too much and I actually threw the sauce in the wok to reduce a little because it was a little thin. This was probably due to using dried noodles rather than fresh (I have a lot of dried noodles so I wanted to use them, and these are actually labeled Sichuan spicy noodles). The flavor is wonderful and this was so easy. I'm already planning on making it again for a vegetarian friend!

headline: Vegan Chorizo for Omnivores Recipe
description: I wanted to make a vegan chorizo recipe that doesn't just come close to regular chorizo in the flavor department, but outright nails it. I wanted a meat-free chorizo with textural contrast up the wazoo, and a chorizo that changes texture as you cook it just like its meat-based counterpart. I wanted a chorizo that is tangy, rich, and complex.
name: Vegan Chorizo for Omnivores Recipe
keywords: chorizo, tempeh, tofu
recipeIngredient: 1 (10-ounce) block of extra-firm cottony (non-silken) tofu, drained and cut into 1-inch slices
1 (15-ounce) can black or Puy lentils, drained and rinsed
1 whole sweet dried chilies like Costeño, Guajillo, or Choricero, stems and seeds removed
1 to 2 small hot dried chilies like Arbol or Cascabel, stems and seeds removed (optional)
1 whole rich fruity dried chili like Ancho, Mulatto, Negro, or Pasilla, stems and seeds removed
1 whole chipotle chili in adobo sauce with 2 tablespoons sauce from can
1/4 cup vegetable shortening or coconut oil
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 tablespoon freshly toasted and ground cumin seeds
1 teaspoon freshly toasted and ground coriander seed
1 tablespoon yellow or red miso paste

recipeInstructions.text: Line a large plate with a double layer of paper towels. Place tofu on top in a single layer and transfer to freezer. Freeze for 15 minutes, then remove and let thaw while you prepare the other ingredients.

Adjust rack to 4 inches below broiler element and preheat broiler to high. Line a rimmed baking sheet with aluminum foil and place the poblano on top. Broil, turning occasionally, until blackended on all sides, about 6 minutes total. Remove from oven, lift foil and wrap it around the poblano to form a tight seal, transfer to a plate and set aside. Reduce oven temperature to 325°F (160°C) and leave the door open to allow oven to cool slightly.
Line rimmed baking sheet with a fresh piece of foil and spread lentils on top in a single layer. Transfer to oven and cook until mostly dry and crunchy, 20 to 30 minutes.

Meanwhile, place dried chiles on a microwave-safe plate and microwave until toasted, about 30 seconds. Transfer to a glass liquid measuring cup. Add raisins, chipotle chiles and their juice, and water. Cover with plastic wrap and microwave until simmering, about 1 1/2 minutes. Remove from microwave and let stand 2 minutes. Transfer to a blender and blend until completely smooth. Set mixture aside.
Cut tempeh into 1-inch pieces. Working in batches, transfer to a food processor and pulse until chopped to the texture of ground meat, about 10 to 12 short pulses. Set aside.

When cool enough to handle, carefully unwrap and peel poblano pepper, discarding skins and seeds. Finely dice cooked flesh. Melt shortening in a large saucepan over medium-high heat. Add onions and poblanos, season with salt and pepper, and cook, stirring, until softened, about 4 minutes. Add garlic, fresh and dried oregano, cinnamon, cumin, coriander, cloves, and cook, stirring, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add miso paste, soy sauce, red wine vinegar, and chile mixture. Add crumbled tofu, tempeh, and dehydrated lentils. Stir to incorporate and season to taste with salt and pepper. For a moister, saucy texture, add a few tablespoons of water. For a dryer, crumblier, well-browned texture, add 2 tablespoons more oil and continue cooking until most of the excess liquid has evaporated and mixture is dark brown with crisp bits, about 15 minutes. Serve in tacos, burritos, mixed with eggs, on nachos, or in any recipe that calls for fresh Mexican chorizo.

review.reviewBody:
I just made this. I left out the arbol (spicy) chile, because I'm a wimp, but it still has a really nice building heat that hits after you swallow your bite. It's super delicious, and I personally think it resembles chorizo a lot. I've eaten TONS of different Mexican chorizos, and they've all had their own unique flavor with some kind of inexplicable underlying sameness. This was no different.

I had to use dried lentils, because I couldn't find canned anywhere. I also only had those cheap green and orangey ones :X. I know it's annoying when people make a recipe differently than written and then write about their experience, but I really wanted to make this, had visited three stores, and was just ready to use what I had on hand, haha. 

I simmered the lentils for about fifteen minutes, drained, and then did the crisping method described in the recipe. I ended up broiling them a bit just to get them extra crispy... they're weirdly addicting to eat all on their own, so I'll make extra next time. I saved some to add right before the mixture is ready for dinner, so they retain their crispness. 

I did the 15-minute crispy method for the chorizo mixture, and it's still not as crispy as I'd like, but I think that's because I was working in a 10-inch TFal. Probably what I'll do is just pull out the amount we need for tonight's dinner (sopes), and I'll crisp that up on its own. Should be faster with a smaller amount of mixture. Gonna freeze the rest.

This took me about an hour and a half start to finish, including washing the dishes. Thanks for the effort you put into this! I'm not usually a faux meat kinda person, but I really felt like the sopes needed something indulgent.

This recipe looks incredible, but i got a few problem. 

I live in Germany so it would become allmost impossble get all these dried chilis, can i replace with one of a kind dried (you get in asia marked here). Can i replace mexican oregano with italian (neither available)? Aaaaaand can i replace tempeh with comletly frozen and crumbled tofu?

Thanks so far.

Making this took a while, but it was completely worth it. Fortunately it makes a pretty large batch, so I have plenty to save for later, and it has kept incredibly well in the fridge. The flavor is great, and I love the texture I achieve when I brown it until it's a little drier and crumbly. This will absolutely become part of my regular rotation. Thanks, kenji!

This was delicious and the house smells awesome! I doubled the recipe and plan to freeze it in smaller bags. 

One note - I used tinfoil-lined pans to dehydrate the lentils as instructed, and when I went to add them to the mixture on the stove, it was tough to remove the lentils (some of which had stuck to the foil) without the foil tearing. I tried to remove the foil pieces, but can't be sure I got them all. Next time, I'll use parchment paper or no liner at all, as I don't think I can safely use this batch in the microwave without some potential fireworks...!

Absolutely delicious. When I make this again -- and I certainly will -- I will probably make more of the crispy lentils (which are a brilliant idea) and put about half of them in after everything else is cooked. The lentils were still a great textural contrast, but not crunchy anymore.
 
I'm not a vegetarian but I like to eat my weeknight meals mostly vegetable based. The biggest thing this is missing from real chorizo is that magic that the aliums, spices, and chilis have when cooked in pork fat. So I'm very tempted to try using schmaltz rather than the coconut oil that I used. Lard would probably be better, but I usually have some schmaltz from making stock.

headline: Vegan Cauliflower-Creamed Spinach
description: This vegan creamed spinach uses cauliflower purée as a stand-in for the cream. The most amazing part: The dish tastes just as creamy, but is actually more intensely spinach-flavored.

video.description: Using cauliflower purée as a stand-in for cream produces a thick, rich, and even more intensely spinach-flavored creamed spinach. [Video: J. Kenji López-Alt and Vicky Wasik. Recipe: J. Kenji López-Alt]
video.name: How to Make Truly Creamy Vegan Creamed Spinach

name: Vegan Cauliflower-Creamed Spinach
keywords: cauliflower, creamed spinach, easy, spinach
recipeIngredient: 6 ounces cauliflower florets (170g; about 1/3 of a small head)
6 ounces almond, soy, rice, or cashew milk (2/3 cup; 170ml)
1 pound (450g) mature curly or flat-leaf spinach, washed well and roughly chopped
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Combine cauliflower and milk of choice in a small saucepan. Bring to a simmer over medium heat, cover, reduce heat to lowest setting, and let cook until cauliflower is completely tender, about 10 minutes. Using an immersion blender or countertop blender, blend into a smooth purée. Set aside.

Heat coconut oil over medium heat in a large saucepan until melted. Add onion and cook, stirring frequently, until softened but not browned, about 4 minutes. Add garlic and cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add nutmeg and stir to combine. Add spinach one handful at a time, stirring and folding until each handful of spinach is wilted, before adding the next.

Add cauliflower purée to spinach mixture and stir to combine. Bring to a bare simmer and cook, stirring occasionally, until spinach is completely tender and mixture is creamy. Season to taste with salt and pepper and serve.

review.reviewBody: Just made it. It's a nice spinach dish. There's no way I'd ever mistake it for creamed spinach, though. This is one of those vegan dishes that's just fine as a tasty vegetable dish, but really looses when compared to the traditional dish. It's a good spinach dish, and it is kind of creamy, but it's not creamed spinach.

@bdcbbq, I think it depends on your taste. If you want a super creamy, rich and heavy dish, then you'll probably like regular better. If you want the flavors of the spinach, nutmeg, etc. to come through a little more (but still be creamy), then this is better. Personally, I like this version better - sometimes creamed spinach is too rich for me, and this seems more balanced.

Interesting. I like this more for less fat and extra vegetables as a substitute.
Does this taste better than regular creamed spinach. I'm not vegan but subbing a little whole, 2%, 1% milk and maybe olive oil or such fat for the coconut oil do fine.
I made it with Yam, instead of cauliflower. It turned out absolutely amazing, better than other spinach dishes I´ve had. Thanks for the recipe!

This is a neat way to use cauliflower; a useful technique to get veg into other dishes. Sticking with the nut milk & cauliflower base and then folding in some butter or Reggiano would result in a truly perfect recipe. The best of both worlds!

headline: Vegan Carbonara Pasta Recipe
description: A vegan version of pasta carbonara that's silky and rich, dotted with meaty bits, plus the characteristic lactic tang of Pecorino Romano, but with no dairy products whatsoever.
name: Vegan Carbonara Pasta Recipe
keywords: Italian, mushroom, pasta, quick, Roman, tofu
recipeIngredient: 7 ounces silken tofu (1/2 of a 14-ounce block; 200g)
Generous pinch cayenne pepper or red chili flakes
1 tablespoon (15ml) white wine vinegar or fresh juice from 1 lemon
4 ounces (115g) king oyster mushrooms, stems and caps sliced into 1/2-inch "lardons"

recipeInstructions.text: In a blender, combine tofu, sauerkraut brine, nutritional yeast, miso, cayenne or chile flakes, smoked paprika, black pepper, and vinegar or lemon juice. Blend at high speed, stopping to scrape down sides if necessary, until a very smooth, silky sauce forms. Season with salt. Add 1/4 cup (60ml) olive oil and blend in at low speed just until emulsified.
In a large sauté pan, heat remaining 1/4 cup (60ml) olive oil over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add mushrooms and cook, stirring, until browned, about 6 minutes.

In a pot of salted boiling water, cook pasta until just al dente. Transfer pasta to pan with mushrooms, reserving pasta-cooking water. Pour on just enough creamy sauce to coat all the pasta, then add about 1/4 cup (60ml) pasta-cooking water. Cook over medium heat, stirring, until sauce forms a silky glaze that coats pasta. Serve.

review.reviewBody:
This was hands down the best pasta dish I've had in the last five years since my favorite Mediterranean /Italian restaurant closed down. I'm an omnivore but my vegan sister-in-law came over for Christmas Eve dinner so I made this. I'm not one to make a roast and then make the sole vegan eat only the sides or some kind of sad salad while we pig out. I made your Provencal Tian and between that and this dish we all -feasted- on vegan deliciousness and were completely satisfied. That sauce is unctuous in the best sense of the word and loaded to the top with umami. Those king oyster mushroom lardons were amazing. I can't believe the chew they had along with that delicious mushroomy essence I love. 

I'm making this again tomorrow with the other half of that block of tofu and the other king oyster that was in the pack we got. Then this recipe is going into my regular rotation.

I love this recipe so much. It’s been a standard in my rotation for two years. It’s so good that it gave me the reassurance I needed to go majority vegan (I don’t have hard rules , but, these days I mostly eat that way). I literally keep a jar of the sauce in my fridge to throw over pasta when I’m feeling lazy like it’s mac and cheese, it’s so easy to make from shelf stable ingredients that it’s a game changer. Often I use whole sauerkraut instead of just the brine because I don’t mind the texture and don’t like to waste it (I wouldn’t eat it too much otherwise). The mushrooms are so good, I don’t want to cook them any other way now. My only note is that this amount of pepper is kind of ungodly, I usually half it. I’m not normally one to comment on anything or review anything at all. But this recipe is perfect and this website has otherwise generally changed my life, I love to cook now and feel confident enough to invent my own things now, thanks for being geniuses.

That sounds great and I'll try it soon! Have you tried fermented Tofu/doufuru (in case you're not familiar with the stuff: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fermented_bean_curd, most Asian food shops have it) as a Pecorino replacement? It has a lot of the spicy stinginess and some tang as well, when I first tried it, it immediately reminded me of aged sheep's cheese. I'll eventually try it with this recipe myself in any case :-)

@Yosh Thanks for leaving your comment, it adds a useful insight which is that, indeed, this is meant to be served hot. Cooking the sauce with the noodles as per the recipe will be more than enough to get the pasta and sauce piping hot before serving, so there's no issue there in terms of technique.

Brought this dish to a party where I boiled the pasta, tossed it with the room temperature sauce and served. It was a total disaster!! The smell of the nutritional yeast was so off-putting, that I took it off the table at once, packed it up and took it home. Not wanting to waste, I thought id give the dish another try the next day. I heated it in the microwave and once the sauce warmed through, the dish turned out quite welll!!! The stank was gone!! Heating it thoroughly made a HUGE difference!! Not sure how you all read the recipe, but I doubt warming it over the stove while coating the noodles would have done the trick. Make sure to hear the sauce through!!

headline: Vegan Pancakes Made With Aquafaba Recipe
description: In the world of vegan cooking, nothing has shaken things up like aquafaba—the recently coined term for the liquid inside a can of cooked beans. In a stand mixer, that liquid can be transformed into a creamy, fine, stable foam with the texture, density, and many of the cooking properties of an egg white–based meringue. Today, we're using it to make light, fluffy pancakes.
name: Vegan Pancakes Made With Aquafaba Recipe
keywords: aquafaba, breakfast, brunch, pancake
recipeIngredient: For the Basic Dry Pancake Mix:
4 tablespoons (60ml) liquid from 1 can of low-sodium chickpeas (reserve remaining liquid and chickpeas for another use)
1 2/3 cups (about 14 ounces; 400ml) almond, rice, or soy milk
1/4 cup (60ml) vegetable oil, plus more for cooking
2 teaspoons (10ml) cider vinegar or distilled white vinegar
