Vegan butter substitute and maple syrup, for serving

recipeInstructions.text: For the Dry Mix: In a large bowl, combine flour, baking powder, baking soda, and salt and whisk to combine.

For the Pancakes: Place chickpea liquid and sugar in the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a whisk attachment. Whisk on high speed until stiff peaks form, about 6 minutes. Meanwhile, combine almond milk, vegetable oil, vanilla extract, lemon zest, and vinegar in a bowl. Add dry mix to wet mix and fold with a rubber spatula to combine (the mixture should remain lumpy). Fold in whipped chickpea liquid, being careful not to let it deflate too much.

Heat a large heavy-bottomed nonstick skillet over medium heat for 5 minutes (or use an electric griddle). Add a small amount of vegan butter or oil to skillet or griddle and spread with a paper towel until no visible butter or oil remains. Reduce heat to low. Use a 1/4-cup dry measure to place 4 pancakes in skillet and cook until bubbles start to appear on top and the bottoms are golden brown, about 3 minutes. Carefully flip pancakes and cook on second side until golden brown and completely set, about 3 minutes longer. Serve pancakes immediately, or keep warm on a wire rack set on a rimmed baking sheet in a warm oven while you cook the remaining 3 batches. Serve with warm maple syrup and vegan butter.

review.reviewBody:
I was very impressed!!! This is going into our family recipe stash, for sure. I made two modifications.

The first was omitting the lemon zest. I saw the other comments mentioning it was too forward. These pancakes were the most savory I've ever had before; I can understand wanting to add a zesty or floral undertone. Next time I might try only half the zest it calls for or maybe experiment with lavender.

The second was doubling the baking powder. I saw a YouTube video mention that using 4 whole tsp's was their secret to supremely fluffy mouth feel. This recipe has the whipped aquafaba though and I think that wasn't necessary.

Friendly reminder (because I've messed up pancakes multiple times and I finally got a good result): FOLD in your dry ingredients and whipped aquafaba. DO NOT "MIX". You don't want to exert any force into the batter because it will break down the lather. Don't fear lumps.

10/10 Would recommend, spiritually

I made this recipe for the first time today with two minor changes. I added the sugar to the dry ingredients instead of the aquafaba. I also added 1/8 tsp. of cream of tartar to the aquafaba before I whipped it. 

It seemed to work very well, requiring only about 2 minutes to form stiff peaks in the whipped aquafaba. The pancakes were fluffy and delicious. I doubt most people could tell they don't contain animal products.

I agree with the person who said the lemon zest was a bit too forward for a standard pancake, but still tasted good. I'm putting this in the good old standby recipe file!
This is such a good recipe for using up leftover chickpea water! It tastes so yummy and relatively easy to make, I highly recommend!
The pancakes look very appetizing. But I couldn't cook them. I don't know why(
These worked amazingly. Even my very meat eating friend loved them and said she'd never have known they were vegan.

headline: Veal Saltimbocca (Roman Sautéed Veal Cutlets With Prosciutto and Sage) Recipe
description: Veal saltimbocca, a Roman specialty, is a simple dish of sautéed veal cutlets, layered with prosciutto and fresh sage, and served with a buttery, lemony pan sauce. It's quick and easy to make, but to make it truly great, you have to pay attention to the details.
name: Veal Saltimbocca (Roman Sautéed Veal Cutlets With Prosciutto and Sage) Recipe
keywords: beef, cutlet, Italian, Roman, veal
recipeIngredient: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
Fresh juice from 1 lemon, to taste
1 teaspoon soy sauce (5ml), preferably usukuchi (light soy sauce) (optional; see note)

recipeInstructions.text: Arrange cutlets on a work surface, cover with a sheet or two of plastic wrap, and pound each with a meat pounder or the bottom of a small heavy saucepan or skillet until no more than 1/4-inch thick throughout. Season lightly on one side only with salt and pepper.
Flip veal cutlets so that the salted side is down. Pick eight of the largest sage leaves from your bunch and lay one in the center of each cutlet; if the sage leaves are small, use two per cutlet.

Lay a slice of prosciutto on top of each cutlet, sandwiching the sage leaves flat between them. Using two wooden toothpicks per cutlet, fasten the prosciutto to the cutlets (the easiest way to do this is to push the toothpicks down through the prosciutto and just into the veal, then back up through the prosciutto again, much like fastening them together with a safety pin).
Pour about 1/2 cup of cornstarch into a wide, shallow bowl. Dredge the underside of each prosciutto-topped cutlet in the cornstarch, shaking off the excess.

In a large skillet or sauté pan, heat 2 tablespoons olive oil over high heat until shimmering. Add 4 of the cutlets, prosciutto-side up, and cook, swirling the pan occasionally, until the cutlets are lightly browned on the bottom and the last traces of pink are visible on top at the edges. Using a thin metal spatula, flip all of the cutlets prosciutto-side down, then flip them back immediately. Transfer to a clean platter. Lower heat at any time while cooking the cutlets to prevent burning.
Add remaining 1 tablespoon olive oil to the skillet. Add remaining 4 veal cutlets and repeat as in Step 5, then transfer to the platter.

Lower heat to medium-low and add butter and a few sprigs of sage to the skillet and cook until butter is melted. Add white wine. Bring to a simmer over medium heat, stirring and scraping up any browned bits, then continue to cook, stirring and swirling constantly, until sauce is emulsified and slightly thickened (exact time can vary significantly depending on your skillet size and burner power; increase the heat at any time if it seems to be taking too long, or lower the heat if it's reducing too quickly).

Season with salt and pepper, then stir in 1 teaspoon of lemon juice. Taste and add another teaspoon (or more) of lemon juice, if desired. Stir in soy sauce, if using. If the sauce breaks at any point, whisk in a tablespoon or two of water to bring it back together. Discard sage sprigs. Pour sauce all over veal cutlets and serve right away.

review.reviewBody: Best dinner ever! We use chicken but still works like a charm.

thank you, daniel...a great recipe. we love it. a trick i'd like to share to help avoid tough veal: prick the veal with a hand tenderizer or skewer & then marinate it overnight in a mixture of yogurt, honey, garlic & soy sauce (for the salt & flavour). the yogurt i'd used for years but the addition of soy i learned from an egyptian site & it really works. :-)

Just made this and now I totally understand why it is called saltimbocca, it was really lovely, complex in taste yet simple in presentation and easy to make. Thank you for a well-written recipe. 
I followed the advice of someone in the recipe comments and used Marsala instead of white wine, and then skipped the soy sauce. This was because I am far away from every type of soy except from Kikkoman's standard sauce, which I didn't feel like using, but I can get Marsala by driving 20 km. The sage came from my garden, where I had to cut down my sage quite a bit, so now I'm eating all the sage recipes.

this is an interesting "easy take" on saltimbocca. I have found a couple of things that can be done to change it for the better, depending on what the cook wants to do. For one thing, chopping the sage and sprinkling it on the cutlet, and then laying the prosciutto BEFORE pounding is very effective in adhering the prosciutto to the veal. just have to be very gentle when pounding. Also, start off prosciutto side down in the pan, just to make it all stick, and then flip over and cook through.
Another option is to forgo trying that presentation at all, and cooking the cutlets as normal, without the sage/prosciutto slice, and instead making a richer pan sauce, and garnishing the sauce with prosciutto and sage.
It's fun to do the thing with the layer of prosciutto the first time you make it, but after that the novelty wears off and you may find that by doing it a bit more conventionally, it actually tastes better, too.

For the flat version, just a kiss of heat on the prosciutto side is recommended. But for the rolled version, the advice is to put the prosciutto on the outside of the roll instead of rolled up with the meat. I'd much prefer the rolled style, but what is to prevent the prosciutto from becoming overly crisp and salty?

headline: Vanilla Sprinkle Cookies Recipe
description: These vanilla cookies are covered in sprinkles, just like your local Italian-American bakery used to make.
name: Vanilla Sprinkle Cookies Recipe
keywords: cookie monster, Cookies, sprinkles, vanilla
recipeIngredient: 3/4 cup (1 1/2 sticks) unsalted butter, at room temperature

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium bowl, combine flour, baking soda, and salt; set aside. In the bowl of a stand mixer fitted with a paddle attachment, cream together butter, oil, sugar, and confectioners' sugar until fluffy, about 3 minutes. Add egg and vanilla and beat to combine. Add dry ingredients and mix just until dough comes together. Dough will be very soft but wrap it in plastic wrap and refrigerate for at least one hour.
Adjust oven rack to upper and lower-middle positions and preheat oven to 350°F (180°C). Line 2 rimmed baking sheets with parchment paper.

Fill a shallow bowl with sprinkles. Use a 2-ounce cookie scoop to form cookies into balls. Roll each ball in sprinkles to cover then transfer to prepared baking sheets. Bake until cookies are golden at the edges, about 20 minutes. Let cool 5 minutes then transfer to a wire rack to finish cooling. Cookies will keep in an airtight container for up to 3 days.

review.reviewBody: I was wondering if these could be rolled out or if they could be piped??
Love these cookies easy to make and are a crispy treat. I have made them several times.
These are exactly what I’ve been looking for. Easy and absolutely yummy! These are definitely going on our top cookie list!

How many cookies are in 1
 serving

I Loved the texture of this cookie. I made a double batch and used a 1.5 fluid ounce scoop. It only made about 3 doz. It would have made far fewer if I had used my 2 oz. scoop. Next time I'll use a 1 oz scoop.

headline: Ajo Blanco (Spanish Chilled "White Gazpacho" Bread and Almond Soup) Recipe
description: Sometimes called "white gazpacho," this elegant cold soup is thickened with almonds and bread and brightened with a splash of sherry vinegar.
name: Ajo Blanco (Spanish Chilled "White Gazpacho" Bread and Almond Soup) Recipe
keywords: bread, gazpacho, quick, soup, spanish
recipeIngredient: 1 cup blanched or Marcona almonds (6 ounces; 170g), see note
1 to 2 medium cloves garlic (depending on how strong you want the garlic flavor to be)
1/2 pound (225g) fresh, crustless rustic bread (see note), cut into 1-inch cubes (about 3 cups)
1 1/2 teaspoons (7ml) sherry vinegar, plus more if desired
1 1/2 tablespoons (22ml) extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for garnish and for serving
Green seedless grapes, crushed toasted almonds, and thinly sliced fresh mint leaves, for garnish

recipeInstructions.text: In a blender, combine almonds with water and garlic and blend at high speed until milky; you may need to stop and scrape down sides of blender jar once or twice. Add bread and blend until very smooth. Season with salt, then blend in vinegar and olive oil. If using a less powerful blender, you may want to pass the soup through a fine-mesh strainer at this point; with a high-powered blender, that won't be necessary.
Transfer soup to a sealed container and refrigerate until very well chilled, at least 2 hours and up to 2 days.

To Serve: Cut up grapes into smaller pieces and toss with almonds, mint, and just enough olive oil to coat. Season garnish with salt. Shake or stir soup well. Check consistency and thin with cold water, if desired. Adjust seasoning, adding more salt and/or vinegar, if desired. Pour into chilled serving bowls. Spoon grape garnish on top, lightly drizzling more olive oil onto each serving in a decorative manner. Serve.

review.reviewBody: If you’re not impressed with this when you taste it, the problem isn’t the lack of garnish. Garnish won’t fix this. The problem is that the recipe doesn’t contain enough oil and sherry vinegar. I made this today and wondered why it was so bland. I compared it with the recipe I’ve used in previous years (LA Times) and found that for the same or similar quantities of bread, almonds, and water, the LA Times recipe contains 1/4 c. of sherry vinegar, 1/2 c. olive oil, and 3 cloves of garlic. You can go light on the garlic if garlic isn’t your thing, but the extra olive oil dramatically improves the soup’s texture and the extra vinegar really brightens the flavor. Highly recommend upping the oil and vinegar if you use this recipe.
Just to say, as someone did above, blanching almonds is one of the easiest things in the world. 60 seconds in boiling water, drain and the skins slide right off!

My taste-buds were not expecting this! This soup is rich, and I struggled to finish a serve. However I enjoyed it, especially with the grape garnish. I used stale home-made cider rye bread, which imparted quite a strong flavour to the soup. I think if I were to make it again, I'd go with a simple white bread.
@cosmicook it's quite easy to blanch your own almonds (which I did).
Making this again but with a grape/cuke/mint sorbet for garnish

headline: Classic Vanilla Ice Milk Recipe
description: Like sorbet, ice milk is light and refreshing on a hot summer's day, but with the creamy, soft consistency you'll find in the best ice cream.
name: Classic Vanilla Ice Milk Recipe
keywords: dairy, dessert, eggless, frozen, ice cream, ice milk, milk, vanilla
recipeIngredient: 9 1/4 ounces plain or very lightly toasted sugar (about 1 1/3 cups; 262g)
1 teaspoon (4g) Diamond Crystal kosher salt (plus more if desired); for table salt, use about half as much by volume or the same weight

recipeInstructions.text: Whisk sugar, cornstarch, powdered milk, and salt together in a 3-quart saucier. When no lumps of cornstarch remain, add exactly 14 ounces of the milk (about 1 2/3 cups; 396g) and whisk to combine. Cook over medium heat, whisking constantly but not vigorously, until it begins to simmer. This will take about 6 minutes; if the process seems to be moving slowly, simply turn up the heat. When the mixture comes to a boil, set a timer and continue cooking and whisking for exactly 1 minute. This ensures the cornstarch is fully hydrated.

Immediately transfer mixture to a large bowl, then whisk in remaining milk, along with the vanilla (see note). Bearing in mind that the ice milk will taste substantially less sweet once frozen, season with an additional pinch of salt, if desired. Cover and refrigerate the base until cold, thick, and no warmer than 40°F (4°C), about 3 hours. (This process can be sped along with an ice bath if time is of the essence; in that case, a stainless steel bowl will help cool the base even faster.)

Churn in an ice cream maker according to the manufacturer’s directions. Meanwhile, place a quart-sized container and flexible spatula in the freezer. When the ice milk looks fluffy and thick, shut off the machine and, using the chilled spatula, scrape it into the chilled container. Enjoy as soft-serve, or cover with plastic pressed directly against the surface of the ice milk, then close lid and freeze until firm enough to scoop, about 4 hours. (The time will vary depending on the material and dimensions of the container.)

review.reviewBody:
Funny, I was thinking about Ice Milk recently while looking at ice cream at the store. 
I grew up eating ice milk in the 60's, it was cheaper than cream, and my folks were all about cheaper...
Now I remember others; Tab, Swanson TV dinners, Shake n' Bake, Fish Sticks. The dawn of the convenience food era.
Can you use something in replacement for the milk powder?
I grew up eating ice milk.
I loved it! 😊
I've just flavored it with tonka bean.. let's see...🙂

headline: New England–Style Frozen Custard | The Food Lab
description: True New England-style frozen custard (which is to say, ice cream) without the need to buy an ice cream machine.
name: New England–Style Frozen Custard | The Food Lab
keywords: desserts, frozen desserts, ice cream, The Food Lab, vanilla

recipeInstructions.text: In a large bowl or stand mixer fitted with the whisk attachment, whisk egg yolks, sugar, vanilla, and salt until pale yellow and mixture falls off of whisk in thick ribbons, about 5 minutes. Set aside. Stirring constantly, heat evaporated milk in a medium saucepan on stovetop until it comes to a simmer. Slowly add hot milk to egg mixture, whisking constantly, until fully incorporated. Transfer mixture back to saucepan and heat, whisking constantly, to 180°F (82°C) (it should become thick and custardy). Do not overheat, or eggs will scramble. Chill mixture completely.

Whip 1 cup heavy cream with whisk or in stand mixer until doubled in volume. Add whipped cream to egg mixture and fold with whisk just until no lumps remain. Pour mixture into ice cube trays and freeze for 4 hours, or until solid.

Combine frozen cubes of ice cream (use a spoon or a dull knife to remove them) and remaining heavy cream in food processor and process until smooth, about 30 seconds, scraping down sides and breaking up lumps as necessary during process. Transfer mixture to quart container, and freeze for at least 4 more hours before serving.

review.reviewBody: I just made this with my brother. The mixture wouldn't have fit into a food processor so we just used our blender which has and "ice cream" setting and also a pulse setting. We also didn't have ice cube trays so we froze the mixture onto a cookie pan (baking sheets) overnight in our freezer. Then we blended it, and froze it again in the quart container for a little over 8 hours. Even with these changes, our custard turned out perfectly! So, if anyone is worried about not having a specific item, don't be! It will still be amazing!

Ice cream contains eggs. Sherbet contains dairy, no eggs. Sorbet does not contain dairy. there are other variations on this theme, such as gelato, frozen custard, granite. as far as I know, most of the western world uses what is for some reason being called the "french method".
If you’re using pasteurized liquid egg yolks, can you skip the heating part, or is it still necessary?

I would just like to thank you for your explanation of the process and for sharing your scientific method as well! I am new to the whole baking/dessert thing. For me, cooking is an art. I never measure. I know when something is done by the way it smells etc. With that being said, I do have a scientific type of brain. I want to know the why of things. Which is why I discovered I like to bake, it's still art but done in a scientific manner. Have you written a book on such a process? I have been looking for a book that explains to me the why behind baking. For instance, needing salt to activate baking soda. How would a newbie ever know that? The difference between room temp eggs and fridge temp eggs. Things along these lines. Have you written such a book or know of such a book you can direct me towards. I like the way your brain works. I am about to embark upon my custard journey as we speak. Thanks again!

For anyone else looking at Kaels method, be careful. There's a reason Kenji spent a paragraph in the accompanying article writing about how specifically replaced the milk with evaporated milk to up the protein/fat content to make a smoother ice cream by reducing ice crystal formation. By modding the recipe to both reduce the eggs (provides fat and protein and stabilizers) and replace the evaporated milk with cream/milk (resulting in slightly more fat, way less protein), you're going to get a different result. If Kenji says:



>It was an improvement—enough that I'd use evaporated milk in all of my ice cream from now on. 



I'm going to take his word on it. 


@Cindy108

The only difference between this and the ice cream machine method is the use of the food processor/blender to break up to frozen cubes. To make an ice cream base for the machine, you'd need to use the stove/mixer anyway to make the base and you'd have to pre-freeze and clean the core of the ice cream machine after so it comes down to 1 extra bowl to wash. Ice cream machines aren't magic. They just mix and cool at the same time. It takes the same amount of work and prep to get to the same end result.





If the ice cubes are stuck and for some reason you don't have a silicone ice cube tray or the hard plastic kind that you can twist to loosen the cubes (like the OXO one SE recommends), you can just dip the bottom of the tray in a baking sheet of warm water to slightly melt the outside and it should just pop out.

headline: Vanilla Bean Simple Syrup Recipe
description: Making your own vanilla syrup at home is easy. Makes a great addition to coffee, tea, or cocktails.
name: Vanilla Bean Simple Syrup Recipe
keywords: easy recipes, simple syrup, vanilla bean, vanilla syrup

recipeInstructions.text: Add sugar and water to a small saucepan. Slice vanilla bean down the center and scrape out the black seeds. Add the seeds and pod to the liquid mixture. Heat over medium high heat, stirring occasionally until sugar has dissolved completely and mixture has come to a boil, about 10 to 15 minutes. Remove from heat and pour into a sterile glass container. Store in the refrigerator for up to one week.

review.reviewBody: hi; can I leave the pod in after you put it in the glass container??

headline: Ajiaco (Colombian Chicken and Potato Soup) Recipe
description: All potatoes originated in the Andes, and Colombia has quite a selection of them, the best being the small, yellow, creamy, buttery papas Criollas. They're eaten deep fried, salt roasted, boiled, or—my wife's favorite method—cooked into ajiaco, a classic chicken and potato soup from the mountains around Bogotá.
name: Ajiaco (Colombian Chicken and Potato Soup) Recipe
keywords: chicken, Colombian, potato, soup
recipeIngredient: 2 quarts homemade chicken stock (or low-sodium canned stock)
1 whole bone-in, skin-on chicken breast, split (12 to 16 ounces total)
2 pounds russet potatoes (about 2 medium) peeled and cut into rough 1-inch chunks
1 pound Red Bliss potatoes (about 2 small), peeled, split into quarters lengthwise, and cut into 1/2-inch slices
2 ears corn, shucked and broken into 3 pieces each
1 serrano or 1/2 jalapeño chile, seeded and finely minced
Kosher salt and freshly cracked black pepper
1/2 cup sour cream, thinned with 1 tablespoon milk
1/2 cup capers, rinsed, drained, and roughly chopped
1 ripe avocado, preferably smooth, light-green fuerte variety, sliced into wedges

recipeInstructions.text: Combine chicken stock, chicken breast, onion, bay leaves, potatoes, and guascas in a large saucepot or Dutch oven. Add more water if necessary to cover solids by 1-inch. Bring to a boil over high heat. Reduce to a simmer and cook until chicken breast is cooked through, about 10 minutes. Transfer chicken breast to plate and set aside until cooled to room temperature.

Continue to simmer potatoes until russets and papas Criollas are completely tender and falling apart, about 45 minutes longer, adding more water as necessary. Discard onion and bay leaves. Using whisk, mash potato pieces against side of pot and stir vigorously to thicken soup. The soup should be thick, with large chunks of potatoes still remaining.
Add corn cobs and continue to cook, stirring occasionally, until corn is cooked and soup is thickened to the consistency of thick heavy cream, about 15 minutes longer. Remove from heat.

While soup is cooking, make the aji : Combine onion, cilantro, and chile pepper in small serving bowl and add water until just covered. Season generously with salt and stir to combine. Set aside. Discard chicken skin and bones. Shred meat into bite-size pieces and set aside in serving bowl.
Season soup to taste with salt and pepper. Serve immediately, passing picked chicken, chopped capers, sour cream, and aji table-side for diners to add to their bowl. Serve avocado slices on the side.

review.reviewBody: As we do alot of vegan/veg cooking, we did the above receipe without the chickin broth( we used veg broth), chicken, and sour cream. We did add 1 cup of chopped carrots and 3 garlic cloves, chopped. Came out great.
I am making this today, to eat after the Colombia v Brazil game. Maybe some arepas to start off with!
I just tried this recipe and it was wonderful! Thank you so much for sharing!
I love Ajiaco, thank you so much for reminding me of it!

@kitchengeeking the restaurant Nikki is referring to is called La Vitrola, and to be honest the reputation exceeds the actual food quality in my experience having eaten there three different times and never having been delighted. The best seafood I had in Cartagena was in a "shack" restaurant called "El Boney". It's on the beach in Bocagrande across from Hotel El Caribe.

headline: Aji Amarillo (Green Peruvian Dipping Sauce)
description: A fiery, creamy green sauce made with jalapeños and aji amarillo that's perfect for fries and grilled chicken.
name: Aji Amarillo (Green Peruvian Dipping Sauce)
keywords: aji amarillo, condiments, green sauce, Peruvian, sauces
recipeIngredient: 2 fresh jalapeños, including seeds and ribs, roughly chopped
1 cup freshly picked cilantro leaves and small stems
2 tablespoons grated cotija cheese or Parmesan cheese
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Combine jalapeños, aji amarillo, cilantro, cotjia, garlic, oil, vinegar, and lime juice in a blender. Blend on high speed until smooth paste forms. Add mayonnaise and blend until homogenous. Transfer to a bowl and season to taste with salt and pepper. Serve with French fries or grilled chicken.

review.reviewBody:
This is a good recipe. I am Peruvian, and most of the time we do not use sauce like this unless it is at a restaurant... so this is good to know. Typically we just use Rocoto or Aji Amarillo straight up (at least in my community). Two tips:

- Make twice the amount that this recipe calls for - it blends more easily and this recipe just makes very little in general when you consider how fast you run through this!

- If your sauce is thin, use unsalted saltine crackers to thicken it up in the blender - this is very common in Peru.

Thanks for the great proportions and break down of the ingredients, it's pretty spot on!

@LizLemon: I've never been to Super Pollo in DC but I've had Crisp & Juicy Peruvian chicken out in Rockville and it's crazy good. 

Try the recipe for the sauce you seek here:

http://southamericanfood.about.com/od/saladssidedishes/r/ajiamarillo.htm

It's Aji Amarillo Salsa (also called Crema de Aji). 

The green sauce served at the Peruvian pollerias I go to are --similarly -- not creamy and are more herby and bright green 

It's called Aji de Huacatay Salsa. Some info about it can be found here:

http://chowhound.chow.com/topics/509782

Good luck with the sauces and buen provecho!

@Kathryn and @ Susquehanna: My favorite Peruvian chicken place in DC (Super Pollo) also serves everything with two sauces on the side: a sort of mayonnaise-like whitish yellow sauce, and a spicy, herby green sauce which looks like chimichurri. The recipe provided here, though, seems like a mix of the two sauces. Do either of you know of a recipe that would be for just the white sauce? I am obsessed with it. It reminds me of aioli but is actually so much better! Help!
Curious about the possibility of making the paste using dried ajis amarillos...

I love this recipe as much as I love the story behind it! This is a pretty solid recipe!!!! Much better than the one accompanying the peruvian chicken on the NYTimes :) I'm going to try making it again with little to no aji amarillo though as I thought it was just a tad too tangy. THANK YOU AGAIN FOR HUNTING THIS DOWN and that no scarce peruvian mint was needed!

headline: Uovo in Raviolo (Runny Egg Yolk Ravioli) Recipe
description: Picture this: gorgeous oversized ravioli filled with a ring of creamy ricotta surrounding a perfectly intact, perfectly runny yolk. They're rich, delicious, and freaking beautiful.
name: Uovo in Raviolo (Runny Egg Yolk Ravioli) Recipe
keywords: egg, Italian, pasta, ravioli

nutrition.servingSize: Makes 10 large ravioli, serving 4 or 5 as a main course

recipeIngredient: Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
2 teaspoons fresh juice from 1 lemon, divided
1 tablespoon finely chopped parsley, for garnish

recipeInstructions.text: For the Ravioli: Lay a clean kitchen towel or a triple layer of lint-free paper towels on a rimmed baking sheet. Spread ricotta evenly over surface of towels. Top with a second clean kitchen towel or triple layer of paper towels. Press with hands or a second rimmed baking sheet and let stand until excess moisture has been absorbed, 5 minutes. Transfer ricotta to a medium bowl (it should come right off the towels).

Stir Parmesan cheese, nutmeg, and 1/2 teaspoon lemon juice into ricotta. Season to taste with salt and pepper. With a spoon, transfer filling into a pastry bag fitted with a 1/4-inch round tip or a zipper-lock bag with a 1/4-inch hole cut from a bottom corner. Refrigerate.

Meanwhile, divide dough into 2 even sections. Working one section at a time, with remaining section tightly wrapped in plastic, roll dough through machine until sheet is just under 1/16 of an inch thick (typically second-to-last setting on roller). For a detailed description of this process, see steps 5 through 10 of our fresh pasta recipe . Cut sheet in half to create 2 pieces of dough roughly 15 inches long and 5 inches across.

Lay dough sheets out on a lightly floured surface. Using a 3 1/2-inch round cookie cutter, cut out circles as close together as possible; you should have 10 rounds of dough from the 2 sheets (if you don't, re-roll dough scraps and cut more circles). Cover 5 of the dough rounds with a kitchen towel to keep moist and discard any remaining dough scraps.

Use pastry bag to gently squeeze out a ring of filling approximately 1 1/2 inches in diameter onto each of the 5 uncovered dough rounds. Then pipe a second ring directly on top of each of the first ones.
Working one at a time, separate 5 egg yolks from whites and gently slide yolk into center of ricotta fillings.

Remove towel from the other 5 dough rounds, and, working one at a time and using a pastry brush dipped in water, very lightly wet the edge of each dough round. Set dough rounds on top of each raviolo, moistened-side down. Slowly working your way around each raviolo, press and stretch the top dough rounds to make the edges meet with bottom dough rounds. Press down gently on each filling to remove air bubbles, being careful not to press on yolks themselves, then press edges to seal. Transfer ravioli to floured parchment paper, cover with kitchen towel, and repeat Steps 3 through 7 with remaining portion of dough.

For the Pan Sauce: Bring unsalted water to a boil in a large pot. Meanwhile, in 2 large sauté pans, heat half of pancetta in each over medium-high heat, stirring occasionally, until fat is rendered and pancetta is lightly browned, about 4 minutes. Using a slotted spoon, transfer pancetta to a plate. Add half of shallot to each pan and cook, stirring, for 30 seconds. Add half of wine to each pan and cook, scraping up any browned bits, until wine is almost completely evaporated, about 1 minute. Remove from heat and return pancetta to each pan.

When water is boiling, gently slide ravioli into pot. Boil for 1 minute 30 seconds (ravioli will be slightly undercooked). Drain, reserving 1 cup pasta water. Meanwhile, return skillets pan to low heat and melt half of butter in each. Evenly divide lemon juice, pasta water, and ravioli between both skillets. Swirl pans gently to until sauce is emulsified, approximately 1 minute.
Transfer 2 to 3 ravioli to each plate and spoon pan sauce on top. Sprinkle with parsley and serve.

review.reviewBody: And you make the sauce in two pans because why?
OMG... Making this tomorrow night!
@beccascope it is 3 1/2 (3.5) inch. 3/12 (quarter) inch in the text is a typo and if you look at the Special Equipment list at the bottom you will see the correct size there
Doesn't look very effortless to me.
What is a 3/12 cutter? How many inches across should the raviolo be?

headline: Tuna Poke (Hawaiian Raw-Tuna Salad) Recipe
description: This super-simple tuna poke brings together fresh fish and salty seaweed for a quick and refreshing one-bowl meal.

video.description: In this video, you'll learn how to make tuna poke or Hawaiian raw-tuna salad. Watch as we show you how to make this super-simple tuna poke for a quick and refreshing one-bowl meal. We show you how to make this no-cook seafood main dish that is perfect for summer. See how you can make this delicious Hawaiian and Pacific Islander dinner. This video will walk you through each step in our tuna poke recipe.
video.name: How to Make Tuna Poke

name: Tuna Poke (Hawaiian Raw-Tuna Salad) Recipe
keywords: easy, Hawaiian, poke, quick, seafood, tuna

nutrition.servingSize: Serves 4 to 6 as an appetizer, or 2 to 3 as a main course with steamed rice

recipeIngredient: 12 ounces (340g) raw sashimi-grade tuna, cut into 1/2-inch cubes
3 ounces (85g) sweet onion, such as Maui or Vidalia, cut into 1/4-inch dice
1 teaspoon (about 3g) white or black sesame seeds, or a mix
4 teaspoons (20ml) soy sauce, more or less to taste
2 teaspoons (10ml) toasted sesame oil, more or less to taste
1 teaspoon (5ml) honey, more or less to taste
Steamed rice (if eating as a meal)

recipeInstructions.text: Place wakame and hijiki in separate small bowls. Cover with boiling water and let rest until rehydrated and tender, about 5 minutes. Drain and press with paper towels. Roughly chop wakame. Add wakame and hijiki to a large bowl.

Add tuna, onion, scallion, sesame seeds, soy sauce, sesame oil, honey, and optional crushed red pepper to bowl. Season with a small pinch of kosher salt and gently fold to combine. Taste and adjust with more soy sauce, sesame oil, honey, or crushed red pepper as desired. Let sit 5 minutes at room temperature, then serve on its own or on top of steamed rice.

review.reviewBody: Kukui is essential.
Hah. Interesting point. And yet you have left a thoughtful comment here that took you some time!

We enjoy this in our hot Texas summers. We do tend to add some diced avocado and water chestnuts too, for the richness and crunch, sometimes diced bit of jicama. Out of onions once (horrors!!) so used some french fried onions, was tasty that way too.
I'm going to be really interested to see what all the poke restaurants (that used to be frozen yogurt shops) turn into next. They'll have to be better. Ready for this food fad to end.

I mostly buy IQF whole fish from my local Asian markets. Typically the IQF fish I purchase are Sierra mackerel, bonito, striped bass, yellowtail, croaker, red snapper for use as sushi/sashimi, ceviche, and poke. I prefer to not buy fillets or steaks pre-cut since you don't know what you are actually getting. I like to hand pick the fish for quality then clean it and cut it myself. When available, I'll purchase fresh flown-in fish. I found a beautiful blue parrotfish from Hawaii and a California scorpionfish. Super fresh with clear eyes and delicious flesh. I was happy! 

~Chieko

headline: Ultra-Fluffy Mashed Potatoes
description: Our recipe tells you how to use one incredibly simple technique to produce the fluffiest and lightest mashed potatoes you'll ever eat.

video.description: Don't want to fuss with mashed potatoes right before serving Thanksgiving dinner? Here are three ways to make them ahead of time and have them come out just as delicious. [Video: Vicky Wasik. Recipes: Daniel Gritzer, J. Kenji López-Alt]
video.name: 3 Ways to Make Delicious Mashed Potatoes in Advance

name: Ultra-Fluffy Mashed Potatoes
keywords: comfort, holiday, mashed potato, potato, side, thanksgiving
recipeIngredient: 12 tablespoons unsalted butter (1 1/2 sticks; 6 ounces; 170g), room temperature, cut into 1/2-inch pats
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Peel potatoes and cut into 1- or 2-inch cubes. Transfer to a pot of cold water and rinse, changing water 2 or 3 times until it runs clear. Cover potatoes with fresh cold water and season generously with salt.
Set potatoes over medium-high heat and bring to a boil, then reduce heat to maintain a gentle simmer. Cook until potatoes are completely tender, about 15 minutes after reaching a simmer.
Drain potatoes in a colander and rinse under hot running water for 30 seconds to wash away excess starch. Allow potatoes to steam for 1 minute to remove excess moisture.
Set a ricer or food mill over now-empty pot and pass potatoes through.
Add butter and gently fold into potatoes.

Mound potatoes into the center of the pot and pour milk all around. Set over medium heat and bring milk to a simmer before gently folding it into the potatoes. If looser potatoes are desired, add additional milk in a similar fashion around the mashed potato mass and bring it to a simmer before folding into potatoes. Season with salt and pepper, then serve.

review.reviewBody: what happened to the Serious Eats database? so many recipes have erroneous amounts listed in their ingredients.
Thanks Daniel for updating the recipe, works wonderfully
The amount of milk is quite ridiculous but if you can't judge that by the consistency of your potatoes, no recipe can save you. Don't be a slave to the recipe and just use your common sense

I love everything Kenji does, so first I made it JUST as written. Small batch. It was good, no soupy problems. BUT-- for The Big Day, I followed the hints from my ancient James Beard cookbook, just as I have for the last 45 years. 
1. Big russets. Scrub and BAKE THEM at 400 or 425 until a fork finds no resistance. 
2. Then, holding each with a pot holder, break open and scoop out with a spoon. (Fast, easy, no peeling, and FLUFFY AS A NEWBORN LAMB. Well, fluffier.)
3. Then, most importantly, add only warmed ingredients!!! Otherwise, danger of gumminess!
4. Warmed 1/2 and 1/2, melted butter, perhaps some sour cream, salt, white pepper-- to taste. And I use a hand mixer-- slowly, minimally. (Arthritis has caught up with me.) They are so good that my daughter called from the Surinamian jungle for ideas on duplicating them with cassava and goat's milk.

Followed the recipe, except for step 4 (couldn't find my ricer, so I used my masher instead). Perfectly fluffy, perfectly seasoned, would make again. 

My tip -- if you use the amount of milk listed in the recipe and you think it's too much, wait for it to simmer off a bit (as directed in the recipe) before folding in, or just pour some out. Or, just add the milk a little at a time because the amount of moisture absorbed will vary from potato to potato.

headline: Adobo-Marinated Grilled Pork Chops Recipe
description: Filipino adobo is a classic dish, usually of stewed chicken or pork in a tangy, flavorful sauce made from cane vinegar, soy sauce, and aromatics. But the building blocks of the adobo sauce also make a great marinade for grilled meats, like the pork chops here.

video.description: Dry, chewy grilled pork chops can be a thing of the past: This video will teach you how to turn out thick-cut beauties that are everything an excellent grilled pork chop should be. [Video: Vicky Wasik. Technique: Joshua Bousel]
video.name: How to Grill Pork Chops

name: Adobo-Marinated Grilled Pork Chops Recipe
keywords: Asian, easy, marinade, pork, pork chop, vinegar
recipeIngredient: 1/2 cup (120ml) cane vinegar, preferably Datu Puti brand
Two (12-ounce; 334g) bone-in pork chops, about 1 1/2 inches thick
Warm cooked sticky rice, for serving (see note)

recipeInstructions.text: In a medium saucepan, combine vinegar, soy sauce, water, garlic, peppercorns, and bay leaf and bring to a boil. Let marinade cool to room temperature.
Place pork chops in a heavy-duty zipper-lock bag and pour marinade on top. Seal, pressing out air from bag, and refrigerate at least 8 and up to 24 hours.

Light 1 chimney full of charcoal. When all charcoal is lit and covered with gray ash, pour out and spread coals evenly over half of coal grate. Alternatively, set half the burners of a gas grill to high heat. Set cooking grate in place, cover grill, and allow to preheat for 5 minutes. Clean and oil grilling grate.

Grill pork chops over direct heat, turning occasionally, until well browned outside and 135°F (57°C) in the center for medium, about 10 minutes. If pork chops threaten to burn before they're done in the center, move them to cooler side of grill to finish cooking. Let rest 5 minutes before serving with sticky rice.

review.reviewBody: If you have citrus juice, such as orange or pineapple, substitute it for the water. Its a welcome addition to adobo.
Thanks @Warbler02! A longer marinade not only helps the flavor, but firms up the texture too. You can definitely swap in/out vinegars, but I like sticking to those that match colors.

These were a hit and easy to make. I marinated the chops for 8 hours but will definitely do the full 24 next time. I did use the Datu Puti cane vinegar as I found a bottle locally for only 1.99, but I frequently make Vietnamese grilled pork marinated in rice vinegar and the end flavor of this dish was practically the same.

@stlchef that's called sinamak, a spicy vinegar that usually a table condiment. I would give it a taste before using it straight 1:1 for cane vinegar, because it can be quite intense, maybe use a little bit of it for flavor, but use rice vinegar as a substitute instead?
The only version of Datu Puti I could find was a spiced version containing hot peppers and garlic as well. Will this work, and how should I adjust ingredients to compensate?

headline: Ultra-Crispy Slow-Roasted Pork Shoulder
description: Pull-apart tender meat and ultra-crisp skin: slow-roasted pork may not be the most gorgeous looking, but the flavor more than makes up for it.

video.description: In this video, learn how to make an ultra-crispy slow-roasted pork shoulder. Watch as we show you the steps and ingredients necessary to make delicious ultra-crispy slow-roasted pork shoulder. This pork shoulder recipe is perfect for dinner and features pork. See how you can make this ultra-crispy slow-roasted pork shoulder at home as a beginner or skilled cook. This video will teach you all the steps to preparing delicious slow-roasted pork shoulder to serve as a main dish.
video.name: Ultra-Crispy Slow-Roasted Pork Shoulder Recipe

name: Ultra-Crispy Slow-Roasted Pork Shoulder
keywords: holiday entrees, low carb, pork, pork shoulder, The Food Lab
recipeIngredient: 1 whole bone-in, skin-on pork shoulder, 8 to 12 pounds total
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven rack to middle position and preheat oven to 250°F (121°C).

Line a rimmed baking sheet with heavy duty aluminum foil (see notes) and set a wire rack inside it. Place a piece of parchment paper on top of the wire rack. Season pork on all sides liberally with salt and pepper and place on parchment paper. Transfer to oven and roast until knife or fork inserted into side shows very little resistance when twisted, about 8 hours total.

Remove pork from oven and tent with foil. Let rest at room temperature for at least 15 minutes and up to 2 hours. Increase oven to 500°F (260°C) and allow to preheat. Return pork to the oven and roast until skin is blistered and puffed, rotating every 5 minutes, about 20 minutes total. Remove from oven, tent with foil and allow to rest an additional 15 minutes. Serve by picking in the kitchen or just bring it to the table and let guests pick meat and crispy skin themselves, dipping into sauce of their choice on the side (see notes).

review.reviewBody: @wiserdays - the usual trick to avoid smoke in the final cook is to move the roast to a new (clean) pan between the long slow cook and the fast hot cook - you'll get a bit of smoke off the meat but it's the buildup in the pan and on the grate that overwhelms your exhaust fan. Make sure the oven floor & racks are clean as well.

I really don't get why there is so much confusion with this recipe. Take a pork butt for best cracklin. Turn oven to 250 degrees Fahrenheit . After you salt and pepper your roast, you lay aluminum on bottom then put down your rack and lay parchment down if you don't want to clean up the rack later. Put in the oven for 8 hours, or till fork turns easily when testing from the side if the roast. Remove the roast, tent, which means to lay foil over the roast. It can sit between 15 minutes to 2 hours. Turn your oven up to 500 degrees. Take foil off the roast and return to the oven. Every 5 minutes turn the pan a quarter turn. Not flipping it. Just the pan. It will crisp the skin. Remove after the 20 minutes is up. Let sit 15 minutes and voila it is ready. Bon appetit.

Really really good. I used Montreal steak seasoning instead of salt and pepper. I also peeled back the skin and put the seasoning on the meat and used toothpicks to hold it in place. It shrank back a lot, but the meat was still moist. When I removed the pork to rest while heating the oven, I tossed some skin on potatoes in the rendered fat and seasoned them with Montreal Steak seasoning and cooked them in a roasting pan while the oven was reaching 500, for maybe about 20ish minutes. Sooo delicious. Super easy. Much much better than the slow cooker version that I made last time.
Set off the fire alarm at the 500°f stage...... I recommend replacing the foil that collects the juices BEFORE proceeding.

For the poster who wanted an approximate temp, I would go for 195. That will get you close, but Kenji's method will tell you when it is done. I have had them go from six to twelve hours, but eight hours is a good average. There is a point in the cook, about 160 degrees, where they go into a holding pattern and will stay at the same temp for hours. That is the fat and collagen is rendering out and making the meat tinder. I usually smoke two butts at a time, with one of them I will foil it after fours or so and that one yields a lot of juice to add to both on them when pulled. At the time of pulling I "spray" the meat with apple cider vinegar and add some red pepper flakes. I am doing a brisket for Christmas and I will have two butts on the rack above the brisket to baste it while cooking. One thing that is good about cooking butts is they are very forgiving if you over cook it.

Tenting is draping or loosely covering the foil over the meat.

headline: Ultra-Crispy Roast Potatoes Recipe
description: These potatoes are parboiled, then tossed roughly in a bowl with a metal spoon until their surfaces are roughed and scratched up. All those microscopic nooks and crannies make for an extra-crunchy exterior.
name: Ultra-Crispy Roast Potatoes Recipe
keywords: potato, thanksgiving, The Food Lab
recipeIngredient: 4 1/2 pounds (2kg) russet potatoes (see note), rinsed, peeled if desired, and cut into 2-inch chunks

recipeInstructions.text: Adjust oven racks to lower and upper positions and preheat oven to 500°F (260°C). Place potatoes in a large saucepot and cover with cold water by 1 inch. Add 2 tablespoons (28g) salt and vinegar. Bring to a boil over high heat, reduce to a simmer, and cook until exteriors are tender, about 5 minutes. Potatoes should show slight resistance when poked with a paring knife or a cake tester. Drain potatoes and transfer to a large bowl.

Add fat to bowl with potatoes. Season with pepper and more salt to taste, then toss with a large metal spoon until exteriors are slightly bashed up and coated in a thin layer of potato/fat paste. Divide potatoes evenly between 2 heavy rimmed baking sheets. Spread thyme sprigs over potatoes.

Transfer baking sheets to oven and roast until bottoms of potatoes are crisp and golden brown, about 20 minutes total, swapping trays top for bottom and rotating them once halfway through roasting. Using a thin metal spatula, flip potatoes and roast until second side is golden brown, another 15 to 20 minutes. Discard thyme sprigs and serve.

review.reviewBody:
"I've been using this method ever since Kenji wrote about it. I don't add vinegar to the boiling water. And I don't roast the potatoes, I fry them."

So you change two of three major points of the technique, and the cooking method? Glad it turns out good, but you're not using this method. Comments like this on recipes drive me bonkers.

These are amazing and the recipe, like the humble potato, is flexible. 

I was working with 3 medium-sized russets, only had olive oil for fat and was fresh out of vinegar, so I omitted it. I overboiled by a couple of minutes and ended up cooking in a cast iron for 15, flip, then another 15. 

Tossed in the oil (room temp) with salt, pepper, oregano and fresh garlic. They were amazing. Can't wait to try with duck fat when I'm not cooking on a whim at 9:30 pm on a Tuesday. And can't believe I've never tried this method before. I can't imagine doing it any other way now.

What's interesting is that Sasha Marx recommends an alkaline addition (baking soda) for crispness while Kenji recommends an acidic approach with vinegar. Both make sense - next time I need to combine both methods at different steps of the process.

Dear Kenji

As a Londoner, roast potatoes are close to my heart. Your trick with the vinegar is superb. I do however question your cooking temperature. This might be more subjective and more to the British taste but I find the 500f (250c) a bit odd. 380f for about 1 hour - 1 hour 30 is the standard in the UK. I builds up a stronger and dare I say crunchier coating in my humble opinion. All I ask is this: did you experiment with temperatures or is the 500f a US standard and it was a no brainer for you?

By the way, I need to thank you for making my life better - the bar style pizza using a tortilla has blown minds south of the river. I have won friends and influenced many people with this (and may have passed off as my own).

The method is super reliable as are the results. I was in the middle of juggling the oven times and temperatures to produce three things that needed to be served immediately for best results. The potatoes are time consuming (I needed to make 3 kilos instead of 2), and the success of the salmon was the prime issue. I needed to know from the start how I could manage the potatoes by doing as much as I could hours before the crunch time. My convection was not cooking two pans at a time. It was taking forever! All that turning and shaking was eating up time. so I took one pan out of the oven half baked, so to speak. I set them aside, and they cooled. Would that be a bad thing?
Someone had suggested cooking them on a wire rack set into a baking pan to get the heat flowing over the whole lot, one pan at a time. I used a teflon-coated rack over an ordinary dark oven pan and transferred the pieces onto it. Bingo! I never had to touch them again! And the fact that they had cooled completely in their half baked state was no problem. They came out with excellent overall color and crispiness with the soft interior.
Even though the answer was buried in the comments, people still had problems getting the herbs to stick to the potatoes. I had warmed a few tablespoons of my oil of choice and poured it over the hot, fully-cooked potatoes in a large bowl. I tossed the potatoes until uniformly covered with the oil then distributed the herbs over the pile and tossed them again. Voila. Some fell to the bottom, but I gently stirred them up over the potatoes with a spatula. Most of the herbs stuck all the way to the table. 
I had to take all this food to a dinner ten minutes door to door. Alas, the potatoes did cool off, but a short warm time in the host oven didn't hurt them at all. Despite all the starts and stops, the potatoes were a hit.The only thing I would do differently is give the wire racks a quick coat with cooking spray as four pieces stuck a little one they were done. 
This recipe is not a stand-alone item on a menu. I'm sure a ton of potatoes was used in the development of the recipe. Things must have happened along the way. My experience was anecdotal and I no longer have the fire power in my now small kitchen to do the full testing of results. Are the results truly as good? I know that even in the future, I have to fit them into a dinner prep schedule. Anything I can do to streamline the process has to be done. What do you do?

headline: Waffle Iron Hash Browns Recipe
description: Using the waffle iron to make hash browns gives you crunchy bits outside and silky smooth potato inside, all without having to fuss over potatoes in a pan.
name: Waffle Iron Hash Browns Recipe
keywords: breakfast, hash brown, potato, waffle
recipeIngredient: 2 russet (baking) potatoes, about 10 ounces each, peeled and shredded

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat waffle iron. If it has temperature controls, set it to medium.
Squeeze shredded potato with a towel until it’s as dry as possible.
In a mixing bowl, combine shredded potato, salt, and pepper.
Using a silicone brush or paper towel, carefully grease both sides of waffle iron with butter.

Pile shredded potatoes into waffle iron, over-stuffing it a bit, and close lid. (The pressure of the lid will compress the potatoes and help them emerge as a cohesive, waffled unit.) Cook for 2 minutes, then press down on lid to further compress potatoes (be careful: lid may be hot).

Continue cooking potatoes for 5 minutes longer, then begin checking them: They are ready when potatoes are golden brown all over, about 1 to 2 minutes longer. Serve hot with eggs or any other breakfast foods.

review.reviewBody:
Had to try this as a Sunday Funday project with the grandboyz. I followed this recipe...mostly. >;) What I messed with is adding Kenji's step of m-waving the shredded potatoes 2 mn on high to gelatinize the starches on the outer sides. And I used ghee instead of melted butter=no smoke. I got a really clean potato-ey tasting result with no greasy slog to mop off. Killer recipe/technique!

 Males of the family asked for a repeat at dinner since the waffle iron "was already dirty". Aren't they considerate?
I use a potato ricer to squeeze water from potatoes for hash browns, for zucchini, even for salted eggpant slices.

I made these! Wonderful!

Instead of using the butter to grease the iron, I used a spray oil and drizzled the butter over the uncooked shredded potatoes. 

Thanks again!
I think using a Cuisinart Griddler might even be a better option here! And I happen to have one of those. I need to try this, NOW!

Good results for the first attempt. I did use a box grater and a Belgian waffle maker and I added some minced onion, so I had some variations to contend with and I think I should have squeezed them out some more. The total cooking time was about 11 minutes, and the ridges were thicker than I wanted due to using the Belgian waffle maker, and I probably should've let them go another couple of minutes to get them crispier (too hungry to wait any longer) but the results were good. I think next time I'll try my panini maker to see if I can get them to come out a little thinner and a little crisper.

headline: Waffle Iron Churros Recipe
description: Want to eat churros every morning? Then these waffled churros are for you. Plus, the nooks and crannies of the waffled churros provide space for the chocolate sauce to pool.
name: Waffle Iron Churros Recipe
keywords: churro, dessert, waffle
recipeIngredient: For the Topping and Chocolate Sauce:

recipeInstructions.text: For the Batter: In a small saucepan, bring water, butter, salt, sugar, and cinnamon to a simmer over high heat.

When butter has melted and sugar and salt have dissolved, lower heat to medium, add flour, and stir rapidly. The batter will form quickly as the flour absorbs the water mixture. Continue to cook over medium heat, stirring, for 1 minute.

Remove saucepan from heat and allow mixture to stand for 5 minutes. Add eggs one at a time to batter mixture, stirring until each is incorporated. The batter will be very stiff and look a bit like buttercream frosting.

Meanwhile, For the Topping and Chocolate Sauce: Mix sugar and cinnamon on a plate for dipping. In a saucepan over low heat, combine cream, chocolate, and corn syrup and stir frequently until chocolate begins to melt. Turn off heat and set chocolate mixture aside.
Preheat the waffle iron. (Set it to medium if it has temperature settings.) Coat both sides of the waffle iron with nonstick cooking spray.

Place about 1/4 cup of batter on each section of waffle iron. Do not overstuff waffle iron—the batter will expand considerably. (Err on the side of using less batter before you see how much it spreads out and rises.) Close the lid and cook until churros are golden brown, 5 to 10 minutes. Transfer churros to a plate and repeat with remaining batter.
Brush churros with melted butter and then dip them in cinnamon sugar. Serve warm with chocolate sauce for dipping.

review.reviewBody: I cannot believe how negative people are about this waffle recipe. It is a mashup. It isn't going to be a waffle and it isn't going to be a churro. It is a delicious waffle-shaped pastry. Choux pastry and churro batter are essentially the same ingredients and ratios. These waffles taste delicious and are easy to make, much simpler than deep frying churros. They are lighter than fried churros, but they have the same base flavor. They are definitely worth making. (But I do agree with one criticism: they really only make 3 waffles.)

I've made these a couple of times with great results. As mentioned this is pate au choux and employs the same mixing technique. Agree also that while they aren't really churros, they can be delicious and I think using the waffle iron is genius. The result can be very satisfying if you don't think of it as a churro but rather a crunchy, slightly sweet, creamy treat. 

Note to Woohoo: Hiding behind the veil of anonymity to criticize the creative efforts of people who publish ideas online (for FREE no less), only speaks poorly of you. Please have the courtesy to abstain from commenting or rating recipes until you have actually tried them, and then please show consideration. I've spent plenty of time in Spain and realize this isn't a Spanish churro. Nobody ever claimed it was! You may be surprised to know the Portuguese and even Chinese have equal claim to the origination of the humble churro (Google "you taio").

I rate this 5 stars for creativity - it inspired many spin offs that have put smiles on the faces of me and my family. This fall try adding pumpkin and sweet spices topped with caramel sauce. 

Note to other reviewers: These worked great with my Villaware Belgian waffler. If you have inconsistent results, try a friend or neighbor's.

these are pretty great. pate au choux in the waffle iron. with choco and cinnamon. if you don't think too much of churros, they're great. crispy on the outside, creamy on the inside, with a nice hit of choco and cinnamon. a couple points: it's a pate au choux. so, sort of an emulsion. as you beat the eggs one at a time in the warm batter, the thing will fall apart like mayo, then come back together. keep stirring! and, the one error in the recipe: you MUST fill the waffle grid FULL. this batter doesn't spread like a regular egg/milk/flour batter, so you need to use a spatula to spread the pastry around the iron if you want pretty waffles. also, i agree, this serves at best three eaters. double the recipe and serve four with leftovers.

Oh this was fun and made better with a few modifications: add more cinnamon to the batter and the sugar and also add some more salt to the batter and even on top of the waffles when they finish cooking.

While I have loved SE for a loooong time, I just created an account to comment specifically on this recipe. A grand total of 30min lapsed between my seeing this recipe, and eating my first waffle churro. AMAZING! Is this a waffle. No. Is this a churro. No (well, kind of). Does it matter if the batter is quite thick before putting on the waffle iron? No, just dump it out in the center of your waffle iron and close the lid. In fact, "real" churro batter also has to be pretty thick in order to squeeze it out of the star tip and have it hold shape in the fryer without turning into an amorphous blob. The end result of this recipe is a lightly cinnamon scented, churro-like waffle with a crispy exterior. Next time (and there WILL be a next time!) I'll add a bit more cinnamon to both the batter and also the cinnamon sugar. This recipe basically makes having a churro substitute a realistic dessert (cough... or lunch or breakfast) in my home.

headline: Waffle Cones
description: These golden-brown ice cream cones are sturdy enough to support your favorite scoops, yet delicate and crisp thanks to a blend of brown sugar and honey.

video.name: How to Roll an Ice Cream Cone

name: Waffle Cones
keywords: waffle cone, waffle cones, waffle cone recipe, how to make waffle cones

nutrition.servingSize: 1 heaping cup (11 ounces) batter, for about eight 5 1/2-inch waffle cones

recipeIngredient: 3 ounces egg whites (about 1/3 cup plus 1 tablespoon; 85g)
1 ounce roasted hazelnut oil, see note (about 2 heaping tablespoons; 28g)
1/4 ounce rum, vanilla, or additional water (about 1 1/2 teaspoons; 7g)
1/4 teaspoon (1g) Diamond Crystal kosher salt; for table salt, use about half as much by volume or the same weight
3 ounces bread flour, sifted (about 2/3 cup, spooned; 85g)
Neutral cooking spray, such as Pam Original, for greasing the iron

recipeInstructions.text: At least 30 minutes in advance, plug in the waffle maker and preheat to 300°F (150°C); on machines that lack specific settings, start with the medium setting and adjust as needed along the way. If a machine does not allow for temperature control, the ideal time for a given amount of batter will need to be determined individually.

In a medium bowl, combine egg whites, sugar, brown sugar, honey, hazelnut oil, water, rum or vanilla, salt, and baking soda. With a balloon whisk, mix vigorously for a full minute to ensure the baking soda is perfectly homogenized into the batter. Undermixing at this stage can produce waffle cones with a very uneven color and texture.

Sift in bread flour, and whisk until very well combined. With a flexible spatula, scrape and fold the batter several times to ensure perfect uniformity, paying particular care to the batter splashed up the sides. Rushing this step can produce waffle cones with an uneven texture. Let the batter stand 10 minutes before proceeding to the next step; if not briefly rested, the dough may be too thin, lacy, and brittle.

Spritz the plates of the waffle iron with a neutral pan spray, then add approximately 1 1/4 ounces (2 tablespoons) batter onto the center. Close the iron firmly and cook until the wafer is uniformly golden brown, about 85 seconds to 2 minutes. The exact cooking time and temperature will vary drastically from machine to machine; the idea is to find a setting and time that will cook the wafer at a gentle pace, helping drive out moisture without browning too fast. When cooked too fast, the wafer will be brittle and difficult to shape. When cooked too slow, the wafer will be pale, and will not crisp fully once cool.

To Shape a Waffle Cone: Place a hot wafer on a relatively non-conductive work surface, such as a clean kitchen towel or a cutting board. Set the waffle cone form on top, so that its tip is about 1/4 inch from the edge of the wafer, around the 10 o'clock mark. Fold the upper portion of the wafer over the form, and press firmly at the tip to create a seal. Roll the form over, working bit by bit to keep the wafer tight against the form, until you reach the outer edge. Hold the waffle cone firmly in place, seam side down, until cool enough to maintain its own shape, 30 to 45 seconds. Shaping the waffle cone is a skill, and will require a certain degree of practice to master. Transfer shaped cone to a wire rack to cool completely, about 15 minutes.

To Shape a Waffle Bowl: Place a small bowl or ramekin, preferably one with smooth, rounded edges, upside down on a work surface, and have a second, identical bowl or ramekin at the ready. Immediately after griddling, place a hot wafer over the inverted ramekin, then place the second ramekin on top and gently press to nestle the two together. If desired, the excess wafer can be shaped by hand, to create a "frill" around the edges. When the wafer is cool enough to hold its own shape, remove from the ramekins (if left too long, it may stick to either ramekin).

Repeat cooking and shaping procedure with remaining batter, spraying the iron with cooking spray in between each wafer. As soon as the waffle cones or bowls have cooled to room temperature, immediately transfer to an airtight container. The waffle cones and bowls are extremely susceptible to the effects of humidity, and can begin softening in as little as 15 minutes if left in the open. Likewise, if stored in a container while warm, the waffle cones and bowls may steam themselves and soften. But if properly cooked and well protected from air, the cones and bowls will keep for a week or more at cool room temperature. Small sandwich-sized zip-top bags are ideal for protecting and storing individual cones or bowls.

review.reviewBody:
These did not get crisp for me, even though I baked them nice and dark. I followed the recipe, following your suggestion to substitute the hazelnut oil in my trial batch. 
I just have a cheap waffle cone iron so that could be the problem, but I've made other waffle cones in it with more success, although they didn't taste as good.
Would this work in a pizzelle maker? I love waffle cones.... :D

Great recipe. Worked just fine with my not so expensive waffle cone maker. Used butter instead of hazelnut oil. Baked for 2 minutes at medium heat. Came out perfect and super crispy. Just the right sweetness!!!

Where can you purchase the happybuy waffle cone maker? I’ve tried google and was unsuccessful. 
Thank you 😊
Two questions: can the oil be replaced with melted butter? Can the honey be replaced with a dark syrup?

headline: Vodka Pizza
description: Pizza with vodka sauce is a richer, creamier, spicier alternative to traditional tomato sauce pies.
name: Vodka Pizza
keywords: pizza, the pizza lab, vodka
recipeIngredient: 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for drizzling
1 (28-ounce) can whole peeled tomatoes, roughly broken up by hand
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1 recipe Basic New York Pizza Dough, divided and risen at least 2 hours
1 pound fresh mozzarella (preferably buffalo milk), torn into rough 3/4- to 1-inch chunks and drained in a fine mesh strainer set over a bowl

recipeInstructions.text: Heat olive oil in a medium saucepan over medium heat until shimmering. Add garlic, oregano, and pepper flakes and cook, stirring constantly, until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add tomatoes. Increase heat to high, bring to a boil, then reduce to a bare simmer. Cook, stirring occasionally, until reduced by 1/4, about 20 minutes. Add heavy cream, increase heat to bring to a boil, reduce to a simmer, and continue to cook until reduced again by 1/4, about 20 minutes longer. Add vodka and cook for 7 minutes. Remove from heat and season to taste with salt and pepper.

Let sauce cool slightly, then transfer half of sauce to the jar of a blender. Blend, starting on lowest speed and gradually increasing to high until completely smooth, about 2 minutes total. Strain through a fine-mesh strainer into a medium bowl. Repeat with remaining half of sauce. (For storing extra sauce, see Make-Ahead and Storage below).
At least 45 minutes before baking, place a baking stone or steel on an oven rack set to the top position and preheat oven to 550°F (290°C).

Turn single dough ball out onto lightly flour surface. Gently press out dough into rough 8-inch circle, leaving outer 1-inch higher than the rest. Gently stretch dough by draping over knuckles into a 12 to 14-inch circle about 1/4-inch thick. Transfer to pizza peel.

Spread approximately 3/4 cup of sauce evenly over surface of crust, leaving 1/2 to 1-inch border along edge. Place 8 to 10 chunks of mozzarella evenly over surface of pizza and scatter with 4 to 5 basil leaves. Drizzle with about 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil and sprinkle with salt. Slide pizza onto stone or steel and bake until cheese is melted and crust underbelly is spotty brown, 6 to 12 minutes total. Remove from oven with metal pizza peel, transfer to cutting board, slice, and serve. Repeat steps 3 and 4 with remaining ingredients to make 2 additional pizzas.

review.reviewBody: Hmm... I'm confused as to why you strain it at the end. When I tried to strain it through cheesecloth, all that came out was a watery, unsauce like sauce. Maybe cheesecloth is too fine for this application. But that is the closest I have to a fine mesh strainer... Other than my cocktail strainer. Maybe i didn't try hard enough because it was hot. Long story short I ended up abandoning the straining venture... We'll see how it is on my pizza tonight.
The pictured pizza pretty obviously has some grated cheese that has browned on the edges. Do you leave that out of the recipe on purpose?

@fredipus

Ah, I might have tossed some Romano on that particular one. Not essential, but a nice touch!

Think you merged a few recipes there in the directions... "Place cherry peppers in the work bowl of a food processor. Pulse until finely chopped, 8 to 10 short pulses." and cook until "coppa has started to crisp"

headline: Frisco Recipe
description: The Frisco is the product of a long evolutionary process in 20th century mixology. Originating no later than the early 1930s--that's the earliest reference I've found for it, anyway--the drink crawled out of the cocktail equivalent of the primordial soup as a short, sharp burst of rye whiskey with a slight touch of the French herbal liqueur Benedictine and a twist of lemon peel for excitement.
name: Frisco Recipe
keywords: Benedictine, cocktails, whiskey

recipeInstructions.text: Combine ingredients in a cocktail shaker and fill with ice. Shake well for 10 seconds and strain into a chilled cocktail glass.

headline: Vinegar Coleslaw
description: This sweet and tangy vinegar coleslaw is a great accompaniment to rich barbecue.
name: Vinegar Coleslaw
keywords: coleslaw recipe vinegar, vinegar coleslaw, vinegar coleslaw recipe, vinegar based coleslaw
recipeIngredient: 1 teaspoon finely minced garlic (about 1 medium clove)
1 large head green cabbage (about 3 1/2 pounds), finely shredded on a mandoline or by hand
1 large carrot, peeled and grated on the large holes of a box grater
1 medium yellow onion, finely sliced on a mandoline or by hand

recipeInstructions.text: For the Dressing: In a small bowl, whisk together vinegar, sugar, oil, garlic, salt, black pepper, and celery seeds until sugar is dissolved.

For the Slaw: Combine cabbage, carrots, and onion in a large bowl. Sprinkle with sugar and salt and toss to combine. Let stand 5 minutes, then transfer to a large colander and rinse thoroughly under cold running water.

Transfer vegetables to a salad spinner and spin dry. Alternatively, transfer to a large rimmed baking sheet lined with a triple layer of paper towels or a clean kitchen towel and blot mixture dry with more towels. Return to large bowl.
Pour dressing over vegetables and toss to coat. Adjust seasoning to taste with salt and sugar.

review.reviewBody:
This turned out great but a bit too sweet, needed more carrots and was not as piquant as I was hoping it would be. Also, I had to use two large bowls to house the cabbage/carrot/onion mix. Also also, I broke down all the vegetables by hand, so it took about an hour as opposed to the half hour the recipe predicts.

I'll reduce the sugar next time and maybe throw in some pepper flakes to customize the flavor for my taste. 

Extracting the water from the cabbage with sugar and salt was a good call, it was ready to eat almost immediately.

Made the slaw once. Which was a mistake.
I am now required to provide the slaw for our monthly event. 
Been going on for a year.
Question… the written procedures state a one to one vinegar/sugar ratio for the dressing. Then the recipe shows a 2:1 ratio.

A great base recipe! I just made it again with brussel sprouts instead of cabbage. And only made 25% (dividing everything by 4). I had to use white vinegar because I was out of apple cider vinegar - it was less sweet & I liked that.

This coleslaw is awesome. I usually halve or even quarter the amount of sugar in both the dressing and what's used to sprinkle on the cabbage. Agree that the salad spinning step is kind of a pain in the kiester. But it's durned tasty.

Hmm. Just made this for the first time. I found the step of rinsing and salad spinning the whack of shredded veggies tricky. They absorbed a lot of water, and basically broke my salad spinner. Possible I shredded too finely? I also found the veggies continued to taste salty and sweet after rinsing for maybe the same reason. The dressing tasted good but very sweet, and seemed to be a lot for the volume of vegetable -- of course you can always add more!

headline: Homemade Bagel Bites
description: If you can't understand the allure of made-from-scratch Bagel Bites, there's nothing I can say or do to convince you. This is a recipe for the hardcore fans, those of us who've longed for bite-size pizza poppers that taste as good as we remember—chewy, cheesy, salty, and crisp.

video.description: With our recipe for homemade bagels that stay fresh for days, you can make these DIY Bagel Bites at your leisure. [Video: Vicky Wasik. Recipe: Stella Parks]
video.name: How to Make Homemade Bagel Bites

name: Homemade Bagel Bites
keywords: bagel, Bake, bread, mozzarella, pizza, snack, tangzhong, yukone
recipeIngredient: 1 ounce barley malt syrup (4 teaspoons; 30g), optional
Quick and Easy Italian-American Red Sauce
Salt, pepper, and fennel seed to taste
12 ounces finely shredded mozzarella cheese (3 cups; 340g)
6 ounces pepperoni, such as Vermont Smoke & Cure (1 link; 170g)

recipeInstructions.text: For the Mini Bagels: Prepare dough as directed, then divide into 16 equal portions, about 1 1/2 ounces or 43g each. Cup a portion of dough beneath your palm and work in quick, circular motions to form a tight skin around the ball, with only a tiny seam along the bottom. If the seam is large or irregular, continue rounding until the bottom is nearly smooth. Cover with plastic and let rest 15 minutes. Poke a hole into the center of each portion with a damp fingertip, then gently stretch into a 1 1/2–inch ring, wetting your hands in cold water as needed to prevent sticking. Arrange on a well-greased, parchment-lined half sheet pan, cover with plastic, and refrigerate 24 to 36 hours, depending on your schedule.

To Boil and Bake: Adjust oven rack to lower-middle position and preheat to 425°F (220°C). Nest a wire baking rack in a half sheet pan, then cover with parchment. Fill a stainless steel pot with about 3 inches of water, stir in malt syrup (if using), and bring to a boil over high heat. Meanwhile, line a baking sheet or cutting board with a thick layer of paper towels. Working with three or four at a time, boil the bagels, about 15 seconds per side. Place on paper towels, then immediately transfer to the prepared half sheet pan. (If left on the paper towels too long, the bagels will stick; if this happens, quickly dip the bagel back into the hot water, and the wet paper towel will peel right off.) Bake until blistered and golden brown all over, about 18 minutes. Cool at least 15 minutes before proceeding to the next step, or store mini bagels up to 36 hours in a paper bag.

To Finish: Adjust oven rack to lower-middle position and preheat to 450°F (230°C). Split mini bagels horizontally with a serrated knife, arrange half on a parchment-lined baking sheet, and toast only until their surface is a little dry, about 5 minutes. Top each with a few tablespoons of red sauce, followed by a sprinkle of salt, pepper, and fennel seeds, followed by a generous mound of cheese and a small handful of diced pepperoni. Bake until the cheese is melted and golden brown, about 16 minutes, and serve immediately. Repeat with remaining bagel halves for round two.

review.reviewBody: loved it brought my child hood back
To save a little time and little money. yummy and unique recipe! love it

The finished product was great, if a little over baked. I'm still thinking I didn't boil the bagels long enough. But with homemade sauce, cheese and pepperoni squares on top we enjoyed our from scratch bagel bites.

No rating yet, as I'm just commenting on the mini bagel portion at this point. My minis took well over 18 minutes to turn brown, 23 minutes, and they were still white on the bottom even though I used the specified wire rack. I flipped them and cooked them 3 more minutes to at least get them a golden color. I never did see blisters really. I know my oven is true to temp because it's new and because it has done other recipes just fine. I just thought I should mention the extra time.

Maybe I didn't boil them long enough? I counted the seconds, then flipped, then took them out when they floated.

Made these tonight, was not disappointed!

I was convinced that either my yeast was bad (unlikely since I used it successfully recently) or that my yukone was too hot and killed the yeast (also unlikely since I tested it), because after 36 hours in the fridge the mini bagels had exactly zero rise and were dense and stodgy. Continued on and they rose properly in the oven--perhaps too much since they ended up more spherical than bagel shaped.

Turns out spherical mini bagels still make excellent bagel bites.

headline: Vieux Carré
description: Born in New Orleans, this stiff cocktail of rye and Cognac is a drink to sip and savor.

video.description: In this video, you'll learn how to make vieux carre cocktails. Watch and follow along as this rye whiskey cocktail is brought together quickly and easily. This video shows you how to make this famous new orleans cocktail. Learn how to make this rye and cognac cocktail in under two minutes for a quick and beginner-friendly drink. See how easy this cocktail is to prepare for even those who are new to mixed drinks.
video.name: How to Make a Vieux Carré

name: Vieux Carré
keywords: alcohol, Benedictine, brandy, cocktails, cognac, drinks, rye, vermouth, whiskey

recipeInstructions.text: Combine all ingredients in a mixing glass and fill with ice; stir well for 20 seconds and strain into an ice-filled old fashioned glass. Garnish with a cherry.

review.reviewBody:
nice i like ..drink 
acemaxs31.com

This drink looks great, but I haven't had a chance to try it yet. Does anyone know where the Old Fashioned glass in the picture comes from? It looks really nice, but I haven't been able to track it down with reverse image search.

headline: 30-Minute Tuscan White Bean Soup
description: The key is plenty of rosemary and a hunk of rind from some good Parmigiano-Reggiano tossed in while it simmers. That and plenty of good olive oil for drizzling.
name: 30-Minute Tuscan White Bean Soup
keywords: beans, kale, low carb, quick, soup, swiss chard
recipeIngredient: 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil, plus more for serving
4 cloves garlic, minced on a microplane grater
1 quart homemade or low-sodium canned chicken broth
2 (15-ounce) cans white beans (cannellini or great northern), with their liquid
4 6-inch sprigs rosemary, leaves finely chopped and stems reserved
3 to 4 cups roughly chopped kale or swiss chard leaves
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper

recipeInstructions.text: Heat olive oil in a large saucepan over medium-high heat until shimmering. Add onions, carrots, and celery and cook, stirring frequently, until softened but not browned, about 3 minutes. Add garlic and dried red pepper flakes and cook, stirring constantly until fragrant, about 1 minute. Add chicken broth, beans and their liquid, rosemary stems, parmesan rind, and bay leaves. Increase heat to high, and bring to a boil. Reduce to a bare simmer, add kale, cover and cook for 15 minutes.

Discard the bay leaves and rosemary stems. Use a hand blender to roughly puree part of the beans until desired consistency is reached. Alternatively, transfer 2 cups of soup to a blender or food processor and process until smooth (start on low speed and increase to high to prevent blender blow-out). Return to the soup and stir to combine. Season to taste with salt and pepper.
Ladle into bowls, sprinkle with reserved chopped rosemary leaves, drizzle with extra-virgin olive oil and a grating of Parmigiano-Reggiano, and serve with crusty toasted bread.

review.reviewBody: Love it. Needs lemon juice.

I have now made this recipe three ways:
 According to the original instructions: Delicious; now in regular rotation
 Modified to vegetarian stock: Did not disappoint
 With the addition of italian sausage: Fabulous -- others might want to try a spicier one or Andouille.


When I,ve been in a bigger hurry have done it without blending any beans. Was fine that way, though blended is better
We loved the soup! I did add a fennel bulb with fronds, lemon zest and extra garlic because, garlic. Next time I might add an extra can of beans.

I make a very similar soup often, and it's delicious. If you have some spicy italian sausage laying around, cook it first, use the rendered fat instead of (or in addition to) the olive oil to cook the mirepoix, and add the sausage back to the soup at the end. It adds another layer of flavor, taking this into richer territory.

And I'm not sure I'd classify the parm rind as "optional" - I think it's a pretty integral element of the stock. Definitely not nearly as interesting without it.

I love this soup. Don't forget: use your go-to umami flavors here. Fish Sauce, Marmite, Worcestershire, or even MSG (don't tell your mom). There is the expectation from JKLA to season this dish on your own, and he gives you tthis license from his printed book (if not from this particular recipe). I use all of these umami boosters in this soup as well as most of his slow cook recipes, and it has glorious results. Lemon juice is recommended from other users (salt-fat-acid-heat), and is great, but don't sleep on adding some hot Italian sausage and/or pork sausage to this recipe if you are not overly concerned with this being vegitarian or meat-free.
